eng: "My dear Mr. Bennet," said his lady to him one day, "have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last?"
fr: Mon cher Monsieur Bennet, dit un jour Mistriss Bennet a son mari, avez-vous oui dire que Netherfield-Parck fut enfin loue ?

eng: Mr. Bennet replied that he had not.
fr: Monsieur Bennet repondit qu'il n'en avoit pas entendu parler.

eng: "But it is," returned she; "for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she told me all about it."
fr: Cela est ainsi cependant, car je le tiens de Mistriss Long, qui sort d'ici.

eng: Mr. Bennet made no answer.
fr: M. Bennet ne repondit pas.

eng: "Do not you want to know who has taken it?" ~~~ cried his wife impatiently.
fr: Mais ne desirez-vous donc point savoir a qui, s'ecria sa femme avec impatience ?

eng: "_You_ want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it."
fr: -- Vous desirez me le dire ; et je n'ai aucune raison de vous refuser de l'entendre.

eng: "Bingley."
fr: -- Bingley.

eng: "Is he married or single?"
fr: -- Est-il marie ?

eng: "Oh! ~~~ single, my dear, to be sure!
fr: -- Non, certainement, mon cher !

eng: A single man of large fortune; four or five thousand a year. ~~~ What a fine thing for our girls!"
fr: Un homme qui a une grande fortune, quatre ou cinq mille livres sterlings, peut-etre ; quelle bonne affaire pour mes filles !

eng: "How so? ~~~ how can it affect them?"
fr: -- Comment, quel rapport a-t-il donc avec elles ?

eng: "My dear Mr. Bennet," replied his wife, "how can you be so tiresome!
fr: -- Mon cher Monsieur Bennet, que vous etes desagreable ; ne voyez-vous pas que je pense a lui en faire epouser une ?

eng: You must know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them."
fr: -- Est-ce son intention en venant s'etablir ici ?

eng: "Is that his design in settling here?"
fr: -- Son intention, quelle absurdite !

eng: "Design! ~~~ nonsense, how can you talk so!
fr: Comment pouvez-vous parler ainsi ?

eng: But it is very likely that he _may_ fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as soon as he comes."
fr: Il ne les connoit pas ; mais il est tres-probable qu'il deviendra fort amoureux de l'une d'elles.

eng: "I see no occasion for that.
fr: Ainsi, vous devez lui faire une visite aussitot qu'il sera arrive.

eng: You and the girls may go, or you may send them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better, for as you are as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley might like you the best of the party."
fr: -- Je ne vois pas que ce soit necessaire ; vous et vos filles, a la bonne heure, et peut-etre meme seroit-il encore mieux de les y envoyer seules ; votre beaute pourroit leur faire tort.

eng: "My dear, you flatter me.
fr: Il seroit facheux que M. Bingley vous donnat la preference.

eng: I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but I do not pretend to be any thing extraordinary now.
fr: -- Vous me flattez, mon cher Monsieur Bennet, je n'ai certainement pas a me plaindre ; j'ai ete tres-belle dans mon temps, mais, a present, je ne crois pas etre fort remarquable.

eng: When a woman has five grown up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty."
fr: Lorsqu'une femme a cinq grandes filles, elle ne doit plus penser a sa beaute.

eng: "In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of."
fr: Il est bien rare alors qu'elle puisse s'en occuper, a moins que ce ne soit pour en deplorer la perte.

eng: "But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into the neighbourhood."
fr: Mais, mon cher, vous devez vraiment aller voir M. Bingley des qu'il sera dans notre voisinage.

eng: "It is more than I engage for, I assure you."
fr: -- C'est plus que je ne puis promettre.

eng: "But consider your daughters.
fr: -- Songez donc a vos filles !

eng: I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my hearty consent to his marrying which ever he chuses of the girls; though I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy."
fr: -- Vous etes trop scrupuleuse, je crois que M. Bingley seroit charme de vous voir, et je pourrais meme vous charger de quelques lignes pour l'assurer de mon consentement a son mariage avec celle de mes filles qu'il choisira ; quoique cependant je dusse dire un mot en faveur de ma chere petite Lizzy.

eng: "I desire you will do no such thing.
fr: -- Je vous prie de ne point le faire.

eng: Lizzy is not a bit better than the others; and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so good humoured as Lydia. ~~~ But you are always giving _her_ the preference."
fr: Lizzy n'est pas superieure aux autres ; elle n'est a beaucoup pres ni si belle que Jane, ni si gaie que Lydie ; mais vous lui donnez toujours la preference.

eng: "They have none of them much to recommend them," replied he; "they are all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of quickness than her sisters."
fr: -- On ne peut tirer vanite ni des unes ni des autres, repliqua-t-il, elles sont sottes et ignorantes comme toutes les jeunes filles, mais Lizzy a quelque chose de plus anime que ses soeurs.

eng: "Mr. Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way?
fr: -- Je ne sais quelle jouissance vous avez a rabaisser ainsi vos enfans, Monsieur Bennet ?

eng: You take delight in vexing me.
fr: Il semble que vous preniez plaisir a me faire de la peine.

eng: Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour, reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three and twenty years had been insufficient to make his wife understand his character.
fr: M. Bennet offroit un melange si extraordinaire de reparties promptes, d'humeur railleuse, de reserve et de caprices, que vingt-trois ans de mariage n'avoient pas suffi a sa femme pour bien connoitre son caractere.

eng: _Her_ mind was less difficult to develope.
fr: Elle etoit moins difficile a definir.

eng: She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper.
fr: C'etoit une femme ignorante, d'une intelligence mediocre, et d'un caractere foible.

eng: CHAPTER II.
fr: CHAPITRE II.

eng: Mr. Bennet was among the earliest of those who waited on Mr. Bingley.
fr: Monsieur Bennet fut un de ceux qui se montrerent les plus empresses a rechercher M. Bingley.

eng: He had always intended to visit him, though to the last always assuring his wife that he should not go; and till the evening after the visit was paid, she had no knowledge of it. ~~~ It was then disclosed in the following manner.
fr: Son intention avoit toujours ete d'aller chez lui, quoiqu'il eut assure sa femme du contraire, mais elle n'eut connoissance de cette visite qu'apres qu'elle fut faite, et voici comment : M. Bennet voyant sa seconde fille occupee a garnir un chapeau, lui dit : J'espere Lizzy que ce chapeau plaira a M. Bingley.

eng: Observing his second daughter employed in trimming a hat, he suddenly addressed her with, "I hope Mr. Bingley will like it Lizzy."
fr: -- Nous ne saurons point ce qui plait ou deplait a M. Bingley, repondit Mistriss Bennet avec aigreur, puisque nous ne le verrons point.

eng: "We are not in a way to know _what_ Mr. Bingley likes," said her mother resentfully, "since we are not to visit."
fr: -- Vous oubliez, maman, dit Elisabeth, que nous le rencontrerons dans les assemblees, et que Mistriss Long a promis de nous le presenter.

eng: "But you forget, mama," said Elizabeth, "that we shall meet him at the assemblies, and that Mrs. Long has promised to introduce him."
fr: -- Je ne crois pas que Mistriss Long fasse jamais rien pour nous ; c'est une femme fausse, interessee, d'ailleurs elle a deux nieces, et je ne compte point sur elle.

eng: "I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing. ~~~ She has two nieces of her own.
fr: -- Ni moi, dit M. Bennet, je suis bien aise de voir que vous ne fondez pas vos esperances sur ses services.

eng: She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion of her."
fr: Mistriss Bennet ne daigna pas repondre, mais incapable de se contenir, elle commenca a gronder une de ses filles.

eng: "No more have I," said Mr. Bennet; "and I am glad to find that you do not depend on her serving you."
fr: -- Ne toussez donc pas ainsi Kitty, pour l'amour du Ciel, ayez pitie de moi, vous m'abimez, les nerfs.

eng: Mrs. Bennet deigned not to make any reply; but unable to contain herself, began scolding one of her daughters.
fr: -- Kitty n'a aucune discretion, dit son pere, elle ne tousse jamais a propos.

eng: "Don't keep coughing so, Kitty, for heaven's sake!
fr: -- Je ne tousse pas pour me divertir, repondit Kitty avec humeur.

eng: Have a little compassion on my nerves.
fr: -- Quand aura lieu votre premier, bal, Lizzy ?

eng: You tear them to pieces."
fr: -- De demain en quinze.

eng: "Kitty has no discretion in her coughs," said her father; "she times them ill." "I do not cough for my own amusement," replied Kitty fretfully.
"When is your next ball to be, Lizzy?" ~~~ "To-morrow fortnight."
fr: -- Est-il bien vrai, s'ecria Mistriss Bennet !

eng: "Aye, so it is," cried her mother, "and Mrs. Long does not come back till the day before; so, it will be impossible for her to introduce him, for she will not know him herself."
fr: Et Mistriss Long ne reviendra que la veille, il lui sera impossible de nous le presenter puisqu'elle ne l'aura point encore vu.

eng: "Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce Mr. Bingley to _her_."
fr: -- Alors, ma chere, vous aurez l'avantage sur votre amie, en lui presentant vous-meme M. Bingley.

eng: "Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I am not acquainted with him myself; how can you be so teazing?"
fr: -- C'est impossible, M. Bennet, impossible !

eng: "I honour your circumspection.
fr: comment pouvez-vous parler ainsi ?

eng: A fortnight's acquaintance is certainly very little. ~~~ One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a fortnight.
fr: -- J'admire votre circonspection, une relation qui ne date que de quinze jours est certainement tres-peu approfondie ; on ne peut pas bien connoitre un homme au bout de si peu de temps ; mais si vous ne hasardez rien, d'autres le feront.

eng: But if _we_ do not venture, somebody else will; and after all, Mrs. Long and her nieces must stand their chance; and therefore, as she will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I will take it on myself."
fr: Apres tout, Mistriss Long et ses nieces desirant tenter l'aventure, ce sera un acte de generosite de votre part de leur en presenter l'occasion.

eng: The girls stared at their father.
fr: Si vous refusiez de leur rendre ce bon office, je m'en chargerois.

eng: Mrs. Bennet said only, "Nonsense, nonsense!"
fr: Les jeunes filles regardoient leur pere avec etonnement ; Mistriss Bennet se contenta de dire : Quelle absurdite !

eng: "What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation?"
fr: -- Que signifie cette expression emphatique, s'ecria-t-il ?

eng: cried he. ~~~ "Do you consider the forms of introduction, and the stress that is laid on them, as nonsense?
fr: Pensez-vous que la formalite d'une presentation, et l'importance qu'on y attache soient des absurdites ?

eng: for you are a young lady of deep reflection I know, and read great books, and make extracts."
fr: Je sais que vous etes une jeune personne qui a profondement reflechi, qui a lu des livres tres-serieux et fait beaucoup d'extraits.

eng: Mary wished to say something very sensible, but knew not how.
fr: Mary auroit bien desire repondre quelque chose de tres-judicieux, mais elle n'etoit pas preparee, et pendant qu'elle arrangeoit ses phrases, son pere ajouta : Revenons a M. Bingley.

eng: "While Mary is adjusting her ideas," he continued, "let us return to Mr. ~~~ Bingley."
fr: -- Je ne puis souffrir d'entendre parler de M. Bingley, cela me rend malade.

eng: "I am sick of Mr. Bingley," cried his wife.
fr: -- Je suis fache d'apprendre cela.

eng: "I am sorry to hear _that_; but why did not you tell me so before?
fr: Pourquoi ne me l'avez-vous pas dit plutot ?

eng: If I had known as much this morning, I certainly would not have called on him.
fr: Si je l'avois su ce matin, je n'aurois surement pas ete me presenter chez lui.

eng: The astonishment of the ladies was just what he wished; that of Mrs. Bennet perhaps surpassing the rest; though when the first tumult of joy was over, she began to declare that it was what she had expected all the while.
fr: L'etonnement de ces dames fut aussi grand que pouvoit le desirer M. Bennet ; celui de sa femme surtout, quoiqu'elle assurat, une fois le premier elan de sa joie passee, qu'elle s'y attendoit des le premier jour.

eng: "How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet! ~~~ But I knew I should persuade you at last.
fr: -- Combien c'est aimable de votre part, mon cher Monsieur Bennet !

eng: I was sure you loved your girls too well to neglect such an acquaintance. ~~~ Well, how pleased I am!
fr: Je savois bien que je finirois par vous persuader ; j'etois sure que vous aimiez trop vos filles pour negliger de faire une telle connoissance !

eng: and it is such a good joke, too, that you should have gone this morning, and never said a word about it till now."
fr: C'est cependant une singuliere idee ; y etre alle ce matin, et ne nous en avoir rien dit jusqu'a present.

eng: "Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you chuse," said Mr. Bennet; and, as he spoke, he left the room, fatigued with the raptures of his wife.
fr: -- Maintenant Kitty vous pouvez tousser tant qu'il vous plaira. ~~~ En disant ces mots, Monsieur Bennet, fatigue des transports de sa femme, sortit.

eng: "What an excellent father you have, girls," said she, when the door was shut.
fr: -- Quel excellent pere vous avez, mes enfans, dit Mistriss Bennet, des qu'il eut ferme la porte.

eng: "I do not know how you will ever make him amends for his kindness; or me either, for that matter.
fr: Je ne sais comment vous pourrez lui temoigner, ainsi qu'a moi, toute votre reconnaissance !

eng: At our time of life, it is not so pleasant I can tell you, to be making new acquaintance every day; but for your sakes, we would do any thing.
fr: Car je puis vous assurer qu'il n'est pas agreable a notre age de faire chaque jour de nouvelles connoissances ; mais il n'y a rien que nous ne fassions pour vous.

eng: CHAPTER III.
fr: CHAPITRE III.

eng: Not all that Mrs. Bennet, however, with the assistance of her five daughters, could ask on the subject was sufficient to draw from her husband any satisfactory description of Mr. Bingley.
fr: Toutes les questions que Mistriss Bennet, aidee de ses cinq filles, adressa a son mari, ne purent leur faire obtenir une description detaillee de M. Bingley ; on l'attaqua de mille manieres, par d'ingenieuses suppositions, des soupcons imaginaires, des questions indirectes ; il eludoit tout, et trompa l'adresse de chacune.

eng: They attacked him in various ways; with barefaced questions, ingenious suppositions, and distant surmises; but he eluded the skill of them all; and they were at last obliged to accept the second-hand intelligence of their neighbour Lady Lucas.
fr: Elles furent enfin obligees de s'en rapporter aux recits de leur voisine, Lady Lucas ; sir Williams avoit ete enchante de M. Bingley ; il etoit jeune, beau, fort aimable, et pour comble de perfections, il avoit l'intention d'aller a la prochaine assemblee avec plusieurs personnes de sa societe.

eng: Her report was highly favourable.
fr: On ne pouvoit etre plus delicieux !

eng: Sir William had been delighted with him.
fr: Il aimoit passionnement la danse, il deviendroit donc amoureux.

eng: He was quite young, wonderfully handsome, extremely agreeable, and to crown the whole, he meant to be at the next assembly with a large party.
Nothing could be more delightful!
fr: Quel vaste champ d'esperances !

eng: To be fond of dancing was a certain step towards falling in love; and very lively hopes of Mr. Bingley's heart were entertained.
"If I can but see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield," said Mrs. Bennet to her husband, "and all the others equally well married, I shall have nothing to wish for."
fr: -- Si je puis voir une de mes filles heureusement etablie a Metterfield, disoit Mistriss Bennet a son mari, et toutes les autres aussi bien mariees, je n'aurai plus rien a desirer.

eng: Mr. Bingley was good looking and gentleman-like; he had a pleasant countenance, and easy, unaffected manners.
fr: M. Bingley avoit l'air d'un homme comme il faut, ses manieres etoient pleines de grace et de naturel.

Ses soeurs pouvoient passer pour de belles femmes, mais elles avoient le genre affecte et recherche des femmes qu'on nomme a la mode ; son beau frere, M. Hurst paroissoit un bon gentilhomme, mais M. Darcy, son ami, attira bientot l'attention de toute l'assemblee par la beaute de ses traits, l'elegance de sa taille, la noblesse de son maintien, et l'avantage de jouir de dix mille livres de rente ; circonstance qui fut connue et circula tout autour de la salle, en cinq minutes.

eng: His sisters were fine women, with an air of decided fashion.
fr: Les hommes avouerent qu'il etoit bien fait, et les femmes declarerent qu'il etoit beaucoup plus beau que M. Bingley.

eng: His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, merely looked the gentleman; but his friend Mr. Darcy soon drew the attention of the room by his fine, tall person, handsome features, noble mien; and the report which was in general circulation within five minutes after his entrance, of his having ten thousand a year.
fr: On le regarda avec admiration, pendant la moitie de la soiree, jusqu'a ce qu'enfin ses manieres, qui deplaisoient generalement, arreterent le cours de ses succes.

eng: The gentlemen pronounced him to be a fine figure of a man, the ladies declared he was much handsomer than Mr. Bingley, and he was looked at with great admiration for about half the evening, till his manners gave a disgust which turned the tide of his popularity; for he was discovered to be proud, to be above his company, and above being pleased; and not all his large estate in Derbyshire could then save him from having a most forbidding, disagreeable countenance, and being unworthy to be compared with his friend.
fr: On decouvrit qu'il etoit fier, que rien ne lui convenoit, qu'il se croyoit fort au dessus des autres ; alors toute sa grande fortune ne put le sauver ; on prononca qu'il avoit un abord repoussant, un ton desagreable, et qu'il etoit indigne d'etre compare a son ami.

eng: Mr. Bingley had soon made himself acquainted with all the principal people in the room; he was lively and unreserved, danced every dance, was angry that the ball closed so early, and talked of giving one himself at Netherfield.
fr: M. Bingley eut bientot fait connoissance avec les principales personnes qui se trouvoient a l'assemblee ; il etoit gai et prevenant ; il dansa toujours, et fut tres-fache que le bal finit sitot.

eng: Such amiable qualities must speak for themselves.
fr: Il parla meme d'en donner un a Metterfield.
D'aussi aimables qualites previennent toujours en faveur de celui qui les possede.

eng: What a contrast between him and his friend!
fr: Quel contraste avec son ami !

eng: Elizabeth Bennet had been obliged, by the scarcity of gentlemen, to sit down for two dances; and during part of that time, Mr. Darcy had been standing near enough for her to overhear a conversation between him and Mr. Bingley, who came from the dance for a few minutes, to press his friend to join it. ~~~ "Come, Darcy," said he, "I must have you dance.
fr: Elisabeth Bennet avoit ete forcee, par la disette de danseurs, de se reposer ; elle se trouva assez pres de M. Darcy pour entendre sa conversation avec M. Bingley qui venoit de quitter sa place pour se rapprocher de son ami.

eng: I hate to see you standing about by yourself in this stupid manner. ~~~ You had much better dance." ~~~ "I certainly shall not.
fr: -- Venez, Darcy, lui disoit-il, je n'aime pas a vous voir seul, vous ferez beaucoup mieux de danser.

eng: You know how I detest it, unless I am particularly acquainted with my partner.

At such an assembly as this, it would be insupportable. ~~~ Your sisters are engaged, and there is not another woman in the room, whom it would not be a punishment to me to stand up with." ~~~ "I would not be so fastidious as you are," cried Bingley, "for a kingdom!
fr: -- C'est ce que je ne ferai surement pas ; vous savez que je deteste la danse, a moins que je ne connoisse beaucoup mon partner, dans une assemblee comme celle-ci ce seroit au-dessus de mes forces ; vos soeurs sont engagees, et il n'y a pas une personne dans la salle avec laquelle il ne me fut insupportable de danser. ~~~ -- Ma foi !

eng: Upon my honour, I never met with so many pleasant girls in my life, as I have this evening; and there are several of them you see uncommonly pretty."
fr: je ne serois pas si difficile que vous, s'ecria Bingley, je n'ai jamais vu tant de jolies personnes rassemblees, il y en a meme qui sont des beautes remarquables.

eng: "_You_ are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room," said Mr. Darcy, looking at the eldest Miss Bennet. ~~~ "Oh!
fr: -- Vous dansez avec la seule belle personne qu'il y ait dans toute la salle, dit M. Darcy, en regardant l'ainee des Miss Bennet.

eng: she is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld! ~~~ But there is one of her sisters sitting down just behind you, who is very pretty, and I dare say, very agreeable.
fr: -- C'est la plus belle creature que j'aie jamais vue, mais il y a une de ses soeurs (elle est justement assise derriere vous), qui est tres-agreable, je puis meme dire tres-jolie.

eng: Do let me ask my partner to introduce you." ~~~ "Which do you mean?"
fr: Permettez-moi de prier ma danseuse de vous presenter a elle.

eng: and turning round, he looked for a moment at Elizabeth, till catching her eye, he withdrew his own and coldly said, "She is tolerable; but not handsome enough to tempt _me_; and I am in no humour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted by other men.
fr: >> -- Laquelle dites-vous ; puis se tournant, il regarda Elisabeth, jusqu'a ce que rencontrant ses yeux, il detourna les siens, et dit froidement : Elle est passable, mais point assez belle pour me tenter ; d'ailleurs, je ne suis pas d'humeur dans ce moment a consoler les jeunes dames que les autres hommes dedaignent.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: my dear Mr. Bennet," as she entered the room, "we have had a most delightful evening, a most excellent ball.
I wish you had been there.

Jane was so admired, nothing could be like it. ~~~ Every body said how well she looked; and Mr. Bingley thought her quite beautiful, and danced with her twice. ~~~ Only think of _that_ my dear; he actually danced with her twice; and she was the only creature in the room that he asked a second time.
fr: mon cher Monsieur Bennet, dit Mistriss Bennet, en entrant dans la chambre, nous avons eu une soiree delicieuse, un bal charmant, j'aurois voulu que vous y fussiez alle ; Jane a ete plus admiree qu'on ne peut le dire ; chacun s'extasioit sur sa figure et M. Bingley l'a trouvee extremement belle ; il a danse deux fois avec elle !

eng: First of all, he asked Miss Lucas.
fr: pensez a cela mon cher !

eng: I was so vexed to see him stand up with her; but, however, he did not admire her at all: indeed, nobody can, you know; and he seemed quite struck with Jane as she was going down the dance.
So, he enquired who she was, and got introduced, and asked her for the two next.
fr: il a danse deux fois avec elle ; elle est la seule de l'assemblee qu'il ait engagee une seconde fois.

eng: Then, the two third he danced with Miss King, and the two fourth with Maria Lucas, and the two fifth with Jane again, and the two sixth with Lizzy, and the Boulanger----" "If he had had any compassion for _me_," cried her husband impatiently, "he would not have danced half so much!
fr: D'abord, il a engage Miss Lucas ; j'etois un peu fachee de le voir aupres d'elle, cependant il ne l'admiroit point, vous savez qu'elle n'est pas remarquable ; en voyant Jane, il a paru frappe d'etonnement ; il a demande qui elle etoit, s'est fait presenter et l'a engagee pour les deux contredanses suivantes ; ensuite il a danse les deux troisiemes avec Miss King, les deux quatriemes avec Mary Lucas, les deux cinquiemes avec Jane encore, et les deux sixiemes, ainsi que la boulangere, avec Lizzy.

eng: For God's sake, say no more of his partners.
fr: -- S'il avoit eu pitie de moi, s'ecria M. Bennet avec impatience, il n'auroit pas tant danse ; pour l'amour de Dieu ne me parlez plus de ses partners.

eng: Oh! ~~~ that he had sprained his ancle in the first dance!"
fr: Que ne s'est-il foule le pied des le commencement du bal.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: He walked here, and he walked there, fancying himself so very great! ~~~ Not handsome enough to dance with!
fr: Il se promenoit en long et en large, s'imaginant etre fort au-dessus des autres... pas assez belle pour danser avec lui ?

eng: I wish you had been there, my dear, to have given him one of your set downs.
fr: J'aurois voulu que vous fussiez la, mon cher.

eng: I quite detest the man."
CHAPTER IV.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE IV.

eng: "He is just what a young man ought to be," said she, "sensible, good humoured, lively; and I never saw such happy manners!--so much ease, with such perfect good breeding!"
fr: -- Il est precisement ce que doit etre un jeune homme, disoit-elle, bon, gai, aimable, je n'ai jamais vu des manieres plus prevenantes, ni autant d'aisance avec un air si comme il faut.

eng: "He is also handsome," replied Elizabeth, "which a young man ought likewise to be, if he possibly can. ~~~ His character is thereby complete."
fr: -- Ajoutez qu'il est beau, repondit Elisabeth, un jeune homme doit l'etre aussi (s'il le peut) ; pour que son portrait soit parfait.

eng: "I was very much flattered by his asking me to dance a second time. ~~~ I did not expect such a compliment." ~~~ "Did not you?
fr: -- J'ai ete tres-flattee qu'il m'ait engagee a danser une seconde fois ; je ne m'attendois pas a cette distinction de sa part.

eng: _I_ did for you. ~~~ But that is one great difference between us. ~~~ Compliments always take _you_ by surprise, and _me_ never.
fr: -- Vraiment, moi j'y comptois pour vous ; mais il y a une grande difference entre nous ; les complimens qui vous sont adresses ne me surprennent jamais, et vous toujours.

eng: What could be more natural than his asking you again?
fr: Qu'y avoit-il de plus naturel qu'il vous engageat une seconde fois ?

eng: He could not help seeing that you were about five times as pretty as every other woman in the room. ~~~ No thanks to his gallantry for that.
fr: Il ne pouvoit s'empecher de voir que vous etiez deux fois plus jolie que toutes les autres femmes du bal, ainsi vous ne lui devez pas de reconnoissance.

eng: Well, he certainly is very agreeable, and I give you leave to like him. ~~~ You have liked many a stupider person." ~~~ "Dear Lizzy!" ~~~ "Oh!
fr: Il est certainement tres-aimable, et je vous permets bien d'en etre enchantee, vous avez aime des gens bien moins agreables que lui.

eng: And so, you like this man's sisters too, do you?
fr: Et vous aimez aussi les soeurs de cet homme, n'est-ce pas ?

eng: Their manners are not equal to his." ~~~ "Certainly not; at first.
fr: Cependant leurs manieres ne sont pas si prevenantes que les siennes ?

eng: But they are very pleasing women when you converse with them.
fr: -- Non pas au premier abord ; mais lorsqu'on leur parle, on voit que ce sont des femmes aimables.

eng: Miss Bingley is to live with her brother and keep his house; and I am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming neighbour in her."
fr: Miss Bingley doit demeurer chez son frere et tenir sa maison.

eng: Elizabeth listened in silence, but was not convinced; their behaviour at the assembly had not been calculated to please in general; and with more quickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than her sister, and with a judgment too unassailed by any attention to herself, she was very little disposed to approve them.
They were in fact very fine ladies; not deficient in good humour when they were pleased, nor in the power of being agreeable where they chose it; but proud and conceited.
fr: Je me serois bien trompee si nous ne trouvons pas en elle une charmante voisine. ~~~ Elisabeth ecoutoit en silence, mais n'etoit pas persuadee.

eng: They were rather handsome, had been educated in one of the first private seminaries in town, had a fortune of twenty thousand pounds, were in the habit of spending more than they ought, and of associating with people of rank; and were therefore in every respect entitled to think well of themselves, and meanly of others.
fr: Avec un esprit plus observateur et moins de douceur que Jane, et n'ayant pas ete distraite par ce qui la concernoit elle-meme, elle etoit peu disposee a approuver les manieres des soeurs de M. Bingley au bal.

eng: They were of a respectable family in the north of England; a circumstance more deeply impressed on their memories than that their brother's fortune and their own had been acquired by trade.
fr: C'etoient de belles dames, d'une humeur assez douce avec ceux qui leur plaisoient, aimables lorsqu'elles le vouloient, d'une figure agreable, elles avoient ete elevees dans une des premieres pensions de Londres, ensorte qu'habituees a frayer avec des gens de qualite, et a depenser plus que ne leur permettoit une fortune de vingt mille livres, elles s'arrogeoient le droit de se croire superieures aux autres.

eng: Mr. Bingley inherited property to the amount of nearly an hundred thousand pounds from his father, who had intended to purchase an estate, but did not live to do it.--Mr.
fr: Elles etoient d'une bonne famille du nord de l'Angleterre, circonstance plus profondement gravee dans leur memoire que celle de l'origine de leur fortune, que leur pere avoit acquise dans le commerce.

eng: Bingley intended it likewise, and sometimes made choice of his county; but as he was now provided with a good house and the liberty of a manor, it was doubtful to many of those who best knew the easiness of his temper, whether he might not spend the remainder of his days at Netherfield, and leave the next generation to purchase.
fr: Monsieur Bingley avoit herite de son pere environ cent mille livres ; ce dernier avoit eu l'intention d'acheter une terre ; la mort l'avoit surpris avant l'execution de ce projet ; son fils avoit aussi le meme dessein, mais depuis qu'il avoit loue une charmante habitation, ceux qui connoissoient le laisser aller de son caractere pensoient qu'il pourroit bien y passer le reste de ses jours et laisser a la generation suivante le soin d'acheter.

eng: Between him and Darcy there was a very steady friendship, in spite of a great opposition of character.--Bingley was endeared to Darcy by the easiness, openness, ductility of his temper, though no disposition could offer a greater contrast to his own, and though with his own he never appeared dissatisfied.
fr: En depit de contraste frappant que presentoient les caracteres de Bingley et de Darcy, une veritable amitie regnoit entre eux, Bingley se confioit entierement a l'attachement de son ami et avoit la plus haute opinion de son jugement, il lui etoit cher par sa franchise et sa douceur.

eng: On the strength of Darcy's regard Bingley had the firmest reliance, and of his judgment the highest opinion. ~~~ In understanding Darcy was the superior.
fr: Darcy etoit superieur pour l'esprit, quoique Bingley n'en fut pas depourvu, il avoit plus de finesse, et etoit en meme temps fier, reserve, et dedaigneux ; ses manieres quoique polies n'etoient point attrayantes ; sous ce rapport son ami avoit tout l'avantage.

eng: Bingley was by no means deficient, but Darcy was clever.
fr: Bingley etoit sur d'etre aime partout ou il paraissoit, Darcy au contraire deplaisoit presque generalement.

eng: He was at the same time haughty, reserved, and fastidious, and his manners, though well bred, were not inviting.
fr: La maniere dont ils parloient du bal de Meryton, auroit suffi pour montrer la difference de leurs caracteres.

eng: In that respect his friend had greatly the advantage. ~~~ Bingley was sure of being liked wherever he appeared, Darcy was continually giving offence.
fr: Bingley n'avoit jamais rencontre des gens plus aimables, et de plus jolies personnes ; chacun avoit ete plein de prevenance, et de politesse pour lui ; il n'y avoit ni gene ni ceremonie et il s'etoit bientot senti a son aise avec tous les gens qui composoient l'assemblee.

eng: The manner in which they spoke of the Meryton assembly was sufficiently characteristic.
fr: Quant a Miss Bennet, il ne pouvoit rien se figurer de plus beau.

eng: Bingley had never met with pleasanter people or prettier girls in his life; every body had been most kind and attentive to him, there had been no formality, no stiffness, he had soon felt acquainted with all the room; and as to Miss Bennet, he could not conceive an angel more beautiful.
fr: Darcy au contraire, n'avoit vu la qu'un rassemblement fort insipide, dans lequel il y avoit peu de jolies personnes ; point qui eussent l'air vraiment comme il faut ; aucune ne lui avoit inspire le plus leger interet, aucune ne lui avoit donne la plus legere marque d'attention.

eng: Darcy, on the contrary, had seen a collection of people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion, for none of whom he had felt the smallest interest, and from none received either attention or pleasure.
Miss Bennet he acknowledged to be pretty, but she smiled too much.
fr: Il avouoit cependant que Miss Bennet etoit jolie, mais il trouvoit qu'elle sourioit trop.

eng: For though elated by his rank, it did not render him supercilious; on the contrary, he was all attention to every body. ~~~ By nature inoffensive, friendly and obliging, his presentation at St. James's had made him courteous.
fr: La il pouvoit se penetrer du degre d'importance qu'il avoit acquis et n'etant plus absorbe par les affaires, sa principale occupation etoit de se montrer extremement poli avec tout le monde, car quoique tres-fier de son nouveau rang, il n'etoit point devenu dedaigneux ; au contraire, naturellement amical et obligeant, sa presentation a S.t James l'avoit rendu encore plus affable.

eng: Lady Lucas was a very good kind of woman, not too clever to be a valuable neighbour to Mrs.
fr: Lady Lucas etoit une excellente femme, dont l'esprit n'avoit rien d'assez superieur pour l'empecher d'etre une voisine tres-precieuse a Miss Bennet.

eng: Bennet.--They had several children.
fr: Elle avoit plusieurs enfans ; l'ainee agee de vingt-sept ans, bonne et pleine de raison, etoit extremement liee avec Elisabeth.

eng: The eldest of them, a sensible, intelligent young woman, about twenty-seven, was Elizabeth's intimate friend.
fr: Il etoit indispensable que les miss Lucas et les miss Bennet se rencontrassent pour parler du bal, aussi le lendemain matin vit-on arriver les premieres a Longbourn.

eng: That the Miss Lucases and the Miss Bennets should meet to talk over a ball was absolutely necessary; and the morning after the assembly brought the former to Longbourn to hear and to communicate.
fr: Elles venoient raconter a leurs amies ce qu'elles avoient vu et entendu, et apprendre en echange ce qui auroit pu leur echapper.

eng: "_You_ began the evening well, Charlotte," said Mrs. Bennet with civil self-command to Miss Lucas.
fr: -- La soiree commenca bien pour vous, Charlotte, dit Mistriss Bennet a Miss Lucas, avec une politesse forcee, vous futes le premier objet de l'attention de M. Bingley.

eng: "_You_ were Mr. Bingley's first choice."
fr: -- Oui, mais il a paru cependant donner la preference au second.

eng: "Yes;--but he seemed to like his second better." ~~~ "Oh!--you mean Jane, I suppose--because he danced with her twice.
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ vous parlez de Jane sans doute, parce qu'il a danse deux fois avec elle ; en effet, il avoit l'air de l'admirer, et je crois bien que c'etoit vrai !

eng: To be sure that _did_ seem as if he admired her--indeed I rather believe he _did_--I heard something about it--but I hardly know what--something about Mr.
fr: J'ai oui dire quelque chose la-dessus, je ne me souviens pas fort bien de ce que c'etoit, quelque chose de M. Robinson je crois ?

eng: Robinson." ~~~ "Perhaps you mean what I overheard between him and Mr. Robinson; did not I mention it to you?
fr: -- Peut-etre Madame voulez-vous parler de la conversation que j'ai entendue entre M. Robinson et lui.

eng: Mr. Robinson's asking him how he liked our Meryton assemblies, and whether he did not think there were a great many pretty women in the room, and _which_ he thought the prettiest?
fr: Ne vous l'ai-je pas racontee ? ~~~ M. Robinson lui demandoit comment il trouvoit nos assemblees de Meryton, s'il ne pensoit pas qu'il y avoit beaucoup de jolies femmes dans la salle et laquelle il trouvoit la plus belle.

eng: and his answering immediately to the last question--Oh!
fr: Il repondit vivement a cette derniere question : Oh !

eng: the eldest Miss Bennet beyond a doubt, there cannot be two opinions on that point."
fr: l'ainee des Miss Bennet, sans aucun doute ! ~~~ Il ne peut y avoir deux opinions la-dessus.

eng: "Upon my word!--Well, that was very decided indeed--that does seem as if----but however, it may all come to nothing you know."
fr: -- En verite ! ~~~ he bien, c'etoit positif cela.

eng: "_My_ overhearings were more to the purpose than _yours_, Eliza," said Charlotte.
fr: Il semble alors que... cependant, cela pourroit peut-etre encore ne mener a rien.

eng: "Mr. Darcy is not so well worth listening to as his friend, is he?--Poor Eliza!--to be only just _tolerable_."
fr: -- J'ai ete plus heureuse que vous, Lizzy, dit Charlotte en souriant, M. Darcy n'est pas si aimable que son ami, n'est-ce pas ? ~~~ Pauvre Lizzy !

eng: "I beg you would not put it into Lizzy's head to be vexed by his ill-treatment; for he is such a disagreeable man that it would be quite a misfortune to be liked by him.
fr: etre passable seulement. ~~~ -- Je vous prie de ne point mettre dans la tete a Lizzy d'etre piquee de ce mauvais compliment, car c'est un homme si desagreable, qu'on seroit vraiment fachee d'etre distinguee par lui.

eng: "Aye--because she asked him at last how he liked Netherfield, and he could not help answering her;--but she said he seemed very angry at being spoke to."
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ oui, parce qu'elle lui demanda si Metherfield lui plaisoit, il ne put faire autrement que de lui repondre ; car elle dit qu'il avoit l'air tres-fache qu'on eut ose lui adresser la parole.

eng: "Miss Bingley told me," said Jane, "that he never speaks much unless among his intimate acquaintance.
fr: -- Miss Bingley m'a assure qu'il ne parle jamais qu'a ses plus intimes connoissances, et qu'alors il est extremement aimable, dit Jane.

eng: With _them_ he is remarkably agreeable." ~~~ "I do not believe a word of it, my dear.
fr: -- Je n'en crois pas un mot, ma chere, s'il avoit ete si aimable, il auroit certainement parle a Mistriss Long.

eng: If he had been so very agreeable he would have talked to Mrs. Long.
fr: Mais je devine pourquoi il ne l'a pas fait.

eng: But I can guess how it was; every body says that he is ate up with pride, and I dare say he had heard somehow that Mrs. Long does not keep a carriage, and had come to the ball in a hack chaise."
fr: On dit qu'il est devore d'orgueil, et je suis sure qu'il aura su que Mistriss Long n'avoit point d'equipage, et qu'elle etoit venue au bal dans une voiture de louage.

eng: "Another time, Lizzy," said her mother, "I would not dance with _him_, if I were you."
fr: -- Une autre fois, Lizzy, dit Mistriss Bennet, si j'etois vous, je ne voudrois pas danser avec lui.

eng: "I believe, Ma'am, I may safely promise you _never_ to dance with him."
"His pride," said Miss Lucas, "does not offend _me_ so much as pride often does, because there is an excuse for it.
fr: -- L'orgueil chez lui, dit Miss Lucas, ne me paroit pas si offensant qu'il l'est quelquefois chez d'autres, il a une excuse.

eng: CHAPTER VI.
fr: CHAPITRE VI.

eng: The ladies of Longbourn soon waited on those of Netherfield.
fr: Les dames de Longbourn se presenterent chez celles de Metherfield, qui ne tarderent pas a rendre la visite dans toutes les formes.

eng: The visit was returned in due form.
fr: Les manieres attrayantes des Miss Bennet charmerent de plus en plus Mist.

eng: Miss Bennet's pleasing manners grew on the good will of Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley; and though the mother was found to be intolerable and the younger sisters not worth speaking to, a wish of being better acquainted with _them_, was expressed towards the two eldest.
fr: Hurst et Miss Bingley, et quoiqu'on trouvat que la mere etoit intolerable, et qu'on ne pouvoit faire la conversation avec les soeurs cadettes, on exprima cependant le desir de faire plus ample connoissance avec les deux ainees.

eng: By Jane this attention was received with the greatest pleasure; but Elizabeth still saw superciliousness in their treatment of every body, hardly excepting even her sister, and could not like them; though their kindness to Jane, such as it was, had a value as arising in all probability from the influence of their brother's admiration.
fr: Elisabeth, qui leur trouvoit toujours beaucoup de hauteur, ne pouvoit les gouter.

eng: It was generally evident whenever they met, that he _did_ admire her; and to _her_ it was equally evident that Jane was yielding to the preference which she had begun to entertain for him from the first, and was in a way to be very much in love; but she considered with pleasure that it was not likely to be discovered by the world in general, since Jane united with great strength of feeling, a composure of temper and a uniform cheerfulness of manner, which would guard her from the suspicions of the impertinent. ~~~ She mentioned this to her friend Miss Lucas.
fr: La preference qu'elles accordoient a Jane, venoit du sentiment qu'elle avoit inspire a leur frere ; ce sentiment etoit evident pour tout le monde, et il etoit evident aussi pour Elisabeth que Jane cedoit a l'attrait qu'elle avoit senti pour lui au premier abord ; qu'elle etoit par consequent au commencement d'une inclination ; mais Elisabeth esperoit que l'on ne s'en doutoit pas, parce que Jane avoit une grande force d'ame, un caractere egal et une constante serenite qui la garantiroit des soupcons des medisans ; elle en parla a son amie Miss Lucas.

eng: "But if a woman is partial to a man, and does not endeavour to conceal it, he must find it out."
fr: -- Cependant si une femme qui a de l'amour pour un homme ne fait pas tous ses efforts pour le lui cacher, il doit bien enfin s'en apercevoir.

eng: "Perhaps he must, if he sees enough of her.
fr: -- Peut-etre s'en apercevra-t-il s'il la voit assez souvent pour pouvoir l'etudier.

eng: But though Bingley and Jane meet tolerably often, it is never for many hours together; and as they always see each other in large mixed parties, it is impossible that every moment should be employed in conversing together.
fr: Mais quoique Jane et M. Bingley se rencontrent frequemment, ce n'est jamais long-temps de suite, et comme c'est en societe, ils ne peuvent pas s'entretenir toujours ensemble.

eng: "Your plan is a good one," replied Elizabeth, "where nothing is in question but the desire of being well married; and if I were determined to get a rich husband, or any husband, I dare say I should adopt it.
fr: -- Votre plan seroit bon, s'ecria Elisabeth, s'il ne s'agissoit que d'avoir envie de se marier, et je vous assure que je l'adopterois si je ne voulois qu'epouser un homme riche, ou enfin avoir un mari quelconque.

eng: But these are not Jane's feelings; she is not acting by design.
fr: Mais ces idees la n'occupent point Jane.

eng: As yet, she cannot even be certain of the degree of her own regard, nor of its reasonableness. ~~~ She has known him only a fortnight.
fr: Elle n'a aucun dessein, elle n'est pas meme certaine du degre de preference qu'elle lui accorde, et s'il est fonde.

eng: She danced four dances with him at Meryton; she saw him one morning at his own house, and has since dined in company with him four times. ~~~ This is not quite enough to make her understand his character."
fr: Elle ne le connoit que depuis quinze jours ; elle a danse a Meryton avec lui ; elle l'a vu en visite a Metherfield, et a dine trois ou quatre fois avec lui ; ce n'est reellement pas assez pour qu'elle puisse connoitre et juger son caractere.

eng: "Not as you represent it. ~~~ Had she merely _dined_ with him, she might only have discovered whether he had a good appetite; but you must remember that four evenings have been also spent together--and four evenings may do a great deal."
fr: -- Non pas comme vous presentez la chose, si elle n'avoit fait que diner avec lui, elle auroit pu seulement decouvrir s'il avoit un bon appetit, mais vous oubliez qu'ils ont aussi passe trois ou quatre soirees ensemble, et cela fait beaucoup.

eng: If the dispositions of the parties are ever so well known to each other, or ever so similar before-hand, it does not advance their felicity in the least.
fr: Que les deux parties connaissent parfaitement leurs defauts reciproques, et que meme d'avance elles soient parfaitement d'accord, cela n'assure pas le moins du monde leur felicite.

eng: They always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to have their share of vexation; and it is better to know as little as possible of the defects of the person with whom you are to pass your life."
fr: Les defauts, qui ne sont souvent que de legeres differences, vont toujours en augmentant, et deviennent par la suite si opposes qu'ils peuvent occasionner mille desagremens aux deux epoux.

eng: "You make me laugh, Charlotte; but it is not sound. ~~~ You know it is not sound, and that you would never act in this way yourself."
fr: Le mieux seroit encore de connoitre aussi peu que possible les defauts de la personne avec laquelle on doit passer sa vie.

eng: Occupied in observing Mr. Bingley's attentions to her sister, Elizabeth was far from suspecting that she was herself becoming an object of some interest in the eyes of his friend.
fr: -- Vous me faites rire, Charlotte, mais vous ne me persuadez point, vous ne voudriez pas vous-meme agir ainsi.

eng: Mr. Darcy had at first scarcely allowed her to be pretty; he had looked at her without admiration at the ball; and when they next met, he looked at her only to criticise.
fr: >> Toute occupee a observer les soins de M. Bingley pour sa soeur, Elisabeth etoit loin de soupconner qu'elle fut elle-meme devenue un objet d'interet pour son ami.

eng: But no sooner had he made it clear to himself and his friends that she had hardly a good feature in her face, than he began to find it was rendered uncommonly intelligent by the beautiful expression of her dark eyes. ~~~ To this discovery succeeded some others equally mortifying.
fr: M. Darcy avoit d'abord eu de la peine a convenir qu'elle fut jolie ; il l'avoit consideree avec indifference au bal ; depuis lors, il ne l'avoit regardee que pour la critiquer, mais il n'eut pas plutot prouve a ses amis qu'il n'y avoit pas un trait de sa physionomie de remarquable, qu'il commenca a trouver que la belle expression de ses yeux noirs lui donnoit l'air fort spirituelle ; a cette decouverte en succederent plusieurs autres egalement mortifiantes.

eng: "You are severe on us."
fr: -- Vous etes severe pour nous.

eng: "It will be _her_ turn soon to be teazed," said Miss Lucas.
fr: Ce sera bientot son tour d'etre attaquee, pensa Miss Lucas.

eng: "I am going to open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows."
fr: -- Je vais ouvrir le piano, Elisa, et vous savez ce qui en arrivera.

eng: "You are a very strange creature by way of a friend!--always wanting me to play and sing before any body and every body!--If my vanity had taken a musical turn, you would have been invaluable, but as it is, I would really rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of hearing the very best performers."
fr: -- Vous etes une singuliere creature, sous l'apparence d'une amie ! ~~~ toujours me faire jouer et chanter devant tout le monde !

eng: On Miss Lucas's persevering, however, she added, "Very well; if it must be so, it must."
fr: si ma vanite s'etoit tournee du cote de la musique, vous auriez ete inappreciable !

eng: And gravely glancing at Mr. Darcy, "There is a fine old saying, which every body here is of course familiar with--'Keep your breath to cool your porridge,'--and I shall keep mine to swell my song."
fr: mais j'aimerois mieux ne pas en faire devant des gens qui sont accoutumes a entendre les artistes les plus distingues.

eng: Her performance was pleasing, though by no means capital.
fr: Cependant Miss Lucas persistant, elle ajouta : Allons, puisque vous le voulez, il le faut.

eng: After a song or two, and before she could reply to the entreaties of several that she would sing again, she was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by her sister Mary, who having, in consequence of being the only plain one in the family, worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments, was always impatient for display.
fr: Son execution etoit agreable quoique peu brillante ; apres un ou deux morceaux de chant, et avant qu'elle eut eu le temps de repondre aux sollicitations des personnes qui desiroient l'entendre encore, elle fut remplacee au piano avec empressement par sa soeur Mary, qui ayant le plus travaille pour acquerir des talens et de l'instruction, etoit toujours impatiente de les montrer.

eng: Mary had neither genius nor taste; and though vanity had given her application, it had given her likewise a pedantic air and conceited manner, which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than she had reached.
fr: Mary n'avoit ni dispositions, ni genie, et la vanite qui lui avoit donne beaucoup d'application, lui avoit donne aussi un air pedant et satisfait qui auroit nui a de plus grands talens que les siens.

eng: Mr. Darcy stood near them in silent indignation at such a mode of passing the evening, to the exclusion of all conversation, and was too much engrossed by his own thoughts to perceive that Sir William Lucas was his neighbour, till Sir William thus began.
fr: M. Darcy etoit dans une muette indignation de cette maniere de passer la soiree qui excluoit toute espece de conversation. ~~~ Il etoit trop occupe par ses reflexions pour faire attention a sir Williams Lucas qui etoit pres de lui ; jusqu'a ce qu'enfin ce dernier lui adressa la parole.

eng: "What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr.
fr: -- Quel charmant amusement pour les jeunes gens, Monsieur Darcy !

eng: Darcy!--There is nothing like dancing after all.--I consider it as one of the first refinements of polished societies."
fr: Apres tout, il n'y a rien comme la danse ; je la considere comme un des premiers degres de la civilisation dans les societes policees.

eng: Sir William only smiled.
fr: Sir Williams sourit legerement.

eng: "Your friend performs delightfully;" he continued after a pause, on seeing Bingley join the group;--"and I doubt not that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr.
fr: -- Vos amis dansent a ravir. ~~~ Apres une courte pause, voyant Bingley se joindre au groupe des danseurs : je ne doute pas, M. Darcy, que vous ne soyez vous-meme adepte dans cet art ?

eng: Darcy." ~~~ "You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, Sir."
fr: -- Vous m'avez vu danser a Meryton, je crois, Monsieur.

eng: "Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight.
fr: -- Oui, en verite, et ce spectacle m'a procure un plaisir infini !

eng: Do you often dance at St. ~~~ James's?"
fr: Vous dansiez souvent a St.-James surement ?

eng: "Never, sir."
fr: -- Jamais, Monsieur.

eng: "It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it."
fr: -- C'est un honneur que je ne fais nulle part, lorsque je puis m'en dispenser.

eng: "You have a house in town, I conclude?"
fr: -- Vous avez une maison a Londres, je suppose ?

eng: Mr. Darcy bowed.
fr: M. Darcy s'inclina.

eng: "I had once some thoughts of fixing in town myself--for I am fond of superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of London would agree with Lady Lucas."
fr: -- J'avois eu une fois l'idee de m'etablir a Londres ; j'aime passionement la bonne societe, mais je n'etois pas sur que cet air-la convint a la sante de Lady Lucas.

eng: He paused in hopes of an answer; but his companion was not disposed to make any; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards them, he was struck with the notion of doing a very gallant thing, and called out to her, "My dear Miss Eliza, why are not you dancing?--Mr.
fr: Il s'arreta pour attendre une reponse, mais son interlocuteur n'etois pas dispose a lui en faire une. ~~~ Dans ce moment, Elisabeth passoit pres d'eux.

eng: Darcy, you must allow me to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner.--You cannot refuse to dance, I am sure, when so much beauty is before you."
fr: Sir Williams, enchante de l'idee de faire une chose qu'il croyoit tres-polie, l'arreta, et lui dit : ma chere Miss Elisa, pourquoi ne dansez-vous pas ?

eng: And taking her hand, he would have given it to Mr. Darcy, who, though extremely surprised, was not unwilling to receive it, when she instantly drew back, and said with some discomposure to Sir William, "Indeed, Sir, I have not the least intention of dancing.--I entreat you not to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner."
fr: M. Darcy, vous me permettrez de vous presenter cette jeune dame, comme un partner fort agreable ; vous ne pouvez me refuser de danser, quand la beaute est devant vous ; et prenant la main d'Elisabeth, il vouloit la donner a Darcy, qui quoiqu'extremement surpris, ne la recevoit pas sans plaisir, lorsqu'elle la retira brusquement et dit a sir Williams : En verite, Monsieur, je n'ai pas le moindre desir de danser, et je ne venois point vous demander un partner.

eng: Mr. Darcy with grave propriety requested to be allowed the honour of her hand; but in vain.
fr: M. Darcy lui demanda alors d'un air fort serieux de lui faire l'honneur de danser avec lui, mais ce fut en vain ; Elisabeth etoit decidee, et Sir Williams, malgre tous ses efforts, ne put parvenir a ebranler sa resolution.

eng: Elizabeth was determined; nor did Sir William at all shake her purpose by his attempt at persuasion.
fr: -- Vous dansez si bien, miss Elisa ! ~~~ il est cruel de me refuser le plaisir de vous voir !

eng: "You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny me the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the amusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us for one half hour."
fr: Quoique M. Darcy n'aime pas cet exercice, il ne feroit aucune difficulte de nous obliger pendant une demi heure.

eng: Her resistance had not injured her with the gentleman, and he was thinking of her with some complacency, when thus accosted by Miss Bingley, "I can guess the subject of your reverie."
fr: Sa resistance ne lui avoit point fait de tort dans l'esprit de M. Darcy, il pensoit a elle avec complaisance, lorsqu'il fut aborde par Miss Bingley. ~~~ -- Je parie que j'ai devine le sujet de votre reverie ?

eng: "I should imagine not."
fr: -- Je ne le crois pas.

eng: "You are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings in this manner--in such society; and indeed I am quite of your opinion.
fr: -- Vous pensez combien il seroit insupportable de passer plusieurs soirees de cette maniere, et dans une pareille societe.

eng: Miss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face, and desired he would tell her what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections.
fr: Miss Bingley fixa les siens sur lui et le pria de vouloir bien lui dire qu'elle etoit la dame qui avoit le bonheur de lui inspirer de telles reflexions.

eng: Mr. Darcy replied with great intrepidity, "Miss Elizabeth Bennet."
fr: -- Miss Elisabeth Bennet.

eng: "Miss Elizabeth Bennet!"
fr: -- Miss Elisabeth Bennet !

eng: repeated Miss Bingley.
fr: s'ecria Miss Bingley, je suis stupefaite.

eng: "I am all astonishment.
fr: Y a-t-il long-temps qu'elle est votre favorite ?

eng: How long has she been such a favourite?--and pray when am I to wish you joy?"
fr: Quand pourrai-je vous faire mon compliment, je vous prie ?

eng: "That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask.
fr: -- C'est absolument la question que je pensois que vous me feriez.

eng: "Nay, if you are so serious about it, I shall consider the matter as absolutely settled.
fr: -- Mais vraiment si vous parliez serieusement je regarderois la chose comme arrangee.

eng: You will have a charming mother-in-law, indeed, and of course she will be always at Pemberley with you."
fr: Vous aurez une charmante belle-mere ! ~~~ Je pense qu'elle demeurera toujours a Pimberley avec vous ?

eng: He listened to her with perfect indifference, while she chose to entertain herself in this manner, and as his composure convinced her that all was safe, her wit flowed long.
fr: Il l'ecoutoit avec une parfaite indifference, pendant qu'elle s'amusoit a parler ainsi : tranquilisee par son air calme qui lui persuadoit qu'il n'y avoit rien de reel dans cette plaisanterie, elle continua a deployer son esprit sur ce sujet.

eng: Mr. Bennet's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother's fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply the deficiency of his.
fr: La fortune de M. Bennet consistoit presqu'entierement en une propriete de deux mille livres de rentes, qui malheureusement pour ses filles, etoit a defaut d'enfans males, substituee a un parent fort eloigne.

eng: Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and had left her four thousand pounds.
fr: La fortune de leur mere, quoiqu'assez considerable pour leur position actuelle, ne pouvoit pas suppleer a celle de leur pere.

eng: She had a sister married to a Mr. Philips, who had been a clerk to their father, and succeeded him in the business, and a brother settled in London in a respectable line of trade.
fr: Mistriss Bennet avoit herite de son pere, qui etoit avocat a Merytion, quatre mille livres ; elle avoit une soeur mariee a M. Phillips, autrefois clerc de leur pere, qui lui avoit succede ; et un frere etabli a Londres qui faisoit un commerce honorable.

eng: At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the head quarters.
fr: L'arrivee d'un regiment de milice, qui devoit passer l'hiver dans le voisinage, et dont le quartier general etoit a Meryton, leur causa une grande joie. ~~~ Les visites a Mrs.

eng: Their visits to Mrs. Philips were now productive of the most interesting intelligence.
fr: Phillips devenoient maintenant du plus grand interet, chaque jour ajoutoit quelque chose a ce qu'elles savoient deja du nom et de l'histoire de chaque officier.

eng: Every day added something to their knowledge of the officers' names and connections.
fr: Elles n'ignorerent pas long-temps leurs logemens, et enfin elles eurent le bonheur de faire connoissance avec les officiers eux-memes, Mr.

eng: Their lodgings were not long a secret, and at length they began to know the officers themselves.
fr: Phillips leur fit visite a tous, et ouvrit ainsi a ses nieces une source de felicites, auparavant inconnue.

eng: Mr. Philips visited them all, and this opened to his nieces a source of felicity unknown before.
fr: Elles ne s'entretenoient plus que des officiers ; et la grande fortune de Mr.

eng: They could talk of nothing but officers; and Mr. Bingley's large fortune, the mention of which gave animation to their mother, was worthless in their eyes when opposed to the regimentals of an ensign.
fr: Bingley, dont la seule idee suffisoit pour animer leur mere, disparoissoit a leurs yeux devant l'uniforme d'un simple enseigne. ~~~ Un matin apres avoir ete temoin de leurs transports sur ce sujet-la, Mr.

eng: "If my children are silly I must hope to be always sensible of it."
fr: -- Si mes enfans sont ridicules, j'espere que je m'en apercevrai toujours.

eng: "Yes--but as it happens, they are all of them very clever."
fr: -- Mais s'ils ne le sont pas ? ~~~ Si au contraire ils sont remplis d'esprit ?

eng: "This is the only point, I flatter myself, on which we do not agree.
fr: -- C'est le seul point sur lequel nous ne soyons pas d'accord.

eng: I remember the time when I liked a red coat myself very well--and indeed so I do still at my heart; and if a smart young colonel, with five or six thousand a year, should want one of my girls, I shall not say nay to him; and I thought Colonel Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William's in his regimentals."
fr: Je me souviens tres-bien moi-meme, du temps ou j'aimois beaucoup les habits rouges[1] ; et en verite, dans le fond de mon coeur, je les aime encore. ~~~ Si un jeune et brillant colonel de vingt-six ans, avec mille livres de rente, me demandoit une de mes filles, je ne la lui refuserois point. ~~~ Je trouvois que le colonel Forster, avoit tres bonne facon dans son uniforme, l'autre jour chez Sir Williams.

eng: "Mama," cried Lydia, "my aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain Carter do not go so often to Miss Watson's as they did when they first came; she sees them now very often standing in Clarke's library."
fr: -- Maman, s'ecria Lydie, ma tante dit que maintenant le colonel Forster et le capitaine Carter, ne vont plus si souvent chez Mistriss Watson ; elle les voit beaucoup dans le cabinet de lecture de Clarke.

eng: Mrs. Bennet was prevented replying by the entrance of the footman with a note for Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and the servant waited for an answer.
fr: L'arrivee d'un laquais empecha Mistriss Bennet de repondre, il apportoit un billet pour Miss Bennet, et venoit de Netherfield ; il demandoit une reponse.

eng: Mrs. Bennet's eyes sparkled with pleasure, and she was eagerly calling out, while her daughter read, "Well, Jane, who is it from? ~~~ what is it about?
fr: Les yeux de Mistriss Bennet brilloient de plaisir, et ne laissant pas le temps a sa fille de lire, elle lui demandoit : -- Eh bien, Jane, de qui est-ce ?

eng: what does he say?
fr: Que dit-il ?

eng: Well, Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love."
fr: Allons Jane, depechez-vous et dites-nous ?... ~~~ depechez-vous donc mon ange !

eng: "It is from Miss Bingley," said Jane, and then read it aloud.
fr: -- C'est de Miss Bingley, et elle lut a haute voix, ce qui suit : Ma chere amie.

eng: "My dear Friend, "If you are not so compassionate as to dine to-day with Louisa and me, we shall be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives, for a whole day's t?te-?-t?te between two women can never end without a quarrel.
fr: << Si vous n'etes pas assez complaisante pour venir diner aujourd'hui avec nous, nous courons le risque, Louisa et moi, de nous hair le reste de notre vie ; car un jour entier passe en tete a tete entre deux femmes, ne peut pas finir sans une querelle.

eng: Come as soon as you can on the receipt of this. ~~~ My brother and the gentlemen are to dine with the officers.
fr: Venez donc aussitot que vous aurez lu ce billet ; mon frere et nos Messieurs sont alles diner avec les officiers.

eng: Yours ever, "CAROLINE BINGLEY."
fr: >> Votre affectionnee, Caroline Bingley.

eng: "With the officers!"
fr: -- Avec les officiers !

eng: cried Lydia. ~~~ "I wonder my aunt did not tell us of _that_."
fr: s'ecria Lydie, je suis surprise que ma tante ne nous l'ait pas dit.

eng: "Dining out," said Mrs. Bennet, "that is very unlucky."
fr: -- Il dine dehors, dit Mistriss Bennet, c'est tres-facheux.

eng: "Can I have the carriage?"
fr: -- Puis-je avoir la voiture ?

eng: said Jane.
fr: dit Jane.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: but the gentlemen will have Mr. Bingley's chaise to go to Meryton; and the Hursts have no horses to theirs."
fr: ces Messieurs ont surement pris la voiture de Mr.

eng: "I had much rather go in the coach." ~~~ "But, my dear, your father cannot spare the horses, I am sure.
fr: Bingley, pour aller diner a Meryton, et les Hurst n'ont point de chevaux.

eng: They are wanted in the farm, Mr. Bennet, are not they?"
fr: -- Mais je prefererois aller en voiture.

eng: "They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them."
fr: -- Je suis sure ma chere, que votre pere ne peut pas vous donner les chevaux, ils sont employes a la ferme, n'est ce pas, Mr.

eng: "But if you have got them to-day," said Elizabeth, "my mother's purpose will be answered."
fr: Bennet ? ~~~ -- Je les donne bien souvent, lors-meme qu'ils sont employes a la ferme.

eng: She did at last extort from her father an acknowledgment that the horses were engaged.
fr: -- Mais si vous les donniez aujourd'hui, dit Elisabeth, le plan de ma mere seroit manque.

eng: Jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback, and her mother attended her to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a bad day.
fr: Elle parvint ainsi, a faire prononcer a son pere que les chevaux etoient occupes ; par consequent Jane fut obligee d'aller a cheval ; sa mere l'accompagna jusqu'a la porte en predisant gaiement le mauvais temps.

eng: Her hopes were answered; Jane had not been gone long before it rained hard.
fr: Ses esperances furent bientot realisees.

eng: Her sisters were uneasy for her, but her mother was delighted.
fr: Jane venoit de partir, lorsqu'une grosse pluie commenca a tomber ; ses soeurs etoient inquietes, mais sa mere etoit ravie.

eng: The rain continued the whole evening without intermission; Jane certainly could not come back.
fr: La pluie continua sans interruption toute la soiree, certainement Jane ne pouvoit pas revenir !

eng: Breakfast was scarcely over when a servant from Netherfield brought the following note for Elizabeth: "My dearest Lizzy," "I FIND myself very unwell this morning, which, I suppose, is to be imputed to my getting wet through yesterday.
fr: Le dejeuner etoit a peine fini, qu'un domestique de Netherfield arriva, apportant le billet suivant pour Elisabeth.

eng: My kind friends will not hear of my returning home till I am better.
fr: Ma chere Lizzy, << Je suis tres-incommodee ce matin, et je dois l'attribuer a ce que j'ai ete mouillee hier.

eng: They insist also on my seeing Mr. Jones--therefore do not be alarmed if you should hear of his having been to me--and excepting a sore-throat and head-ache there is not much the matter with me."
fr: Mes bons amis ne veulent pas entendre parler de me laisser retourner a la maison, avant que je sois mieux, ils insistent aussi pour que je voie Mr.

eng: "Yours, &c." "Well, my dear," said Mr. Bennet, when Elizabeth had read the note aloud, "if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness, if she should die, it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of Mr. Bingley, and under your orders." ~~~ "Oh!
fr: Jones, ainsi vous ne serez pas inquiets si vous apprenez qu'il est venu me voir, je n'ai absolument que mal a la gorge et mal a la tete.

eng: I am not at all afraid of her dying.
fr: >> Votre, etc. -- Eh bien !

eng: People do not die of little trifling colds.
fr: ma chere, dit Mr.
Bennet, lorsqu'Elisabeth eut fini de lire ce billet, si votre fille a une maladie dangereuse, et si elle en meurt, ce sera une consolation pour vous de savoir, qu'elle l'a prise en courant apres Mr.

eng: She will be taken good care of.
fr: Bingley, et par vos ordres.

eng: As long as she stays there, it is all very well.
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ je ne crains pas qu'elle en meure, on ne meurt pas pour un petit coup de froid.

eng: I would go and see her, if I could have the carriage."
fr: Elle sera soignee, tout ira bien tant qu'elle restera la ; j'irai la voir si je puis avoir la voiture.

eng: Elizabeth, feeling really anxious, was determined to go to her, though the carriage was not to be had; and as she was no horse-woman, walking was her only alternative.
fr: Elisabeth qui etoit reellement inquiete de sa soeur, etoit decidee a aller la voir, quoiqu'elle ne put pas avoir la voiture, et comme elle ne savoit pas monter a cheval, elle n'avoit d'autre parti a prendre que celui d'y aller a pied.

eng: She declared her resolution.
fr: Elle declara son intention.

eng: "How can you be so silly," cried her mother, "as to think of such a thing, in all this dirt!
fr: -- Comment pouvez-vous avoir cette idee, s'ecria sa mere : avec une telle boue !

eng: You will not be fit to be seen when you get there."
fr: Vous ne serez pas en etat de vous montrer lorsque vous arriverez.

eng: "I shall be very fit to see Jane--which is all I want."
fr: -- Mais je serai bien en etat de voir c'est tout ce que je veux.

eng: "Is this a hint to me, Lizzy," said her father, "to send for the horses?"
fr: -- Est-ce une maniere de m'insinuer que je dois vous preter les chevaux, Lizzy ?

eng: "No, indeed.
fr: dit son pere.

eng: I do not wish to avoid the walk. ~~~ The distance is nothing, when one has a motive; only three miles. ~~~ I shall be back by dinner."
fr: -- Non en verite, je ne crains point de faire cette promenade ; la distance n'est rien, lorsqu'on a un but ; il n'y a que trois milles, je serai de retour pour diner.

eng: "We will go as far as Meryton with you," said Catherine and Lydia.--Elizabeth accepted their company, and the three young ladies set off together.
fr: -- Nous irons avec vous, jusqu'a Meryton, s'ecrierent Catherine et Lydie ; Elisabeth accepta leur compagnie, et les trois jeunes personnes partirent ensemble.

eng: "If we make haste," said Lydia, as they walked along, "perhaps we may see something of Captain Carter before he goes."
fr: -- Si nous allons vite, disoit Lydie, tout en marchant, nous pourrons peut-etre encore voir le capitaine Carter, avant qu'il parte.

eng: In Meryton they parted; the two youngest repaired to the lodgings of one of the officers' wives, and Elizabeth continued her walk alone, crossing field after field at a quick pace, jumping over stiles and springing over puddles with impatient activity, and finding herself at last within view of the house, with weary ancles, dirty stockings, and a face glowing with the warmth of exercise.
fr: A Meryton, elles se separerent ; les deux plus jeunes allerent chez la femme d'un officier, dont elles s'etoient deja fait une amie, et Elisabeth continua seule sa route, traversant les champs d'un pas precipite, sautant par dessus les haies et les ruisseaux avec une impatiente vivacite ; elle arriva enfin tres-fatiguee, ses bas crottes, et avec un teint anime par l'exercice.

eng: When breakfast was over, they were joined by the sisters; and Elizabeth began to like them herself, when she saw how much affection and solicitude they shewed for Jane.
fr: Lorsque le dejeuner fut fini, les deux soeurs les rejoignirent, Elisabeth commenca a les aimer un peu plus, lorsqu'elle vit combien de tendresse et d'attention elles temoignoient a Jane.

eng: The apothecary came, and having examined his patient, said, as might be supposed, that she had caught a violent cold, and that they must endeavour to get the better of it; advised her to return to bed, and promised her some draughts.
fr: Le medecin arriva, et ayant interroge la malade, il prononca, comme on l'avoit bien suppose, qu'elle avoit un violent coup de froid. ~~~ Il lui conseilla de se remettre au lit, et promit de lui envoyer quelques potions.

eng: The advice was followed readily, for the feverish symptoms increased, and her head ached acutely.
fr: Son conseil fut promptement suivi, car la fievre augmentant, elle souffroit beaucoup de la tete.

eng: When the clock struck three, Elizabeth felt that she must go; and very unwillingly said so.
fr: Quand trois heures sonnerent, Elisabeth pensa qu'elle devoit partir et le dit avec chagrin.

eng: Miss Bingley offered her the carriage, and she only wanted a little pressing to accept it, when Jane testified such concern in parting with her, that Miss Bingley was obliged to convert the offer of the chaise into an invitation to remain at Netherfield for the present.
fr: Miss Bingley lui offrit la voiture, mais la pressa faiblement de l'accepter.

eng: Elizabeth most thankfully consented, and a servant was dispatched to Longbourn to acquaint the family with her stay, and bring back a supply of clothes.
fr: Alors Jane temoigna tant de peine de voir partir sa soeur, que Miss Bingley fut obligee de changer l'offre de la voiture en une invitation de rester a Netherfield ; Elisabeth l'accepta avec reconnoissance, et un domestique fut envoye a Longbourn, pour dire qu'elle n'y retournoit pas, et pour lui rapporter les vetemens qui lui etoient necessaires.

eng: CHAPTER VIII.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE VIII.

eng: At five o'clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half past six Elizabeth was summoned to dinner. ~~~ To the civil enquiries which then poured in, and amongst which she had the pleasure of distinguishing the much superior solicitude of Mr. Bingley's, she could not make a very favourable answer.
fr: A cinq heures, les deux dames se retirerent pour faire leur toilette, et a six et demie, on vint avertir Elisabeth que le diner etoit servi ; elle descendit, et put repondre d'une maniere satisfaisante, aux obligeantes questions qu'on lui fit sur l'etat de sa soeur, questions parmi lesquelles elle eut le plaisir de distinguer celles de Mr. ~~~ Bingley, qui temoignoit encore plus de sollicitude que les autres.

eng: Jane was by no means better.
fr: Jane etoit vraiment mieux.

eng: The sisters, on hearing this, repeated three or four times how much they were grieved, how shocking it was to have a bad cold, and how excessively they disliked being ill themselves; and then thought no more of the matter: and their indifference towards Jane when not immediately before them, restored Elizabeth to the enjoyment of all her original dislike.
fr: Les deux dames de Netherfield apres avoir repete plusieurs fois, combien elles etoient desolees qu'elle eut pris ce rhume, combien elles craindroient elles-memes d'etre malades, etc, etc, n'y penserent plus ; et leur indifference pour Jane lorsqu'elle n'etoit plus sous leurs yeux, permit a Elisabeth de se livrer, de nouveau, a l'eloignement qu'elle avoit d'abord ressenti pour elles.

eng: Their brother, indeed, was the only one of the party whom she could regard with any complacency.
fr: Leur frere etoit dans le fait la seule personne qu'elle put voir avec plaisir.

eng: His anxiety for Jane was evident, and his attentions to herself most pleasing, and they prevented her feeling herself so much an intruder as she believed she was considered by the others.
fr: Sa sollicitude pour Jane se montroit visiblement, et ses attentions pour elle-meme, l'empecherent de se trouver aussi deplacee que les autres le pensoient : lui seul s'occupoit d'elle.

eng: She had very little notice from any but him.
fr: Miss Bingley etoit entierement distraite par M. Darcy, sa soeur ne l'etoit guere moins.

eng: Miss Bingley was engrossed by Mr. Darcy, her sister scarcely less so; and as for Mr. Hurst, by whom Elizabeth sat, he was an indolent man, who lived only to eat, drink, and play at cards, who when he found her prefer a plain dish to a ragout, had nothing to say to her.
fr: Mr. ~~~ Hurst, a cote de qui Elisabeth etoit placee, etoit un homme indolent, qui ne vivoit que pour manger, boire et jouer, et lorsqu'il vit qu'elle preferoit des mets simples a des plats plus recherches, il n'eut plus rien a lui dire.

eng: When dinner was over, she returned directly to Jane, and Miss Bingley began abusing her as soon as she was out of the room. ~~~ Her manners were pronounced to be very bad indeed, a mixture of pride and impertinence; she had no conversation, no style, no taste, no beauty.
fr: Elisabeth retourna vers Jane immediatement apres le diner ; aussitot qu'elle fut sortie de la chambre, Miss Bingley commenca a se moquer d'elle ; elle decida qu'il y avoit dans sa contenance un melange d'orgueil et d'impertinence ; qu'elle n'avoit ni conversation, ni gout, ni beaute ; Mistriss Hurst pensoit de meme, et ajouta : Elle n'a rien en sa faveur, si ce n'est qu'elle marche bien ; je n'oublierai jamais son entree de ce matin, elle avoit presque l'air d'une femme echappee de quelque horde de sauvages.

eng: Mrs. Hurst thought the same, and added, "She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent walker.
fr: -- C'est parfaitement vrai, Louisa, j'avois toutes les peines du monde a garder mon serieux.

eng: I shall never forget her appearance this morning.
She really looked almost wild."
fr: Quelle sottise de venir ici !

eng: "She did indeed, Louisa. ~~~ I could hardly keep my countenance.
fr: Avait-elle besoin de courir a travers champs, parce que sa soeur avoit pris un coup de froid ?

eng: Very nonsensical to come at all!
fr: Avec ses cheveux detaches et ebouriffes !

eng: Why must _she_ be scampering about the country, because her sister had a cold?
Her hair so untidy, so blowsy!"
fr: -- Oui, et sa jupe !

eng: "Yes, and her petticoat; I hope you saw her petticoat, six inches deep in mud, I am absolutely certain; and the gown which had been let down to hide it, not doing its office."
fr: j'espere que vous avez vu sa jupe, qui avoit, j'en suis sure, au moins six pouces de boue ; sa robe qu'elle avoit laissee retomber par-dessus pour la cacher, ne remplissoit pas trop bien son devoir.

eng: "Your picture may be very exact, Louisa," said Bingley; "but this was all lost upon me.
fr: -- Votre description peut etre tres-exacte, Louisa, dit Mr.

eng: I thought Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked remarkably well, when she came into the room this morning.
fr: Bingley, mais tout cela a ete perdu pour moi ; je trouvois Miss Elisabeth extremement bien, lorsqu'elle est arrivee ce matin ; sa jupe crottee ne m'a point frappe.

eng: Her dirty petticoat quite escaped my notice."
fr: -- Vous l'auriez observee, je suis sure, Mr.

eng: "_You_ observed it, Mr. Darcy, I am sure," said Miss Bingley; "and I am inclined to think that you would not wish to see _your sister_ make such an exhibition."
fr: Darcy ; je penche a croire, que vous ne voudriez pas voir votre soeur faire une pareille escapade.

eng: --A short pause followed this speech, and Mrs. Hurst began again.
fr: Un court silence suivit cette reponse ; Mistriss Hurst reprit la parole.

eng: "I have an excessive regard for Jane Bennet, she is really a very sweet girl, and I wish with all my heart she were well settled.
fr: -- J'aime beaucoup Jane Bennet, c'est une charmante fille, que je souhaite de tout mon coeur de voir bien etablie ; mais je crains qu'avec un tel pere, une telle mere, et des relations si peu relevees, elle n'ait pas beaucoup de chances en sa faveur.

eng: But with such a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is no chance of it."
fr: -- Je crois avoir entendu dire, qu'elles ont un oncle avocat a Meryton.

eng: "I think I have heard you say, that their uncle is an attorney in Meryton."
fr: -- Oui, et elles en ont un autre, qui demeure a Londres, dans quelqu'endroit pres de Cheap-side. ~~~ -- Oh !

eng: "Yes; and they have another, who lives somewhere near Cheapside."
fr: celui-la, c'est le personnage le plus considere de toute la famille.

eng: "That is capital," added her sister, and they both laughed heartily.
fr: Et elles se mirent a rire aux eclats.
