To Kitty, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected.
fr: Cet evenement ne paroit pas etre tres-inattendu pour Kitty !

eng: I am very, very sorry. ~~~ So imprudent a match on both sides!--But I am willing to hope the best, and that his character has been misunderstood.
fr: J'en suis bien fachee, c'est un mariage si peu convenable pour les deux parties !...

eng: Thoughtless and indiscreet I can easily believe him, but this step (and let us rejoice over it) marks nothing bad at heart. ~~~ His choice is disinterested at least, for he must know my father can give her nothing.
fr: Je veux esperer que son caractere a ete noirci ; je puis facilement croire qu'il est indiscret et leger ; mais cette demarche, rejouissons-nous-en, ne prouve pas un mauvais coeur ; son choix est desinteresse, car il doit bien savoir que mon pere ne peut rien donner a ses filles.

eng: Our poor mother is sadly grieved. ~~~ My father bears it better.
fr: Notre pauvre mere est au desespoir de cet evenement, mon pere le supporte mieux.

eng: How thankful am I, that we never let them know what has been said against him; we must forget it ourselves.
fr: Combien je trouve heureux que nous n'ayons rien dit contre lui !

eng: They were off Saturday night about twelve, as is conjectured, but were not missed till yesterday morning at eight. ~~~ The express was sent off directly.
fr: Ils s'enfuirent samedi, on croit aux environs de minuit, mais on ne s'en est apercu que le lendemain ; on nous a envoye l'expres a l'instant meme.

eng: My dear Lizzy, they must have passed within ten miles of us.
fr: Ils doivent deja etre a dix milles de nous.

eng: Colonel Forster gives us reason to expect him here soon.
fr: Le colonel Forster croit que nous les reverrons bientot ici.

eng: Lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of their intention.
fr: Lydie a laisse quelques lignes pour Mistriss Forster, ou elle l'informoit de leur intention.

eng: I must conclude, for I cannot be long from my poor mother.
fr: Je dois finir, car je ne puis rester plus long-temps eloignee de ma pauvre mere.

eng: I am afraid you will not be able to make it out, but I hardly know what I have written."
fr: Je crains que vous ne puissiez pas me lire, je sais a peine ce que j'ai ecrit.

eng: Without allowing herself time for consideration, and scarcely knowing what she felt, Elizabeth on finishing this letter, instantly seized the other, and opening it with the utmost impatience, read as follows: it had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first.
fr: >> Sans se donner le temps de faire aucune reflexion, Elisabeth, en finissant cette lettre, ouvrit l'autre ; elle avoit ete ecrite vingt-quatre heures apres la premiere.

eng: "By this time, my dearest sister, you have received my hurried letter; I wish this may be more intelligible, but though not confined for time, my head is so bewildered that I cannot answer for being coherent.
fr: << Je souhaite, ma chere soeur, que cette lettre soit plus lisible que la derniere ; cependant je suis si troublee, que je ne saurois mettre beaucoup de suite dans ce que j'ecris.

eng: Our distress, my dear Lizzy, is very great.
fr: Notre malheur est grand, ma chere Lizzy !

eng: My father and mother believe the worst, but I cannot think so ill of him.
fr: Mon pere et ma mere veulent supposer tout ce qu'il y a de pire, mais je ne puis avoir si mauvaise opinion de Wikam et de ma soeur.

eng: Many circumstances might make it more eligible for them to be married privately in town than to pursue their first plan; and even if _he_ could form such a design against a young woman of Lydia's connections, which is not likely, can I suppose her so lost to every thing?--Impossible.
fr: Il y a tant de circonstances qui peuvent leur avoir fait preferer d'etre maries secretement a Londres, plutot que de suivre leur premier projet, qu'on peut comprendre leur demarche ; et meme, si Wikam avoir pu former de tels desseins sur une jeune fille d'une famille respectable, ce qui n'est pas vraisemblable, pouvons-nous croire que Lydie ait perdu tout sentiment d'honneur et de reserve ? ~~~ Non, c'est impossible !

eng: Could she exert herself it would be better, but this is not to be expected; and as to my father, I never in my life saw him so affected.
fr: -- Ma pauvre mere est reellement bien malade, elle garde la chambre ; quant a mon pere, je ne l'ai jamais vu si affecte.

eng: Poor Kitty has anger for having concealed their attachment; but as it was a matter of confidence one cannot wonder.
fr: La pauvre Kitty est tres-fachee d'avoir cache leur inclination ; mais on ne peut lui reprocher de n'avoir pas trahi leur confiance.

eng: I am truly glad, dearest Lizzy, that you have been spared something of these distressing scenes; but now as the first shock is over, shall I own that I long for your return? ~~~ I am not so selfish, however, as to press for it, if inconvenient.
fr: Je suis bien aise, ma chere Lizzy, que vous n'ayez pas ete temoin de ces tristes scenes ; mais a present que le premier choc est passe, j'avoue que je languis apres votre retour ; je ne suis cependant pas assez egoiste pour vous engager a le precipiter, s'il y a quelques inconveniens.

eng: I take up my pen again to do, what I have just told you I would not, but circumstances are such, that I cannot help earnestly begging you all to come here, as soon as possible.
fr: >> << P. S. ~~~ Je reprends la plume justement pour faire ce que je ne voulois pas, mais les circonstances sont telles, que je dois reellement vous engager a revenir ici le plutot que vous pourrez.

eng: I know my dear uncle and aunt so well, that I am not afraid of requesting it, though I have still something more to ask of the former.
My father is going to London with Colonel Forster instantly, to try to discover her.
fr: Je connois si bien mon oncle et ma tante, que je ne crains pas de m'adresser a eux.

eng: What he means to do, I am sure I know not; but his excessive distress will not allow him to pursue any measure in the best and safest way, and Colonel Forster is obliged to be at Brighton again to-morrow evening.
fr: Mon pere va partir pour Londres avec le colonel Forster, pour tacher de les decouvrir ; je ne sais trop ce qu'il y pourra faire, son extreme affliction ne lui permettra peut-etre pas de prendre les meilleurs moyens : le colonel Forster est oblige d'etre a Brighton demain au soir.

eng: In such an exigence my uncle's advice and assistance would be every thing in the world; he will immediately comprehend what I must feel, and I rely upon his goodness."
fr: Les avis et les secours de mon oncle seroient bien necessaires a mon pauvre pere ; il comprendra tout ce que nous devons eprouver, et je compte sur sa bonte.

eng: Her pale face and impetuous manner made him start, and before he could recover himself enough to speak, she, in whose mind every idea was superseded by Lydia's situation, hastily exclaimed, "I beg your pardon, but I must leave you.
fr: La paleur d'Elisabeth et l'impetuosite de ses mouvemens le firent reculer de quelques pas : mais, uniquement occupee de Lydie, Elisabeth s'ecria : -- Pardonnez-moi, je dois vous laisser, il faut que je trouve tout de suite Mr.

eng: I must find Mr. Gardiner this moment, on business that cannot be delayed; I have not an instant to lose."
fr: Gardiner ! ~~~ je n'ai pas un instant a perdre.

eng: "Good God!
fr: -- Grand Dieu !

eng: You are not well enough;--you cannot go yourself."
fr: Gardiner ; vous n'etes pas bien, vous ne pouvez y aller vous-meme.

eng: Elizabeth hesitated, but her knees trembled under her, and she felt how little would be gained by her attempting to pursue them.
fr: -- Elisabeth hesitoit, et ses genoux trembloient sous elle, elle sentoit qu'elle ne pouvoit faire un pas ; alors rappelant le domestique, elle le chargea d'aller chercher son oncle et sa tante, d'une voix si tremblante qu'on pouvoit a peine l'entendre.

eng: Calling back the servant, therefore, she commissioned him, though in so breathless an accent as made her almost unintelligible, to fetch his master and mistress home, instantly.
fr: Elle s'assit, incapable de se soutenir plus long-temps.

eng: On his quitting the room, she sat down, unable to support herself, and looking so miserably ill, that it was impossible for Darcy to leave her, or to refrain from saying, in a tone of gentleness and commiseration, "Let me call your maid.
fr: Elle avoit l'air si souffrant, qu'il fut impossible a Darcy de la quitter.

eng: Is there nothing you could take, to give you present relief?--A glass of wine;--shall I get you one?--You are very ill." "No, I thank you;" she replied, endeavouring to recover herself.
fr: -- Laissez-moi appeler votre femme de chambre, lui dit-il avec l'expression d'un profond sentiment, vous allez vous trouver mal !

eng: "There is nothing the matter with me.
fr: je vais chercher des sels.

eng: I am quite well.
fr: -- Non !

eng: I am only distressed by some dreadful news which I have just received from Longbourn."
fr: je vous remercie, ce ne sera rien ; je suis seulement affligee des terribles nouvelles que je viens de recevoir de Longbourn.

eng: She burst into tears as she alluded to it, and for a few minutes could not speak another word.
fr: En disant cela, elle fondit en larmes, et pendant quelques momens elle ne put prononcer un seul mot.

eng: Darcy, in wretched suspense, could only say something indistinctly of his concern, and observe her in compassionate silence.
fr: Darcy, dans la triste incertitude ou il etoit, osoit a peine exprimer l'interet qu'il prenoit a elle, et la regardoit en silence.
Enfin, elle reprit la parole : -- Je viens de recevoir une lettre de Jane contenant d'affreuses nouvelles !

eng: At length, she spoke again.
fr: elles ne pourront etre secretes pour personne.

eng: "I have just had a letter from Jane, with such dreadful news.
fr: Ma soeur cadette a abandonne tous ses amis, elle est en fuite !

eng: It cannot be concealed from any one.
fr: Elle s'est mise au pouvoir de Mr.

eng: My youngest sister has left all her friends--has eloped;--has thrown herself into the power of--of Mr. Wickham.
fr: Wikam !

eng: They are gone off together from Brighton.
fr: Ils sont partis ensemble de Brighton.

eng: But it is all, all too late now."
fr: Mais c'est trop tard !

eng: "I am grieved, indeed," cried Darcy; "grieved--shocked.
fr: -- Mais, s'ecria Darcy, est-ce une chose parfaitement sure ?

eng: But is it certain, absolutely certain?" ~~~ "Oh yes!--They left Brighton together on Sunday night, and were traced almost to London, but not beyond; they are certainly not gone to Scotland."
fr: -- Ce n'est que trop certain, ils sont partis de Brighton samedi soir ; on a suivi leurs traces presque jusqu'a Londres, mais pas au-dela ; ils ne sont certainement pas alles en Ecosse.

eng: "And what has been done, what has been attempted, to recover her?"
fr: -- Quel moyen a-t-on employe pour les decouvrir ?

eng: "My father is gone to London, and Jane has written to beg my uncle's immediate assistance, and we shall be off, I hope, in half an hour.
fr: -- Mon pere est parti pour Londres, et Jane ecrit pour implorer le secours de mon oncle.

eng: But nothing can be done; I know very well that nothing can be done.
fr: J'espere que nous allons partir tout de suite ; mais, helas !

eng: How is such a man to be worked on?
fr: que peut-on faire ?

eng: How are they even to be discovered?
fr: Que peut-on esperer d'un homme pareil ?

eng: I have not the smallest hope.
fr: Comment pourra-t-on les decouvrir ? ~~~ Ah !

eng: It is every way horrible!"
fr: je n'ai pas la plus legere esperance.

eng: Darcy shook his head in silent acquiesence.
fr: Tout cela est affreux !

eng: "When _my_ eyes were opened to his real character.--Oh!
fr: Darcy secouoit la tete, et ne pouvoit rien lui dire pour la rassurer.

eng: had I known what I ought, what I dared, to do! ~~~ But I knew not--I was afraid of doing too much.
fr: -- Oh, que n'ai-je parle lorsque j'ai eu les yeux ouverts sur son veritable caractere !

eng: Wretched, wretched, mistake!" ~~~ Darcy made no answer.
fr: Mais j'ai craint de reveler... Oh malheureuse, malheureuse erreur !

eng: He seemed scarcely to hear her, and was walking up and down the room in earnest meditation; his brow contracted, his air gloomy.
fr: Darcy ne repondit point, il paroissoit a peine l'entendre, et se promenoit dans la chambre, plonge dans une profonde reverie, les sourcils fronces, toute la figure empreinte d'une expression sombre.

eng: Her power was sinking; every thing _must_ sink under such a proof of family weakness, such an assurance of the deepest disgrace.
fr: Tous les charmes qu'elle avoit eus pour lui alloient s'evanouir, tout sentiment devoit disparoitre a cote d'un tel deshonneur dans sa famille !

eng: She could neither wonder nor condemn, but the belief of his self-conquest brought nothing consolatory to her bosom, afforded no palliation of her distress.
fr: elle ne pouvoit ni s'en etonner, ni le condamner.

eng: It was, on the contrary, exactly calculated to make her understand her own wishes; and never had she so honestly felt that she could have loved him, as now, when all love must be vain.
fr: Jamais elle n'avoit si bien senti qu'elle l'aimoit, que dans ce moment ou elle voyoit qu'il falloit renoncer a lui !

eng: "Oh, yes.
fr: -- Oh oui !

eng: Be so kind as to apologize for us to Miss Darcy. ~~~ Say that urgent business calls us home immediately.
fr: Ayez la bonte de nous excuser aupres de Miss Darcy ; dites-lui que des affaires pressantes nous rappellent !

eng: Conceal the unhappy truth as long as it is possible.--I know it cannot be long."
fr: Cachez la malheureuse realite aussi long-temps que vous pourrez ; je crains bien qu'elle ne soit trop vite connue.

eng: As he quitted the room, Elizabeth felt how improbable it was that they should ever see each other again on such terms of cordiality as had marked their several meetings in Derbyshire; and as she threw a retrospective glance over the whole of their acquaintance, so full of contradictions and varieties, sighed at the perverseness of those feelings which would now have promoted its continuance, and would formerly have rejoiced in its termination.
fr: Elisabeth sentit alors combien il etoit peu probable qu'ils se revissent jamais avec le degre de bienveillance et d'interet qui avoit marque leur rencontre dans le Derbyshire ; et, jetant ses regards en arriere sur toute la suite de leurs liaisons, qui avoit ete si remplie d'evenemens varies et contradictoires, elle soupira en pensant a la singularite des sentimens qui lui faisoient regretter maintenant si vivement celui qu'elle se seroit rejouie autrefois de ne plus voir.

eng: If gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection, Elizabeth's change of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty.
fr: Les chagrins qu'elle alloit devoir a la coupable conduite de sa soeur, augmentoient encore l'horreur de ses reflexions.

eng: But if otherwise, if the regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or unnatural, in comparison of what is so often described as arising on a first interview with its object, and even before two words have been exchanged, nothing can be said in her defence, except that she had given somewhat of a trial to the latter method, in her partiality for Wickham, and that its ill-success might perhaps authorise her to seek the other less interesting mode of attachment.
fr: La seconde lettre de Jane lui otoit toute esperance ; Jane seule pouvoit encore se flatter la-dessus.

eng: Be that as it may, she saw him go with regret; and in this early example of what Lydia's infamy must produce, found additional anguish as she reflected on that wretched business.
fr: Pendant le sejour du regiment dans le Hertfordshire, Elisabeth ne s'etoit jamais apercue que Lydie eut un sentiment particulier pour Wikam, mais elle etoit convaincue qu'il ne lui avoit pas fallu beaucoup de peine pour la captiver.

eng: Never, since reading Jane's second letter, had she entertained a hope of Wickham's meaning to marry her.
fr: Lydie changeoit souvent de favori, tantot un officier, tantot l'autre ; elle ne les estimoit que d'apres leurs assiduites aupres d'elle.

eng: No one but Jane, she thought, could flatter herself with such an expectation.
fr: Ses affections etoient toujours flottantes, mais jamais sans objet.

eng: Surprise was the least of her feelings on this developement.
fr: L'insouciance de son pere et l'indulgence mal entendue de sa mere avoient fait son malheur.

eng: While the contents of the first letter remained on her mind, she was all surprise--all astonishment that Wickham should marry a girl, whom it was impossible he could marry for money; and how Lydia could ever have attached him, had appeared incomprehensible. ~~~ But now it was all too natural.
fr: Elisabeth desiroit avec ardeur de retourner a Longbourn, pour partager avec Jane les soins qui devoient tous reposer sur elle dans une famille ou le trouble regnoit, dont le pere etoit absent, et ou la mere, incapable de prendre une resolution, demandoit des soins continuels.

eng: For such an attachment as this, she might have sufficient charms; and though she did not suppose Lydia to be deliberately engaging in an elopement, without the intention of marriage, she had no difficulty in believing that neither her virtue nor her understanding would preserve her from falling an easy prey.
fr: Quoiqu'elle fut persuadee qu'on ne pouvoit rien faire pour Lydie, cependant le secours de son oncle lui paroissoit de la plus grande necessite ; son impatience de le voir arriver etoit extreme. ~~~ Mr.

eng: She had never perceived, while the regiment was in Hertfordshire, that Lydia had any partiality for him, but she was convinced that Lydia had wanted only encouragement to attach herself to any body.
fr: et Mistriss Gardiner, alarmes par le recit du domestique, avoient suppose que leur niece s'etoit trouvee mal, et s'etoient hates de revenir ; mais elle les tranquillisa bientot a cet egard, et leur apprit le sujet de son message en lisant les deux lettres de Jane, et en appuyant avec energie sur le post-scriptum de la derniere.

eng: Sometimes one officer, sometimes another had been her favourite, as their attentions raised them in her opinion.
fr: L'impression que cette lecture produisit sur Mr. ~~~ et Mistriss Gardiner n'etoit pas douteuse.

eng: Her affections had been continually fluctuating, but never without an object.
fr: Apres les premieres exclamations de chagrin, Mr. ~~~ Gardiner promit de faire tout ce qui seroit en son pouvoir.

eng: The mischief of neglect and mistaken indulgence towards such a girl.--Oh!
fr: Elisabeth, quoiqu'elle n'en eut pas attendu moins, le remercia avec des larmes de reconnoissance.

eng: how acutely did she now feel it.
fr: Les preparatifs du depart furent bientot faits.

eng: She was wild to be at home--to hear, to see, to be upon the spot, to share with Jane in the cares that must now fall wholly upon her, in a family so deranged; a father absent, a mother incapable of exertion, and requiring constant attendance; and though almost persuaded that nothing could be done for Lydia, her uncle's interference seemed of the utmost importance, and till he entered the room, the misery of her impatience was severe.

Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner had hurried back in alarm, supposing, by the servant's account, that their niece was taken suddenly ill;--but satisfying them instantly on that head, she eagerly communicated the cause of their summons, reading the two letters aloud, and dwelling on the postscript of the last, with trembling energy.--Though Lydia had never been a favourite with them, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner could not but be deeply affected.

Not Lydia only, but all were concerned in it; and after the first exclamations of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner readily promised every assistance in his power.--Elizabeth, though expecting no less, thanked him with tears of gratitude; and all three being actuated by one spirit, every thing relating to their journey was speedily settled.
They were to be off as soon as possible.
fr: Ils vouloient partir aussitot.

eng: "But what is to be done about Pemberley?"
fr: -- Mais que faut-il faire pour Pemberley ?

eng: cried Mrs. Gardiner.
fr: s'ecria Mistriss Gardiner ; John nous a dit que Mr.

eng: "John told us Mr. Darcy was here when you sent for us;--was it so?"
fr: Darcy etoit ici lorsque vous nous avez envoye chercher, est-ce vrai ?

eng: "Yes; and I told him we should not be able to keep our engagement.
fr: -- Oui, et je lui ai dit que nous ne pouvions remplir notre engagement ; tout cela est arrange.

eng: _That_ is all settled."
fr: -- Tout cela est arrange !

eng: "That is all settled;" repeated the other, as she ran into her room to prepare.
fr: repetoit sa tante en passant dans sa chambre pour achever les preparatifs.

eng: "And are they upon such terms as for her to disclose the real truth!
fr: Sont-ils donc sur un tel pied ensemble, qu'elle ait ose lui dire la verite ? ~~~ Oh !

eng: Oh, that I knew how it was!"
fr: que je voudrois savoir ce qu'il en est.

eng: But wishes were vain; or at best could serve only to amuse her in the hurry and confusion of the following hour.

Had Elizabeth been at leisure to be idle, she would have remained certain that all employment was impossible to one so wretched as herself; but she had her share of business as well as her aunt, and amongst the rest there were notes to be written to all their friends in Lambton, with false excuses for their sudden departure.
fr: Au milieu de toutes les occupations de nos voyageurs, ils eurent encore plusieurs billets a ecrire a leurs connoissances de Lambton, pour donner quelques raisons supposees de leur depart precipite ; cependant tout fut fini au bout d'une heure.

eng: Could he expect that her friends would not step forward?
fr: Peut-il imaginer que ses amis ne feront aucunes demarches pour elle ?

eng: Could he expect to be noticed again by the regiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster?
fr: Peut-il croire qu'il sera bien vu dans le regiment, apres avoir fait un tel affront au colonel chez qui elle demeuroit alors ?

eng: His temptation is not adequate to the risk."
fr: Non, le plaisir qu'il pourroit y trouver n'est pas egal aux risques qu'il court.

eng: "Do you really think so?"
fr: -- Pensez-vous ?

eng: cried Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.
fr: s'ecria Elisabeth, avec une lueur d'esperance.

eng: "Upon my word," said Mrs. Gardiner, "I begin to be of your uncle's opinion. ~~~ It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and interest, for him to be guilty of it. ~~~ I cannot think so very ill of Wickham.
fr: -- Mais vraiment, dit Mistriss Gardiner, je commence a etre de l'avis de votre oncle ; il seroit trop coupable envers l'honneur, la decence et son interet meme ; je ne puis avoir si mauvaise opinion de Wikam ; pouvez-vous vous-meme l'en croire capable ?

eng: Can you, yourself, Lizzy, so wholly give him up, as to believe him capable of it?"
fr: -- Non, je ne le crois pas capable de negliger son propre interet ; hors de la, il peut tout faire.

eng: "Not perhaps of neglecting his own interest. ~~~ But of every other neglect I can believe him capable.
fr: Cependant, si la chose est telle que vous la supposez, pourquoi n'auroient ils pas ete en Ecosse ?

eng: If, indeed, it should be so!
But I dare not hope it.
fr: -- D'abord, reprit Mr.

eng: Why should they not go on to Scotland, if that had been the case?"
"In the first place," replied Mr. Gardiner, "there is no absolute proof that they are not gone to Scotland." ~~~ "Oh!
but their removing from the chaise into an hackney coach is such a presumption!
fr: Gardiner, il n'y a pas de preuves positives qu'ils n'y soient pas alles.

eng: And, besides, no traces of them were to be found on the Barnet road."
fr: -- Mais on n'a point trouve leurs traces sur le chemin de Barnet.

eng: "Well, then--supposing them to be in London. ~~~ They may be there, though for the purpose of concealment, for no more exceptionable purpose.
fr: -- Eh bien, supposons qu'ils aient ete a Londres ; quoiqu'ils se cachent, ils peuvent avoir la meme intention.

eng: It is not likely that money should be very abundant on either side; and it might strike them that they could be more economically, though less expeditiously, married in London, than in Scotland." ~~~ "But why all this secrecy?
fr: Ils ne doivent pas avoir beaucoup d'argent ni l'un ni l'autre, et peut-etre ont-ils eu l'idee qu'ils seroient maries d'une maniere plus prompte et plus economique a Londres.

eng: Why any fear of detection?
fr: -- Pourquoi ce mystere ?

eng: Why must their marriage be private? ~~~ Oh!
fr: Pourquoi leur mariage doit-il etre si secret ?

eng: no, no, this is not likely. ~~~ His most particular friend, you see by Jane's account, was persuaded of his never intending to marry her.
fr: Ne voyez-vous pas, par le recit de Jane, que son plus intime ami ne croyoit pas qu'il eut l'intention de se marier ?

eng: Wickham will never marry a woman without some money. ~~~ He cannot afford it.
fr: Wikam n'epousera jamais une femme sans fortune, il ne peut s'en passer.

eng: And what claims has Lydia, what attractions has she beyond youth, health, and good humour, that could make him for her sake, forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well?
fr: Et quels charmes a Lydie, apres ceux que donnent la sante, la jeunesse et la gaiete, qui puissent le seduire jusqu'a lui faire renoncer a la possibilite de faire un bon mariage ?

eng: As to what restraint the apprehension of disgrace in the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce. ~~~ But as to your other objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good.
fr: Quant a la crainte d'etre mal vu dans le regiment pour l'avoir enlevee et deshonoree, je ne puis en juger ; mais pour les autres considerations qui, dites-vous, auroient du l'arreter, je ne les crois pas fondees.

eng: Lydia has no brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father's behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that _he_ would do as little, and think as little about it, as any father could do, in such a matter."
fr: Lydie n'a point de frere pour venger son honneur ; et Wikam peut supposer, d'apres la conduite, l'insouciance de mon pere et le peu de soin qu'il a toujours paru donner a tout ce qui concerne sa famille, que, dans ce cas-ci, il se mettra peu en peine d'agir et de le poursuivre.

eng: "But can you think that Lydia is so lost to every thing but love of him, as to consent to live with him on any other terms than marriage?"
fr: -- Mais supposez-vous que Lydie ait si peu d'honneur et l'aime assez passionnement, pour avoir consenti a le suivre a d'autres conditions que celles du mariage ?

eng: "It does seem, and it is most shocking indeed," replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes, "that a sister's sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt.
fr: -- Il est bien cruel, repondit Elisabeth les larmes aux yeux, de douter de la vertu d'une soeur dans une pareille occasion.

eng: But, really, I know not what to say. ~~~ Perhaps I am not doing her justice.
fr: Mais... je ne sais que dire... peut-etre je ne lui rends pas justice.

eng: "Of whom does Jane ever think ill?
fr: -- De qui Jane a-t-elle jamais eu mauvaise opinion ?

eng: And who is there, whatever might be their former conduct, that she would believe capable of such an attempt, till it were proved against them?
fr: et quel homme pourroit-elle croire capable d'une telle action ?

eng: But Jane knows, as well as I do, what Wickham really is. ~~~ We both know that he has been profligate in every sense of the word.
fr: Mais elle sait aussi bien que moi ce qu'est Wikam ; nous savons toutes deux qu'il n'a ni honneur ni probite, et qu'il est aussi fourbe, aussi trompeur qu'insinuant.

eng: That he has neither integrity nor honour.
fr: -- Comment !

eng: That he is as false and deceitful, as he is insinuating."
"And do you really know all this?"
fr: vous savez tout cela ?

eng: cried Mrs. Gardiner, whose curiosity as to the mode of her intelligence was all alive.
fr: s'ecria Mistriss Gardiner, dont la curiosite etoit vivement excitee.

eng: "I do, indeed," replied Elizabeth, colouring.
fr: -- Oui, je le sais, repeta Elisabeth en rougissant ; je vous ai parle l'autre jour de son infame conduite envers Mr.

eng: "I told you the other day, of his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you, yourself, when last at Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man, who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality towards him. ~~~ And there are other circumstances which I am not at liberty--which it is not worth while to relate; but his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless.
fr: Darcy, et vous avez entendu vous-meme, pendant votre dernier sejour a Longbourn, comment il parloit de l'homme qui avoit eu tant de liberalite et d'indulgence pour lui : il y a encore d'autres circonstances que je ne puis... et qu'il n'est pas necessaire de raconter ; mais ses mensonges sur la famille de Pemberley sont innombrables.

eng: From what he said of Miss Darcy, I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud, reserved, disagreeable girl. ~~~ Yet he knew to the contrary himself.
fr: D'apres ce qu'il m'avoit dit de Miss Darcy, je m'etois preparee a voir une personne fiere, dedaigneuse et desagreable, cependant il savoit mieux que personne combien elle est simple et aimable.

eng: He must know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found her."
fr: -- Mais Lydie n'a-t-elle eu connoissance de rien de tout cela ?

eng: "But does Lydia know nothing of this?
Can she be ignorant of what you and Jane seem so well to understand?"
fr: Peut-elle ignorer ce que Jane et vous semblez si bien savoir ?

eng: Till I was in Kent, and saw so much both of Mr. Darcy and his relation, Colonel Fitzwilliam, I was ignorant of the truth myself.
fr: J'ai ignore moi-meme la verite jusqu'au moment ou j'ai ete dans le comte de Kent, ou j'ai beaucoup vu Mr.

eng: And when I returned home, the ----shire was to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight's time.

As that was the case, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could it apparently be to any one, that the good opinion which all the neighbourhood had of him, should then be overthrown?

And even when it was settled that Lydia should go with Mrs. Forster, the necessity of opening her eyes to his character never occurred to me. ~~~ That _she_ could be in any danger from the deception never entered my head.
fr: Darcy et son cousin le colonel Fitz-Williams ; et lorsque je revins a Longbourn, le regiment devant quitter Meryton quinze jours apres, nous ne crumes pas necessaire, Jane et moi, de rendre public ce que nous avions appris.

eng: That such a consequence as _this_ should ensue, you may easily believe was far enough from my thoughts."
fr: Quel avantage pouvoit-il y avoir a detruire la bonne opinion qu'on avoit de lui dans tout le pays ?

eng: "When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I suppose, to believe them fond of each other."

"Not the slightest. ~~~ I can remember no symptom of affection on either side; and had any thing of the kind been perceptible, you must be aware that ours is not a family, on which it could be thrown away.
fr: et meme, lorsqu'il a ete decide que Lydie accompagneroit Mistriss Forster, la necessite de lui ouvrir les yeux sur le veritable caractere de Wikam, ne s'est pas presentee a moi ; l'idee qu'il pourroit chercher a la seduire ne m'etoit jamais venue dans la tete.

eng: When first he entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all were.
fr: -- Vous n'aviez, je pense, aucune raison de les croire epris l'un de l'autre, lorsqu'ils sont partis pour Brighton ?

eng: Every girl in, or near Meryton, was out of her senses about him for the first two months; but he never distinguished _her_ by any particular attention, and, consequently, after a moderate period of extravagant and wild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others of the regiment, who treated her with more distinction, again became her favourites."
fr: -- Pas la plus legere ; je ne puis me rappeler aucune marque d'affection ni d'un cote ni de l'autre ; notre famille n'est pas de celles ou l'on n'auroit pas remarque des signes de preference.

eng: * * * * * It may be easily believed, that however little of novelty could be added to their fears, hopes, and conjectures, on this interesting subject, by its repeated discussion, no other could detain them from it long, during the whole of the journey.
fr: Lorsque Wikam arriva dans le pays, Lydie en etoit, comme nous toutes, tres-enchantee : il n'y avoit pas une jeune fille dans Meryton et dans tout le voisinage qui ne fut fort occupee de lui pendant les deux premiers mois.

eng: From Elizabeth's thoughts it was never absent. ~~~ Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self reproach, she could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness.
fr: Mais il ne l'a jamais distinguee, il n'a jamais eu pour elle des attentions particulieres, et apres les premiers momens, son admiration pour lui se calma.

eng: They travelled as expeditiously as possible; and sleeping one night on the road, reached Longbourn by dinner-time the next day.
fr: D'autres officiers du regiment, qui s'occupoient davantage d'elle, devinrent ses favoris.

eng: It was a comfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane could not have been wearied by long expectations.
fr: Les voyageurs cheminoient avec toute la promptitude possible, et, apres avoir couru la nuit entiere, ils arriverent a Longbourn au moment du diner.

eng: The little Gardiners, attracted by the sight of a chaise, were standing on the steps of the house, as they entered the paddock; and when the carriage drove up to the door, the joyful surprise that lighted up their faces, and displayed itself over their whole bodies, in a variety of capers and frisks, was the first pleasing earnest of their welcome.
fr: Lorsqu'ils entrerent dans la cour, les petits Gardiner, attires par le bruit d'une chaise de poste, accoururent sur le pas de la porte, et lorsqu'ils virent la voiture s'arreter, la joie et la surprise brillerent sur leur figure, et se manifesterent par des bonds et des sauts.

eng: "Not yet," replied Jane. ~~~ "But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope every thing will be well."
fr: -- Pas encore, repondit Jane, mais a present que mon cher oncle est arrive, j'espere que tout ira bien.

eng: "Is my father in town?"
fr: -- Mon pere est-il a Londres ?

eng: "Yes, he went on Tuesday as I wrote you word."
fr: -- Oui, il est parti mardi, comme je vous l'ai ecrit.

eng: "And have you heard from him often?"
fr: -- Et avez-vous eu de ses nouvelles ?

eng: "We have heard only once.
fr: -- Nous en avons eu une fois seulement.

eng: He wrote me a few lines on Wednesday, to say that he had arrived in safety, and to give me his directions, which I particularly begged him to do. ~~~ He merely added, that he should not write again, till he had something of importance to mention."
fr: Il m'ecrivit quelques lignes mercredi, pour me dire qu'il etoit arrive en bonne sante, et pour me donner des instructions que je lui avois demandees avant son depart ; il ajoutoit qu'il ne nous ecriroit pas jusqu'a ce qu'il eut quelque chose de nouveau a nous dire.

eng: Mary and Kitty, thank Heaven!
fr: Mary et Kitty sont bien, Dieu merci.

eng: are quite well."
fr: -- Et vous-meme ?

eng: "But you--How are you?" ~~~ cried Elizabeth.
fr: s'ecria Elisabeth, vous avez bien souffert !

eng: "You look pale.
fr: vous etes pale !

eng: How much you must have gone through!" ~~~ Her sister, however, assured her, of her being perfectly well; and their conversation, which had been passing while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were engaged with their children, was now put an end to, by the approach of the whole party.
fr: Sa soeur l'assura cependant qu'elle etoit bien, et cette conversation, qui avoit eu lieu pendant que Mr. ~~~ et Mistriss Gardiner etoient occupes de leurs enfans, fut interrompue par leur approche.

eng: Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, and welcomed and thanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.
fr: Jane s'avanca vers eux, et les remercia de leur promptitude, les larmes aux yeux.

eng: When they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elizabeth had already asked, were of course repeated by the others, and they soon found that Jane had no intelligence to give.
fr: Lorsqu'ils furent tous dans le salon, les questions qu'Elisabeth avoit deja faites furent reiterees par les autres.

eng: The sanguine hope of good, however, which the benevolence of her heart suggested, had not yet deserted her; she still expected that it would all end well, and that every morning would bring some letter, either from Lydia or her father, to explain their proceedings, and perhaps announce the marriage.
fr: Jane leur dit aussi qu'elle n'avoit rien de nouveau a leur apprendre, elle vouloit cependant esperer encore que tout iroit bien ; elle croyoit tous les matins recevoir quelque lettre de son pere ou de Lydie, qui expliqueroit la conduite des fugitifs, et annonceroit peut-etre leur mariage.

eng: I always thought they were very unfit to have the charge of her; but I was over-ruled, as I always am.
fr: J'avois toujours craint de la leur confier, mais l'on n'a pas voulu me croire, et j'ai ete entrainee comme je le suis toujours ! ~~~ Pauvre chere enfant !

eng: Poor dear child!
fr: Et maintenant Mr.

eng: And now here's Mr. Bennet gone away, and I know he will fight Wickham, wherever he meets him, and then he will be killed, and what is to become of us all?
fr: Bennet est parti, je suis sure qu'il se battra avec Wikam partout ou il le rencontrera ; il sera tue, et alors que deviendrons-nous !

eng: The Collinses will turn us out, before he is cold in his grave; and if you are not kind to us, brother, I do not know what we shall do."
fr: Les Collins nous mettront a la porte avant qu'on lui ait rendu les derniers devoirs seulement !

eng: They all exclaimed against such terrific ideas; and Mr. Gardiner, after general assurances of his affection for her and all her family, told her that he meant to be in London the very next day, and would assist Mr. Bennet in every endeavour for recovering Lydia.
fr: Ah, si vous n'avez pas pitie de nous, mon cher frere, je ne sais pas ce que nous deviendrons ! ~~~ Ils se recrierent contre de si tristes idees ; et Mr.

eng: "Do not give way to useless alarm," added he, "though it is right to be prepared for the worst, there is no occasion to look on it as certain.
fr: Gardiner, apres l'avoir assuree de son affection pour toute sa famille, lui dit qu'il avoit l'intention d'aller a Londres des le lendemain, et qu'il uniroit ses efforts a ceux de Mr.

eng: It is not quite a week since they left Brighton.
fr: Bennet pour decouvrir Lydie.

eng: In a few days more, we may gain some news of them, and till we know that they are not married, and have no design of marrying, do not let us give the matter over as lost.
fr: -- Ne vous abandonnez pas a de vaines alarmes, ajouta-t-il, quoiqu'il soit sage d'etre prepare a tout.

Cependant il n'y a pas encore huit jours qu'ils ont quitte Brighton, dans quelques jours nous pourrons avoir de leurs nouvelles ; et jusqu'a ce que nous sachions positivement qu'ils ne sont pas maries et qu'ils ne veulent pas se marier, nous ne devons pas nous desesperer.

eng: As soon as I get to town, I shall go to my brother, and make him come home with me to Gracechurch Street, and then we may consult together as to what is to be done."
fr: Des que j'arriverai a Londres, j'irai chercher mon frere, je l'amenerai chez moi, et nous pourrons nous consulter sur ce que nous aurons a faire.

eng: And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but tell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chuses, to buy them, after they are married.
fr: Quant aux habits de noces, ne leur permettez pas de retarder pour cela ; dites a Lydie qu'elle aura tout l'argent qu'elle voudra pour les acheter apres qu'elle sera mariee.

eng: And, above all things, keep Mr. Bennet from fighting.
fr: Sur toutes choses, empechez Mr.

eng: Tell him what a dreadful state I am in,--that I am frightened out of my wits; and have such tremblings, such flutterings, all over me, such spasms in my side, and pains in my head, and such beatings at heart, that I can get no rest by night nor by day.
fr: Bennet de se battre ; dites-lui dans quel etat je suis ; que je meurs de frayeur ! ~~~ que j'ai tant de tremblements, tant de palpitations, tant de spasmes, tant de douleurs a la tete, tant de serremens de coeur, que je n'ai pas un instant de repos, ni jour ni nuit.

eng: Oh, brother, how kind you are!
fr: mon frere, que vous etes bon !

eng: I know you will contrive it all."
fr: Je suis sure que vous viendrez a bout de tout.

eng: But Mr. Gardiner, though he assured her again of his earnest endeavours in the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to her, as well in her hopes as her fears; and, after talking with her in this manner till dinner was on table, they left her to vent all her feelings on the housekeeper, who attended, in the absence of her daughters.
fr: Mais Mr. ~~~ Gardiner, en renouvelant ses promesses de faire tout ce qu'il pourroit, fut oblige de lui recommander de mettre de la moderation dans ses esperances, comme dans ses craintes ; et, apres etre reste avec elle jusqu'a ce qu'on annoncat le diner, ils la laisserent exprimer ses sentimens a sa femme de charge qui lui tenoit compagnie pendant l'absence de ses filles.

eng: Then, perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying, she added, "Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful lesson; that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable--that one false step involves her in endless ruin--that her reputation is no less brittle than it is beautiful,--and that she cannot be too much guarded in her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex."
fr: S'apercevant ensuite qu'Elisabeth ne lui repondoit rien, elle ajouta : -- tout malheureux qu'est cet evenement pour Lydie, nous devons en tirer cette utile lecon que la perte de la vertu dans le coeur d'une femme, est irreparable ; qu'une fausse demarche, l'entraine a une ruine inevitable ; que sa reputation n'est pas moins fragile que sa beaute ; et qu'elle ne sauroit etre trop reservee vis-a-vis des personnes peu estimables de l'autre sexe.

Elisabeth ecoutoit cette longue declamation avec etonnement ; mais elle etoit trop oppressee, pour pouvoir y repondre, et Marie eut toute liberte de se consoler par des reflexions, des maux qui pesoient sur sa famille.

eng: Elizabeth lifted up her eyes in amazement, but was too much oppressed to make any reply.
fr: Dans l'apres-dine les deux soeurs ainees purent enfin etre seules pendant une demi-heure.

eng: Mary, however, continued to console herself with such kind of moral extractions from the evil before them.
fr: Elisabeth pria Jane de lui raconter les plus petits details de ce triste evenement.

eng: In the afternoon, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to be for half an hour by themselves; and Elizabeth instantly availed herself of the opportunity of making many enquiries, which Jane was equally eager to satisfy.
fr: -- Le colonel Forster dit Jane a avoue qu'il avoit soupconne un peu d'inclination, surtout du cote de Lydie, mais qu'il n'avoit rien vu qui dut lui donner de l'inquietude.

eng: After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel of this event, which Elizabeth considered as all but certain, and Miss Bennet could not assert to be wholly impossible; the former continued the subject, by saying, "But tell me all and every thing about it, which I have not already heard. ~~~ Give me farther particulars.
What did Colonel Forster say?
fr: Je suis si fachee pour lui de tout ceci !

eng: Had they no apprehension of any thing before the elopement took place?
They must have seen them together for ever."
fr: sa conduite a ete si pleine d'attentions pour nous.

eng: "Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality, especially on Lydia's side, but nothing to give him any alarm.
fr: Il est venu nous temoigner l'interet qu'il prenoit a cette affaire, avant d'avoir l'idee qu'ils ne fussent pas alles en Ecosse.

eng: I am so grieved for him.
fr: -- Et Mr.

eng: His behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost.
fr: Denny etoit-il convaincu que Wikam ne l'epouseroit pas ?

eng: He _was_ coming to us, in order to assure us of his concern, before he had any idea of their not being gone to Scotland: when that apprehension first got abroad, it hastened his journey."
"And was Denny convinced that Wickham would not marry?
fr: Avoit-il su d'avance leur dessein de s'enfuir ?

eng: Did he know of their intending to go off?
fr: Le colonel avoit-il vu Mr.

eng: Had Colonel Forster seen Denny himself?"
fr: Denny lui-meme. ~~~ -- Oui, mais lorsqu'il l'a questionne, Mr.

eng: "Yes; but when questioned by _him_ Denny denied knowing any thing of their plan, and would not give his real opinion about it.
fr: Denny a nie d'avoir eu aucune connoissance de leur projet, et n'a pas voulu dire son opinion ; il n'a point repete alors qu'il ne crut pas a Wikam l'intention de se marier.

eng: He did not repeat his persuasion of their not marrying--and from _that_, I am inclined to hope, he might have been misunderstood before."
fr: D'apres cela, j'espere qu'on l'aura peut-etre mal compris en premier lieu.

eng: "But not before they went to Brighton?"
fr: -- Cependant pas avant leur depart pour Brighton ?

eng: "No, I believe not."
fr: -- Je ne le crois pas.

eng: "And did Colonel Forster appear to think ill of Wickham himself?
fr: -- Et le colonel Forster paroissoit-il avoir mauvaise opinion de Wikam ?

eng: Does he know his real character?"
fr: connoissoit-il son veritable caractere ?

eng: "I must confess that he did not speak so well of Wickham as he formerly did. ~~~ He believed him to be imprudent and extravagant.
fr: -- Je dois avouer qu'il ne parloit plus de Wikam avec autant d'estime qu'autrefois, il le croyoit leger et etourdi.

eng: And since this sad affair has taken place, it is said, that he left Meryton greatly in debt; but I hope this may be false."
fr: Depuis cette triste affaire, on a dit qu'il avoit laisse beaucoup de dettes a Meryton, mais j'espere que cela est faux.

eng: "He brought it with him for us to see."
fr: -- Il l'a apporte pour nous le montrer.

eng: Jane then took it from her pocket-book, and gave it to Elizabeth.
fr: Jane le prit alors dans son portefeuille, et le donna a Elisabeth qui lut ce qui suit.

eng: These were the contents: "MY DEAR HARRIET," "You will laugh when you know where I am gone, and I cannot help laughing myself at your surprise to-morrow morning, as soon as I am missed.
fr: << Ma chere Harriet, Vous rirez lorsque vous apprendrez ou je suis allee, et je ne puis m'empecher de rire moi-meme a l'idee de la surprise que vous eprouverez demain matin lorsque vous saurez que je suis partie.

eng: You need not send them word at Longbourn of my going, if you do not like it, for it will make the surprise the greater, when I write to them, and sign my name Lydia Wickham.
fr: Vous n'avez pas besoin d'ecrire mon depart a Longbourn, si cela vous ennuye ; leur surprise sera bien plus grande, lorsque je leur ecrirai, et que je signerai Lydie-Wikam !

eng: What a good joke it will be!
fr: Quelle drole de chose ce sera !

eng: I can hardly write for laughing.
fr: Je ris de si bon coeur, que j'ai bien de la peine a ecrire.

eng: thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!"
fr: >> -- Etourdie !

eng: cried Elizabeth when she had finished it.
fr: etourdie Lydie !

eng: "What a letter is this, to be written at such a moment.
But at least it shews, that _she_ was serious in the object of her journey.
fr: s'ecria Elisabeth, quelle lettre pour avoir ete ecrite dans un pareil moment !

eng: Whatever he might afterwards persuade her to, it was not on her side a _scheme_ of infamy. ~~~ My poor father! ~~~ how he must have felt it!"
fr: Au moins elle etoit bien convaincue qu'elle alloit se marier ; quoi qu'il puisse lui avoir persuade depuis lors, elle ne croyoit pas lorsqu'elle est partie compromettre son honneur.

eng: "I never saw any one so shocked.
fr: Mon pere qu'a-t-il du eprouver ?

eng: He could not speak a word for full ten minutes. ~~~ My mother was taken ill immediately, and the whole house in such confusion!" ~~~ "Oh!
fr: -- Je n'ai jamais vu une si grande consternation ; il ne put prononcer une parole pendant plus de dix minutes ; ma mere se trouva mal, et toute la maison etoit dans la confusion.

eng: Jane," cried Elizabeth, "was there a servant belonging to it, who did not know the whole story before the end of the day?"
fr: -- Et peut-etre, s'ecria Elisabeth, il n'y a pas un des domestiques qui n'ait su toute l'histoire avant la fin du jour ?

eng: "I do not know.--I hope there was.--But to be guarded at such a time, is very difficult. ~~~ My mother was in hysterics, and though I endeavoured to give her every assistance in my power, I am afraid I did not do so much as I might have done!
fr: -- Je ne sais, mais il etoit bien difficile qu'elle restat secrete dans ce moment ; ma mere prit des attaques de nerfs, et quoique je fisse tout ce que je pouvois, je crains de n'avoir pas encore fait tout, ce que j'aurois du.

eng: that I had been with you, you have had every care and anxiety upon yourself alone." ~~~ "Mary and Kitty have been very kind, and would have shared in every fatigue, I am sure, but I did not think it right for either of them. ~~~ Kitty is slight and delicate, and Mary studies so much, that her hours of repose should not be broken in on.
fr: -- Marie et Kitty ont ete tres-aimables, elles auroient bien voulu m'aider, j'en suis sure ; mais je ne trouvois pas que cela convint ni a l'une ni a l'autre ; Kitty est trop maigre et trop delicate, et Marie etudie trop pour qu'on puisse troubler ses heures de repos.

eng: My aunt Philips came to Longbourn on Tuesday, after my father went away; and was so good as to stay till Thursday with me.

She was of great use and comfort to us all, and lady Lucas has been very kind; she walked here on Wednesday morning to condole with us, and offered her services, or any of her daughters, if they could be of use to us."
"She had better have stayed at home," cried Elizabeth; "perhaps she _meant_ well, but, under such a misfortune as this, one cannot see too little of one's neighbours.
fr: Ma tante Phillips est venue a Longbourn, mardi apres le depart de mon pere, et a ete assez bonne pour rester avec moi jusqu'a jeudi.

eng: Assistance is impossible; condolence, insufferable.
Let them triumph over us at a distance, and be satisfied."
fr: Elle nous a bien soulagees.

eng: She then proceeded to enquire into the measures which her father had intended to pursue, while in town, for the recovery of his daughter.
fr: Lady Lucas a aussi montre beaucoup de bonte, elle vint mercredi matin, et nous offrit ses services et ceux de ses filles s'ils pouvoient nous etre utiles.

eng: "He meant, I believe," replied Jane, "to go to Epsom, the place where they last changed horses, see the postilions, and try if any thing could be made out from them.
fr: -- Elle auroit mieux fait de rester chez elle, s'ecria Elisabeth, peut etre avoient-elles de bonnes intentions, mais dans de pareils malheurs, on ne sauroit trop s'eloigner de ses voisins ; ils ne peuvent donner aucune consolation, et leur compassion est insupportable.

eng: His principal object must be, to discover the number of the hackney coach which took them from Clapham.
fr: Ensuite elle s'informa des mesures que son pere comptoit prendre a Londres pour tacher de decouvrir sa fille.

eng: It had come with a fare from London; and as he thought the circumstance of a gentleman and lady's removing from one carriage into another, might be remarked, he meant to make enquiries at Clapham.
fr: Il avoit l'intention d'aller a Epsom, dernier endroit ou ils ont change de chevaux, pour parler aux postillons.

eng: If he could any how discover at what house the coachman had before set down his fare, he determined to make enquiries there, and hoped it might not be impossible to find out the stand and number of the coach.
fr: Son intention etoit aussi de chercher a decouvrir le numero du fiacre qui les a emmenes de Clapham ; il comptoit faire des recherches a Clapham, ou il ne seroit pas impossible qu'il ne decouvrit leurs traces.

eng: I do not know of any other designs that he had formed: but he was in such a hurry to be gone, and his spirits so greatly discomposed, that I had difficulty in finding out even so much as this."
fr: Je ne sais pas quels etoient ses autres projets ; il est parti avec une telle precipitation et il etoit si trouble, que je n'ai pu lui en demander davantage.

eng: CHAPTER VI.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE XIII.

eng: The whole party were in hopes of a letter from Mr. Bennet the next morning, but the post came in without bringing a single line from him.
fr: On esperoit recevoir une lettre de Mr. ~~~ Bennet le lendemain ; mais la poste arriva sans apporter une seule ligne de lui.

eng: They were forced to conclude, that he had no pleasing intelligence to send, but even of _that_ they would have been glad to be certain.
fr: On conclut de son silence qu'il n'avoit point de bonnes nouvelles a donner. ~~~ Mr.

Gardiner avoit attendu l'arrivee du courrier avant de se mettre en route, et voyant qu'il n'apportoit point de lettre, il partit pour Londres ou il etoit bien sur alors d'etre constamment informe de tout ce qui arriveroit.

eng: Mr. Gardiner had waited only for the letters before he set off.
fr: Il promit de faire tout ce qu'il pourroit pour engager Mr.

eng: When he was gone, they were certain at least of receiving constant information of what was going on, and their uncle promised, at parting, to prevail on Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn, as soon as he could, to the great consolation of his sister, who considered it as the only security for her husband's not being killed in a duel.
fr: Bennet a retourner a Longbourn, afin de calmer sa femme qui craignoit toujours, quoiqu'on put lui dire, qu'il ne fut tue en duel.

eng: Mrs. Gardiner and the children were to remain in Hertfordshire a few days longer, as the former thought her presence might be serviceable to her nieces. ~~~ She shared in their attendance on Mrs. Bennet, and was a great comfort to them, in their hours of freedom.
fr: Mistriss Gardiner et ses enfans devoient passer encore quelques jours a Longbourn ; elle partageoit les soins qu'il falloit prodiguer a Mistriss Bennet, et procuroit a ses filles quelque distraction dans les momens de calme.

eng: Elizabeth, though she did not credit above half of what was said, believed enough to make her former assurance of her sister's ruin still more certain; and even Jane, who believed still less of it, became almost hopeless, more especially as the time was now come, when if they had gone to Scotland, which she had never before entirely despaired of, they must in all probability have gained some news of them.
fr: Quoiqu'Elisabeth n'admit pas tout ce qu'on disoit sur son compte, elle en savoit assez pour considerer le deshonneur de sa soeur comme certain ; Jane, a qui il etoit encore bien plus difficile de persuader le mal, commencoit a perdre toute esperance.

eng: Mr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday; on Tuesday, his wife received a letter from him; it told them, that on his arrival, he had immediately found out his brother, and persuaded him to come to Gracechurch street.
fr: En effet s'ils avoient ete en Ecosse, comme elle avoit persiste a le croire, on auroit du en recevoir deja quelques nouvelles. ~~~ Mr.

eng: That Mr. Bennet had been to Epsom and Clapham, before his arrival, but without gaining any satisfactory information; and that he was now determined to enquire at all the principal hotels in town, as Mr. Bennet thought it possible they might have gone to one of them, on their first coming to London, before they procured lodgings.
Mr. Gardiner himself did not expect any success from this measure, but as his brother was eager in it, he meant to assist him in pursuing it.
fr: Gardiner avoit quitte Longbourn le dimanche, et le mardi sa femme recut une lettre de lui qui disoit qu'il avoit trouve Mr.

eng: He added, that Mr. Bennet seemed wholly disinclined at present, to leave London, and promised to write again very soon.
fr: Bennet, et qu'il l'avoit engage a venir demeurer chez lui ; il ajoutoit qu'il avoit ete deja a Epsom et a Clapham sans pouvoir obtenir aucun renseignement, et que maintenant il etoit decide a aller s'informer dans tous les hotels de la ville, pensant que les fugitifs devoient avoir passe quelque tems dans un hotel, avant de s'etre procure un autre logement.

eng: There was also a postscript to this effect.
fr: Il ajoutoit que Mr.

eng: "I have written to Colonel Forster to desire him to find out, if possible, from some of the young man's intimates in the regiment, whether Wickham has any relations or connections, who would be likely to know in what part of the town he has now concealed himself.
If there were any one, that one could apply to, with a probability of gaining such a clue as that, it might be of essential consequence.
fr: Bennet ne paroissoit point dispose a quitter Londres dans ce moment, promettoit d'ecrire bientot et terminoit sa lettre par le Post-scriptum suivant.

eng: At present we have nothing to guide us. ~~~ Colonel Forster will, I dare say, do every thing in his power to satisfy us on this head.
fr: << J'ai ecrit au colonel Forster pour lui demander de chercher a decouvrir, par le moyen de quelques-uns des jeunes gens du regiment qui sont lies avec Wikam, s'il n'a pas des parens ou des amis dans Londres chez lesquels il ait pu aller se cacher.

eng: But, on second thoughts, perhaps Lizzy could tell us, what relations he has now living, better than any other person."
fr: Si nous pouvions avoir des donnees la-dessus, elles nous seroient de la plus grande utilite, car nous n'avons rien pour nous guider.

eng: Elizabeth was at no loss to understand from whence this deference for her authority proceeded; but it was not in her power to give any information of so satisfactory a nature, as the compliment deserved.
fr: Je crois que le colonel Forster fera tout ce qui lui sera possible pour nous obliger ; mais je reflechis que Lizzy pourra peut-etre mieux qu'aucun autre nous donner quelques eclaircissemens la-dessus.

eng: She had never heard of his having had any relations, except a father and mother, both of whom had been dead many years. ~~~ It was possible, however, that some of his companions in the ----shire, might be able to give more information; and, though she was not very sanguine in expecting it, the application was a something to look forward to.
fr: >> Elisabeth vit bien d'ou venoit cette confiance en elle, mais elle ne put pas la justifier ; elle n'avoit jamais entendu dire que Wikam eut eu d'aunes parens que son pere et sa mere qui etoient morts depuis plusieurs annees ; cependant il etoit possible que quelques-uns de ses camarades fussent en etat de donner plus de renseignemens qu'elle.

eng: Every day at Longbourn was now a day of anxiety; but the most anxious part of each was when the post was expected.
fr: Chaque jour etoit a Longbourn un jour d'anxiete, et le moment le plus facheux etoit celui ou l'on attendoit les lettres.

eng: The arrival of letters was the first grand object of every morning's impatience.
fr: Enfin il en arriva une, mais elle etoit pour Mr. ~~~ Bennet et venoit de Mr.

eng: Through letters, whatever of good or bad was to be told, would be communicated, and every succeeding day was expected to bring some news of importance.

But before they heard again from Mr. Gardiner, a letter arrived for their father, from a different quarter, from Mr. Collins; which, as Jane had received directions to open all that came for him in his absence, she accordingly read; and Elizabeth, who knew what curiosities his letters always were, looked over her, and read it likewise.
fr: Collins ; Jane d'apres les ordres qu'elle avoit recus de son pere d'ouvrir tout ce qui arriveroit a son adresse pendant son absence, la lut, et Elisabeth qui se souvenoit combien les lettres de son cousin etoient bizarres, suivoit des yeux par dessus l'epaule de sa soeur.

eng: Be assured, my dear Sir, that Mrs. Collins and myself sincerely sympathise with you, and all your respectable family, in your present distress, which must be of the bitterest kind, because proceeding from a cause which no time can remove.
fr: Soyez persuade, Monsieur et cher parent, que Mistriss Collins et moi simpathisons vivement avec vous et votre respectable famille, et que nous partageons votre douleur actuelle qui doit etre de l'espece la plus amere puisqu'elle vient d'une cause que le tems ne sauroit attenuer.

eng: No arguments shall be wanting on my part, that can alleviate so severe a misfortune; or that may comfort you, under a circumstance that must be of all others most afflicting to a parent's mind.
fr: Je ne saurois trouver aucun argument qui puisse adoucir votre peine, dans une circonstance qui doit etre plus affligeante que toute autre pour le coeur d'un pere.

eng: The death of your daughter would have been a blessing in comparison of this. ~~~ And it is the more to be lamented, because there is reason to suppose, as my dear Charlotte informs me, that this licentiousness of behaviour in your daughter, has proceeded from a faulty degree of indulgence, though, at the same time, for the consolation of yourself and Mrs. Bennet, I am inclined to think that her own disposition must be naturally bad, or she could not be guilty of such an enormity, at so early an age.
fr: La mort de votre fille auroit ete une benediction en comparaison de ceci ; et l'on doit s'affliger d'autant plus, que d'apres ce que me dit ma chere Charlotte, on a des raisons de supposer que cette excessive dissolution de votre fille est due a une indulgence fort mal entendue : mais je puis vous assurer pour votre consolation et celle de Mistriss Bennet, que je suis porte a croire qu'il falloit que ses dispositions naturelles fussent fort mauvaises. ~~~ Car autrement si jeune, elle auroit ete incapable d'une conduite aussi condamnable.

eng: "A gamester!" ~~~ she cried. ~~~ "This is wholly unexpected.
fr: -- Qui auroit pu s'attendre a ce que ce fut un joueur ?

eng: I had not an idea of it."
fr: s'ecria-t-elle. ~~~ Mr.

eng: Mr. Gardiner added in his letter, that they might expect to see their father at home on the following day, which was Saturday.
fr: Gardiner ajoutoit que ses nieces pouvoient esperer de revoir leur pere le lendemain.

eng: she cried.
fr: -- Quoi !

eng: "Sure he will not leave London before he has found them.
fr: s'ecria-t-elle, il revient sans la pauvre Lydie ! ~~~ oh !

eng: Who is to fight Wickham, and make him marry her, if he comes away?"
fr: surement il ne quittera point Londres sans les avoir decouverts !

eng: As Mrs. Gardiner began to wish to be at home, it was settled that she and her children should go to London, at the same time that Mr. Bennet came from it.
The coach, therefore, took them the first stage of their journey, and brought its master back to Longbourn.
fr: Qui pourroit se battre avec Wikam et le forcer a epouser Lydie, s'il revenoit ici ?

eng: Mrs. Gardiner went away in all the perplexity about Elizabeth and her Derbyshire friend, that had attended her from that part of the world.
fr: Mistriss Gardiner desirant cependant retourner chez elle, partit avec ses enfans dans la voiture qui avoit ramene Mr.

eng: His name had never been voluntarily mentioned before them by her niece; and the kind of half-expectation which Mrs. Gardiner had formed, of their being followed by a letter from him, had ended in nothing.
fr: Bennet, emportant avec elle le vif desir de connoitre les rapports qui existoient entre Elisabeth et Mr. ~~~ Darcy.

eng: Elizabeth had received none since her return, that could come from Pemberley.
fr: Celle-ci n'avoit jamais prononce son nom depuis son retour du Derbyshire.

eng: The present unhappy state of the family, rendered any other excuse for the lowness of her spirits unnecessary; nothing, therefore, could be fairly conjectured from _that_, though Elizabeth, who was by this time tolerably well acquainted with her own feelings, was perfectly aware, that, had she known nothing of Darcy, she could have borne the dread of Lydia's infamy somewhat better.
It would have spared her, she thought, one sleepless night out of two.
fr: Elle paroissoit accablee, mais la fuite de Lydie etoit bien suffisante pour motiver sa tristesse.

eng: When Mr. Bennet arrived, he had all the appearance of his usual philosophic composure.
fr: Mr. ~~~ Bennet arriva avec son air calme et philosophe ; il parloit aussi peu que jamais, il ne dit pas un mot de l'evenement qui l'avoit fait partir, et qui occupoit uniquement toute sa famille.

eng: He said as little as he had ever been in the habit of saying; made no mention of the business that had taken him away, and it was some time before his daughters had courage to speak of it.
fr: Ce ne fut que dans l'apres-dine, lorsqu'il revint aupres de ses enfans pour prendre le the, qu'Elisabeth osa enfin entamer ce sujet.

eng: It was not till the afternoon, when he joined them at tea, that Elizabeth ventured to introduce the subject; and then, on her briefly expressing her sorrow for what he must have endured, he replied, "Say nothing of that.
fr: Elle lui exprima brievement le chagrin qu'elle avoit eprouve de ce qu'il avoit eu a souffrir.

eng: Who should suffer but myself?
fr: -- Ne parlez pas de cela, lui repondit-il.

eng: It has been my own doing, and I ought to feel it."
fr: Qui doit souffrir si ce n'est moi ?

eng: "You must not be too severe upon yourself," replied Elizabeth.
fr: J'ai fait le mal, je dois le supporter sans me plaindre.

eng: "You may well warn me against such an evil.
fr: -- Ne soyez pas si severe envers vous-meme, mon pere.

eng: Human nature is so prone to fall into it!
fr: -- Il est si rare que la nature humaine avoue ses erreurs !

eng: No, Lizzy, let me once in my life feel how much I have been to blame.
fr: Lizzy ! ~~~ Laissez-moi une fois dans ma vie reconnoitre combien j'ai ete blamable ; ne craignez pas que ce sentiment soit trop accablant, l'impression s'en evanouira peut-etre bien vite.

eng: I am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression.
fr: -- Croyez-vous, Monsieur, que les fugitifs soient a Londres ?

eng: It will pass away soon enough."
fr: -- Je le crois.

eng: "Do you suppose them to be in London?"
fr: Ou pourroient-ils etre si bien caches ?

eng: "Yes; where else can they be so well concealed?"
fr: -- Et Lydie qui avoit toujours tant desire aller a Londres !

eng: "And Lydia used to want to go to London," added Kitty.
fr: dit Kitty.

eng: "She is happy, then," said her father, drily; "and her residence there will probably be of some duration."
fr: -- Elle est donc contente a present, reprit son pere sechement, le sejour qu'elle y fera sera peut-etre long.

eng: Then, after a short silence, he continued, "Lizzy, I bear you no ill-will for being justified in your advice to me last May, which, considering the event, shews some greatness of mind."
fr: Apres quelques instans de silence, il reprit : -- Lizzy, ne croyez pas que je vous en veuille pour avoir montre plus de jugement que moi dans l'avis que vous m'avez donne au mois de Mai, et que je n'ai pas suivi.

eng: They were interrupted by Miss Bennet, who came to fetch her mother's tea.
fr: Ils furent interrompus par Jane, qui venoit chercher du the pour sa mere.

eng: "This is a parade," cried he, "which does one good; it gives such an elegance to misfortune!
fr: -- Ce que c'est que l'ostentation ! ~~~ s'ecria-t-il, elle donne de l'elegance au malheur !

eng: Another day I will do the same; I will sit in my library, in my night cap and powdering gown, and give as much trouble as I can,--or, perhaps, I may defer it, till Kitty runs away."
fr: Je suis bien tente d'aller m'etablir dans ma bibliotheque avec ma robe de chambre et mon bonnet, je m'affligerai la plus commodement.

eng: "I am not going to run away, Papa," said Kitty, fretfully; "if _I_ should ever go to Brighton, I would behave better than Lydia."
fr: Mais, non, pas encore, j'attendrai que Kitty s'enfuie.

eng: "_You_ go to Brighton!--I would not trust you so near it as East Bourne for fifty pounds!
fr: -- Je ne veux point m'enfuir, s'ecria Kitty avec humeur !

eng: No, Kitty, I have at last learnt to be cautious, and you will feel the effects of it.
fr: Si je vais jamais a Brighton, je me conduirai bien differemment que Lydie. ~~~ -- Vous a Brighton !

eng: No officer is ever to enter my house again, nor even to pass through the village.
fr: Je n'oserois pas seulement vous envoyer a la distance de Lasbourn, quand on me donneroit cinquante guinees !

eng: Balls will be absolutely prohibited, unless you stand up with one of your sisters.
fr: Non, Kitty, j'ai enfin appris a etre prudent et vous en verrez les effets ; desormais aucun officier n'entrera dans ma maison, ni meme ne traversera le village.

eng: And you are never to stir out of doors, till you can prove, that you have spent ten minutes of every day in a rational manner."
fr: Les bals vous seront absolument defendus, a moins qu'une de vos soeurs ainees veuille bien vous y accompagner ; et vous ne passerez plus le seuil de la porte que vous n'ayez ete occupee raisonnablement au moins dix minutes par jour.

eng: "Well, well," said he, "do not make yourself unhappy. ~~~ If you are a good girl for the next ten years, I will take you to a review at the end of them."
fr: -- Allons, allons, dit-il, ne vous affligez pas trop ; si vous etes une bonne fille, dans dix ans je vous menerai a une revue. ~~~ fin du troisieme volume.

eng: CHAPTER VII.
fr: CHAPITRE PREMIER.

eng: Two days after Mr. Bennet's return, as Jane and Elizabeth were walking together in the shrubbery behind the house, they saw the housekeeper coming towards them, and, concluding that she came to call them to their mother, went forward to meet her; but, instead of the expected summons, when they approached her, she said to Miss Bennet, "I beg your pardon, madam, for interrupting you, but I was in hopes you might have got some good news from town, so I took the liberty of coming to ask."
fr: Deux jours apres le retour de leur pere, Jane et Elisabeth se promenant dans le verger, derriere la maison, virent venir a elles la femme de charge de leur mere. ~~~ -- Je vous demande pardon, Madame, dit-elle a Jane, mais je croyois que vous aviez recu quelques bonnes nouvelles de la ville, et j'ai pris la liberte de venir vous le demander.

eng: "What do you mean, Hill? ~~~ We have heard nothing from town."
fr: -- Vous vous trompez, Hill, nous n'avons point recu de nouvelles de la ville.

eng: "Dear madam," cried Mrs. Hill, in great astonishment, "don't you know there is an express come for master from Mr. Gardiner?
fr: -- Chere Madame, s'ecria Mistriss Hill extremement surprise : ne savez-vous pas qu'il est arrive un expres de Mr.

eng: He has been here this half hour, and master has had a letter."
fr: Gardiner pour mon maitre ?

eng: Away ran the girls, too eager to get in to have time for speech. ~~~ They ran through the vestibule into the breakfast room; from thence to the library;--their father was in neither; and they were on the point of seeking him up stairs with their mother, when they were met by the butler, who said, "If you are looking for my master, ma'am, he is walking towards the little copse."
fr: Les deux soeurs, trop pressees de savoir ce que c'etoit, ne lui en demanderent pas davantage, et se mirent a courir vers la maison, traverserent le vestibule, entrerent dans la salle a manger, puis dans la bibliotheque ; mais leur pere n'etoit nulle part ; elles alloient le chercher dans l'appartement de Mistriss Bennet, lorsqu'elles rencontrerent le sommelier, qui leur dit : -- Si ces dames cherchent mon maitre, elles le trouveront pres du petit bois ou il se promene.

eng: Upon this information, they instantly passed through the hall once more, and ran across the lawn after their father, who was deliberately pursuing his way towards a small wood on one side of the paddock.
fr: Sur cet avis elles sortirent de la maison, et coururent vers le petit bois.

eng: Jane, who was not so light, nor so much in the habit of running as Elizabeth, soon lagged behind, while her sister, panting for breath, came up with him, and eagerly cried out, "Oh, Papa, what news?
fr: Jane n'etoit pas si leste qu'Elisabeth, qui arriva toute essoufflee aupres de son pere, en s'ecriant : -- Ah, mon pere !

eng: what news? ~~~ have you heard from my uncle?"
fr: quelles nouvelles avez-vous recues de mon oncle ?

eng: "Yes, I have had a letter from him by express."
fr: -- J'ai recu une lettre de lui par un expres.

eng: "Well, and what news does it bring?
fr: -- Quelles nouvelles donne-t-elle ?

eng: said he, taking the letter from his pocket; "but perhaps you would like to read it."
fr: dit-il en sortant la lettre de sa poche ; peut-etre desirez-vous la lire ?

eng: Elizabeth impatiently caught it from his hand.
fr: Elisabeth la saisit avec vivacite ; Jane, qui etoit restee un peu en arriere, arriva alors.

eng: Jane now came up.
fr: -- Lisez la haut, leur dit Mr.

eng: "Read it aloud," said their father, "for I hardly know myself what it is about."
fr: Bennet, car je sais a peine moi-meme ce qu'elle contient.

eng: Soon after you left me on Saturday, I was fortunate enough to find out in what part of London they were. ~~~ The particulars, I reserve till we meet.
fr: Samedi, peu de temps apres que vous m'eutes quitte, je fus assez heureux pour decouvrir le lieu ou se cachoient nos fugitifs.

eng: It is enough to know they are discovered, I have seen them both----" "Then it is, as I always hoped," cried Jane; "they are married!"
fr: Je reserverai les details pour le moment ou nous nous reverrons ; il suffit maintenant que vous sachiez que je les ai decouverts ; je les ai vus tous les deux.

eng: Elizabeth read on; "I have seen them both.
fr: >> -- C'est donc comme je l'avois toujours assure ?

eng: They are not married, nor can I find there was any intention of being so; but if you are willing to perform the engagements which I have ventured to make on your side, I hope it will not be long before they are.
fr: s'ecria Jane, ils sont maries. ~~~ Elisabeth poursuivit sa lecture : << Je les ai vus tous les deux, ils ne sont pas maries, et meme il ne m'a pas paru qu'ils eussent l'intention de s'unir.

eng: All that is required of you is, to assure to your daughter, by settlement, her equal share of the five thousand pounds, secured among your children after the decease of yourself and my sister; and, moreover, to enter into an engagement of allowing her, during your life, one hundred pounds per annum.
fr: Mais si vous voulez remplir les engagemens que je me suis hasarde a prendre pour vous, j'espere qu'il ne se passera pas long-temps avant qu'ils le soient.

eng: These are conditions, which, considering every thing, I had no hesitation in complying with, as far as I thought myself privileged, for you.
fr: On vous demande d'assurer a Lydie, par contrat, sa part des cinq mille livres qui doivent revenir a vos enfans apres votre mort et celle de leur mere ; et, en outre, de prendre l'engagement de lui donner pendant votre vie une rente de cent guinees par an : voila les conditions auxquelles, apres avoir tout considere, je n'ai pas hesite d'acquiescer, d'apres les pouvoirs que vous m'avez accordes.

eng: I shall send this by express, that no time may be lost in bringing me your answer.
fr: Je vous envoie ceci par un expres, afin qu'il n'y ait pas de temps perdu pour recevoir votre reponse.

eng: You will easily comprehend, from these particulars, that Mr. Wickham's circumstances are not so hopeless as they are generally believed to be.
fr: Vous comprendrez facilement, par ces arrangemens, que Mr.

eng: The world has been deceived in that respect; and I am happy to say, there will be some little money, even when all his debts are discharged, to settle on my niece, in addition to her own fortune.
fr: Wikam ne se trouve pas dans une position aussi desesperee qu'on le croyoit generalement ; et je me trouve heureux de pouvoir ajouter, que lorsque toutes ses dettes seront payees, il restera encore quelque argent qu'on pourra reconnoitre a Lydie, outre sa propre fortune.

eng: If, as I conclude will be the case, you send me full powers to act in your name, throughout the whole of this business, I will immediately give directions to Haggerston for preparing a proper settlement. ~~~ There will not be the smallest occasion for your coming to town again; therefore, stay quietly at Longbourn, and depend on my diligence and care.
fr: Si, comme je l'espere, vous m'autorisez a terminer cette affaire en votre nom, je donnerai de suite a Haggerston les ordres pour dresser le contrat ; vous n'aurez point besoin de revenir a la ville pour cela ; restez paisiblement a Longbourn, et comptez sur ma diligence et sur tous mes soins.

eng: Send back your answer as soon as you can, and be careful to write explicitly.
fr: Repondez-moi le plutot que vous pourrez, et expliquez-vous clairement.

eng: We have judged it best, that my niece should be married from this house, of which I hope you will approve. ~~~ She comes to us to-day.
fr: Nous avons juge plus convenable que votre fille sortit de notre maison pour aller se marier ; elle doit venir aujourd'hui demeurer avec nous ; j'espere que vous approuverez cette mesure.

eng: I shall write again as soon as any thing more is determined on.
fr: Je vous ecrirai aussitot que la chose sera terminee.

eng: Your's, &c." "EDW. ~~~ GARDINER."
fr: >> Votre, etc. etc. >> Edward Gardiner.

eng: "Is it possible!"
fr: >> -- Est-il possible !

eng: cried Elizabeth, when she had finished. ~~~ "Can it be possible that he will marry her?"
fr: s'ecria Elisabeth lorsqu'elle eut fini la lettre, est-il possible qu'il l'epouse ?

eng: "Wickham is not so undeserving, then, as we have thought him;" said her sister. ~~~ "My dear father, I congratulate you."
fr: -- Wikam n'est cependant pas aussi corrompu qu'on nous le representoit, dit Jane avec joie ; mon cher pere, je vous felicite de ces nouvelles !

eng: "And have you answered the letter?"
fr: -- Avez-vous repondu a cette lettre ?

eng: "No; but it must be done soon."
fr: -- Non, mais ce sera bientot fait.

eng: Most earnestly did she then intreat him to lose no more time before he wrote.
fr: Elle l'engagea avec instance a ne pas perdre un instant.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: my dear father," she cried, "come back, and write immediately. ~~~ Consider how important every moment is, in such a case."
fr: mon cher pere, s'ecria-t-elle, retournons a la maison, et ecrivez tout de suite ; considerez combien le temps est precieux.

eng: "Let me write for you," said Jane, "if you dislike the trouble yourself."
fr: -- Permettez-moi d'ecrire a votre place, dit Jane, c'est une peine pour vous.

eng: And so saying, he turned back with them, and walked towards the house.
