fr: -- C'est le plus joli garcon que j'aie jamais vu, dit Mr. ~~~ Bennet des qu'il fut parti.

eng: He simpers, and smirks, and makes love to us all.
fr: Il sourit, badine, nous caresse tous !

eng: I am prodigiously proud of him.
fr: Je suis extremement fier de lui !

eng: The loss of her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very dull for several days.
fr: Le depart de Lydie rendit Mistriss Bennet tres-triste pendant plusieurs jours.

eng: "I often think," said she, "that there is nothing so bad as parting with one's friends.
fr: -- Je pense souvent, disoit-elle, qu'il n'y a rien de plus triste que les separations.

eng: One seems so forlorn without them." ~~~ "This is the consequence you see, Madam, of marrying a daughter," said Elizabeth.
fr: -- C'est une consequence naturelle ; du plaisir de marier ses filles, Madame, lui repondit Elisabeth, et cela doit vous consoler d'en avoir quatre celibataires.

eng: "It must make you better satisfied that your other four are single." ~~~ "It is no such thing.
fr: -- Ce n'est point cela ; Lydie ne m'a point quittee parce qu'elle est mariee, mais parce que le regiment de son mari se trouve eloigne de nous ; elle ne seroit point partie s'il avoit ete pres d'ici.

eng: Lydia does not leave me because she is married; but only because her husband's regiment happens to be so far off. ~~~ If that had been nearer, she would not have gone so soon."
fr: Mais l'espece de decouragement, dans lequel l'avoit jete cet evenement fut tres-vite passe, et son coeur se r'ouvrit a l'esperance.

eng: But the spiritless condition which this event threw her into, was shortly relieved, and her mind opened again to the agitation of hope, by an article of news, which then began to be in circulation.
fr: La nouvelle circuloit, que le concierge de Netherfield avoit recu l'ordre de tout preparer pour le retour de son maitre, qui devoit arriver sous peu pour profiter de la saison de la chasse.

eng: The housekeeper at Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of her master, who was coming down in a day or two, to shoot there for several weeks.
fr: Mistriss Bennet, etoit dans une agitation extreme, elle regardoit Jane qui sourioit et secouoit la tete.

eng: Mrs. Bennet was quite in the fidgets.
fr: -- Eh bien donc, Mr.

eng: She looked at Jane, and smiled, and shook her head by turns.
fr: Bingley va arriver, ma soeur !

eng: "Well, well, and so Mr. Bingley is coming down, sister," (for Mrs. Philips first brought her the news.)
fr: (car Mistriss Phillips avoit ete la premiere a lui apporter ces bonnes nouvelles).

eng: And so, is it quite certain he is coming?"
fr: Vous croyez donc qu'il est bien sur qu'il va arriver ?

eng: "You may depend on it," replied the other, "for Mrs. Nicholls was in Meryton last night; I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose to know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certain true. ~~~ He comes down on Thursday at the latest, very likely on Wednesday. ~~~ She was going to the butcher's, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks, just fit to be killed."
fr: -- Vous pouvez compter la dessus, repliqua Mistriss Phillips, car Mistriss Nicholls etoit hier au soir a Meryton ; je la vis passer et je sortis dans l'intention d'aller moi-meme lui demander ce qui en etoit ; elle me confirma la nouvelle, et me dit qu'il arriveroit lundi au plus tard et tres-probablement mercredi ; elle me dit aussi qu'elle etoit venue faire de grandes emplettes, et qu'elle avoit achete trois paires de canards tous prets a etre tues.

eng: Miss Bennet had not been able to hear of his coming, without changing colour.
fr: Miss Bennet n'avoit pu apprendre la nouvelle du retour de Mr.

eng: It was many months since she had mentioned his name to Elizabeth; but now, as soon as they were alone together, she said, "I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present report; and I know I appeared distressed.
But don't imagine it was from any silly cause.
fr: Bingley a Netherfield, sans emotion.

eng: I was only confused for the moment, because I felt that I _should_ be looked at.
I do assure you, that the news does not affect me either with pleasure or pain.
I am glad of one thing, that he comes alone; because we shall see the less of him.
Not that I am afraid of _myself_, but I dread other people's remarks." ~~~ Elizabeth did not know what to make of it.
fr: Il y avoit bien des mois qu'elle n'avoit pas prononce son nom a Elisabeth, cependant des qu'elles furent seules elle lui dit.

eng: Had she not seen him in Derbyshire, she might have supposed him capable of coming there, with no other view than what was acknowledged; but she still thought him partial to Jane, and she wavered as to the greater probability of his coming there _with_ his friend's permission, or being bold enough to come without it.
fr: -- Lizzy, j'ai vu que vous me regardiez pendant que ma tante repetoit le bruit qui court, et je crains d'avoir eu l'air un peu trouble ; mais ne croyez cependant pas que cette nouvelle me cause ni peine ni plaisir ; j'ai rougi dans ce moment parce que j'ai vu qu'on me regardoit.

eng: "Yet it is hard," she sometimes thought, "that this poor man cannot come to a house, which he has legally hired, without raising all this speculation!
fr: Je suis bien aise qu'il vienne seul, parce qu'alors nous le verrons beaucoup moins ; ce n'est pas que je me craigne moi-meme, mais je redoute les observations des autres.

eng: I _will_ leave him to himself."
fr: Elisabeth ne savoit que penser ; si elle n'avoit pas vu Mr.

eng: In spite of what her sister declared, and really believed to be her feelings, in the expectation of his arrival, Elizabeth could easily perceive that her spirits were affected by it.
fr: Bingley pendant qu'elle etoit a Lambton, elle auroit pu croire comme les autres, qu'il ne venoit a Netherfield que pour jouir du plaisir de la chasse ; mais il lui avoit paru encore fort attache a Jane ; elle flottoit, entre l'idee qu'il venoit avec la permission de Mr.

eng: They were more disturbed, more unequal, than she had often seen them.
fr: Darcy, et celle que peut-etre il etoit assez hardi pour ne pas l'avoir demandee.

eng: The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents, about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.
fr: -- Il est cependant cruel, pensoit-elle quelquefois, que ce pauvre homme ne puisse venir chez lui, sans le consentement de ses amis ou de ses soeurs.

eng: "As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear," said Mrs. Bennet, "you will wait on him of course."

"No, no. ~~~ You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised if I went to see him, he should marry one of my daughters. ~~~ But it ended in nothing, and I will not be sent on a fool's errand again."
fr: Malgre les protestations de Jane, Elisabeth voyoit bien qu'elle n'etoit pas aussi indifferente qu'elle vouloit le paroitre : elle etoit plus distraite, et son humeur etoit moins egale qu'a l'ordinaire.

eng: His wife represented to him how absolutely necessary such an attention would be from all the neighbouring gentlemen, on his returning to Netherfield.
fr: Alors le sujet qui avoit ete si vivement debattu, un an auparavant entre leurs parens, fut de nouveau remis sur le tapis.

eng: "'Tis an etiquette I despise," said he.
fr: -- Vous irez surement voir Mr.

eng: "If he wants our society, let him seek it. ~~~ He knows where we live.
fr: Bingley aussitot qu'il sera arrive, disoit Mistriss Bennet.

eng: I will not spend _my_ hours in running after my neighbours every time they go away, and come back again."
fr: -- Non certainement, vous m'avez force a y aller l'annee derniere en me promettant que si j'y allois il epouseroit une de mes filles ; il ne l'a pas fait, et cette annee, je n'irai surement pas.

eng: "Well, all I know is, that it will be abominably rude if you do not wait on him.
fr: Sa femme lui representa que cette visite a Netherfield etoit absolument de rigueur.

-- C'est une etiquette que je meprise, repondit-il, s'il a besoin de notre societe, il n'a qu'a venir vous voir ; il sait ou nous demeurons, je ne veux pas perdre mon tems a courir apres mes voisins, chaque fois qu'ils vont et qu'ils viennent.

eng: But, however, that shan't prevent my asking him to dine here, I am determined.
fr: -- Eh bien, ce sera horriblement malhonnete si vous n'y allez pas.

eng: We must have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings soon.
fr: Mais cela ne m'empechera pas de l'inviter a diner, j'y suis tres-decidee.

eng: That will make thirteen with ourselves, so there will be just room at table for him."
fr: Nous aurons bientot Miss Long et les Goulding, cela fera treize en nous comptant ; il y aura justement place pour lui a table.

eng: Consoled by this resolution, she was the better able to bear her husband's incivility; though it was very mortifying to know that her neighbours might all see Mr. Bingley in consequence of it, before _they_ did.
fr: Cette resolution lui fit mieux prendre son parti de l'impolitesse de son mari ; quoiqu'il fut tres-mortifiant de penser, que tous leurs voisins iroient faire visite a Mr.

eng: As the day of his arrival drew near, "I begin to be sorry that he comes at all," said Jane to her sister.
fr: Bingley et qu'elles seroient les dernieres a le voir. ~~~ Le jour de son arrivee approchoit.

eng: "It would be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference, but I can hardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of. ~~~ My mother means well; but she does not know, no one can know how much I suffer from what she says.
fr: Jane dit a sa soeur : -- Je suis tres-fachee qu'il revienne, je pourrois bien le voir avec une indifference parfaite, mais je ne puis supporter d'en entendre parler sans cesse ; ma mere ne sait pas le mal qu'elle me fait !

eng: "I wish I could say any thing to comfort you," replied Elizabeth; "but it is wholly out of my power. ~~~ You must feel it; and the usual satisfaction of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied me, because you have always so much."
fr: -- Je voudrois vous dire quelque chose qui put vous donner du courage, dit Elisabeth, mais cela m'est impossible, et je ne saurois pas meme vous precher la patience ; vous en avez toujours tant !

eng: Mr. Bingley arrived.
fr: Mr.

eng: Mrs. Bennet, through the assistance of servants, contrived to have the earliest tidings of it, that the period of anxiety and fretfulness on her side, might be as long as it could.
fr: Bingley arriva, et Mistriss Bennet chercha a en avoir des nouvelles par tous ceux qui pouvoient l'avoir vu, elle comptoit deja les jours qui devoient s'ecouler avant qu'elle put decemment lui envoyer une invitation, car elle n'esperoit point le voir avant ce moment-la.

eng: She counted the days that must intervene before their invitation could be sent; hopeless of seeing him before.
fr: Quelle ne fut pas sa surprise lorsque le troisieme jour elle le vit depuis sa fenetre entrer dans l'avenue au galop.

eng: But on the third morning after his arrival in Hertfordshire, she saw him from her dressing-room window, enter the paddock, and ride towards the house.
fr: Elle appela ses filles avec transport pour leur faire partager sa joie.

eng: Her daughters were eagerly called to partake of her joy.
fr: Jane ne voulut decidement pas quitter sa place.

eng: Jane resolutely kept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went to the window--she looked,--she saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down again by her sister.
fr: Elisabeth pour satisfaire sa mere courut a la fenetre, mais voyant Mr. ~~~ Darcy avec lui, elle se rassit a cote de sa soeur.

eng: "Some acquaintance or other, my dear, I suppose; I am sure I do not know."
fr: -- Quelqu'une de ses connoissances, je suppose.

eng: "La!"
fr: Je ne le connois pas.

eng: replied Kitty, "it looks just like that man that used to be with him before.
fr: -- Ah, reprit Kitty, il ressemble beaucoup a ce Monsieur qui etoit toujours avec lui l'annee derniere ; quel est son nom !

eng: Mr. what's his name. ~~~ That tall, proud man."
fr: ce Monsieur... qui est si grand et si fier ?

eng: Mr.
fr: Mr.

eng: Darcy!--and so it does I vow.
fr: Darcy ? ~~~ Ce sera lui je parie !

eng: Well, any friend of Mr. Bingley's will always be welcome here to be sure; but else I must say that I hate the very sight of him."
fr: Enfin, tous les amis de Mr.

eng: Jane looked at Elizabeth with surprise and concern.
fr: Bingley seront bien recus ici.

eng: She knew but little of their meeting in Derbyshire, and therefore felt for the awkwardness which must attend her sister, in seeing him almost for the first time after receiving his explanatory letter.
fr: Jane regarda Elisabeth avec surprise et inquietude, n'etant pas instruite de leur rencontre dans le Derbyshire, elle sentoit l'embarras que devoit eprouver sa soeur, en le revoyant pour la premiere fois depuis le moment ou il lui avoit remis la lettre qui contenoit sa justification.
Les deux soeurs, etoient confuses, chacune sentoit sa propre situation et celle de sa soeur.

eng: Both sisters were uncomfortable enough.
fr: Leur mere continuoit a parler de son aversion pour Mr.

eng: Each felt for the other, and of course for themselves; and their mother talked on, of her dislike of Mr. Darcy, and her resolution to be civil to him only as Mr. Bingley's friend, without being heard by either of them.
fr: Darcy, et de ce qu'elle ne vouloit etre polie avec lui que parce qu'il etoit un des amis de Mr. ~~~ Bingley.

eng: But Elizabeth had sources of uneasiness which could not be suspected by Jane, to whom she had never yet had courage to shew Mrs. Gardiner's letter, or to relate her own change of sentiment towards him.
fr: Mr.

eng: To Jane, he could be only a man whose proposals she had refused, and whose merit she had undervalued; but to her own more extensive information, he was the person, to whom the whole family were indebted for the first of benefits, and whom she regarded herself with an interest, if not quite so tender, at least as reasonable and just, as what Jane felt for Bingley.
fr: Darcy n'etoit encore aux yeux de Jane, qu'un homme dont sa soeur avoit refuse la main, et n'avoit pas apprecie le merite ; tandis que pour Elisabeth c'etoit un homme auquel sa famille devoit le premier des bienfaits, l'honneur de Lydie ; et pour lequel, elle avoit un sentiment de reconnoissance et d'estime qui ressembloit bien a de l'amour.

eng: The colour which had been driven from her face, returned for half a minute with an additional glow, and a smile of delight added lustre to her eyes, as she thought for that space of time, that his affection and wishes must still be unshaken.
fr: La paleur qui avoit couvert sa figure au premier moment, fit place au plus bel incarnat, et un sourire de satisfaction donna encore plus d'eclat a ses yeux, lorsqu'elle pensa que peut-etre la tendresse de Mr.

eng: But she would not be secure. ~~~ "Let me first see how he behaves," said she; "it will then be early enough for expectation."
fr: Darcy n'auroit point ete diminuee par le laps du tems, et par tous les evenemens qui s'etoient passes depuis qu'elle ne l'avoit vu.

eng: She sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to lift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of her sister, as the servant was approaching the door.
fr: Elle s'efforcoit de paroitre calme, et osoit a peine lever les yeux ; une inquiete curiosite les lui fit cependant tourner vers sa soeur, au moment ou le domestique ouvrit la porte.

eng: Jane looked a little paler than usual, but more sedate than Elizabeth had expected.
fr: Jane etoit un peu plus pale qu'a l'ordinaire, mais plus tranquille qu'Elisabeth ne s'y etoit attendue.
Lorsque ces Messieurs entrerent, elle rougit un peu, elle les recut cependant sans embarras, et son abord n'etoit ni trop reserve ni trop prevenant.

eng: On the gentlemen's appearing, her colour increased; yet she received them with tolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any symptom of resentment, or any unnecessary complaisance.
fr: Elisabeth etoit moins a son aise, elle parla aussi peu a l'un et a l'autre que la plus stricte politesse pouvoit le lui permettre ; elle s'etoit remise a son ouvrage avec une assiduite qui ne lui etoit point ordinaire ; elle n'avoit ose jeter qu'un regard a la derobee sur Mr.

Darcy ; il avoit l'air serieux, et elle pensoit qu'il ressembloit davantage a ce qu'il s'etoit montre dans le Hertfordshire qu'a ce qu'il etoit a Pemberley ; peut-etre ne pouvoit-il pas etre en presence de sa mere ce qu'il etoit avec son oncle et sa tante, c'etoit une conjecture penible, mais qui n'etoit pas denuee de probabilite.

eng: Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down again to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command.
fr: Bingley avoit l'air content, quoique un peu embarrasse ; Mistriss Bennet le recut avec un tel exces de politesse, que ses deux filles en rougirent, et cet accueil ressortit encore plus, par le contraste de la froide reverence qu'elle fit a Mr.

eng: She had ventured only one glance at Darcy.
fr: Darcy.

eng: He looked serious as usual; and she thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as she had seen him at Pemberley.
But, perhaps he could not in her mother's presence be what he was before her uncle and aunt.
fr: Une distinction si mal appliquee, choqua et affligea extremement Elisabeth.

eng: It was a painful, but not an improbable, conjecture.
fr: Darcy apres lui avoir demande des nouvelles de Mr.

eng: Bingley, she had likewise seen for an instant, and in that short period saw him looking both pleased and embarrassed.

He was received by Mrs. Bennet with a degree of civility, which made her two daughters ashamed, especially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of her curtsey and address to his friend.

Elizabeth particularly, who knew that her mother owed to the latter the preservation of her favourite daughter from irremediable infamy, was hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill applied.
fr: et de Mistriss Gardiner, question a laquelle elle ne put repondre sans un leger embarras, parla fort peu ; il n'etoit pas assis aupres d'elle, peut-etre etoit-ce la la cause de son silence ; mais helas, il n'en etoit pas ainsi en Derbyshire !

eng: Darcy, after enquiring of her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner did, a question which she could not answer without confusion, said scarcely any thing.
He was not seated by her; perhaps that was the reason of his silence; but it had not been so in Derbyshire.
There he had talked to her friends, when he could not to herself.
fr: au moins il parloit a ses amis quand il ne pouvoit l'entretenir elle-meme.

eng: But now several minutes elapsed, without bringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist the impulse of curiosity, she raised her eyes to his face, she as often found him looking at Jane, as at herself, and frequently on no object but the ground.
fr: Elle voyoit clairement qu'il etoit plus pensif et qu'il avoit moins de desir de plaire que la derniere fois qu'ils s'etoient vus ; elle en etoit tres-affligee, et s'en vouloit a elle-meme d'eprouver ce sentiment.

eng: More thoughtfulness, and less anxiety to please than when they last met, were plainly expressed.
fr: Pouvois-je m'attendre a ce qu'il se conduisit autrement, pensoit-elle, mais alors pourquoi est-il venu ?

eng: She was disappointed, and angry with herself for being so. ~~~ "Could I expect it to be otherwise!" ~~~ said she.
fr: Elle auroit voulu lui parler, lui demander des nouvelles de sa soeur, mais elle n'en avoit pas la force.

eng: "Yet why did he come?"
fr: -- Il y a long-temps, Mr.

eng: She was in no humour for conversation with any one but himself; and to him she had hardly courage to speak.
fr: Bingley, que vous avez quitte ce pays, dit Mistriss Bennet.

eng: She enquired after his sister, but could do no more.
fr: Il en tomba d'accord tout de suite.

eng: "It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away," said Mrs. Bennet.
fr: -- Je commencois a craindre que vous ne revinssiez plus, ajouta-t-elle ; on disoit meme que vous rendiez la maison a Noel ?

eng: He readily agreed to it.
fr: mais j'espere que cela n'est pas.

eng: "I began to be afraid you would never come back again. ~~~ People _did_ say, you meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope it is not true. ~~~ A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood, since you went away. ~~~ Miss Lucas is married and settled.
fr: Il y a beaucoup de changement dans la societe, depuis que vous avez quitte Netherfield ; Miss Lucas s'est mariee ainsi qu'une de mes filles ; je suppose que vous devez l'avoir entendu dire ; vous pouvez l'avoir lu dans les papiers.

eng: And one of my own daughters. ~~~ I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have seen it in the papers.
fr: Je sais que c'etoit dans le times, et dans le courier, quoiqu'on ne l'ait pas mis precisement comme on le devoit.

eng: It was in the Times and the Courier, I know; though it was not put in as it ought to be.
fr: Il y avoit seulement : dernierement George Wikam Esq., a Lydie Bennet.

eng: It was only said, 'Lately, George Wickham, Esq.
fr: C'etoit de la composition de Mr.

eng: to Miss Lydia Bennet,' without there being a syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or any thing.
fr: Gardiner, et je ne comprends pas comment il a pu faire une chose pareille ; l'avez vous vu ?

eng: It was my brother Gardiner's drawing up too, and I wonder how he came to make such an awkward business of it. ~~~ Did you see it?"
fr: Bingley repondit affirmativement et fit ses complimens de felicitations ; Elisabeth couverte de confusion, n'osoit pas lever les yeux et ne pouvoit voir la contenance de Monsieur Darcy.

eng: Bingley replied that he did, and made his congratulations. ~~~ Elizabeth dared not lift up her eyes.
fr: -- Il est sur continua Mistriss Bennet que c'est une chose delicieuse, que d'avoir une fille bien mariee, mais aussi, Mr.

eng: How Mr. Darcy looked, therefore, she could not tell.
fr: Bingley, il est fort cruel d'en etre separee.

eng: "It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married," continued her mother, "but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard to have her taken such a way from me.
fr: Ils sont partis pour New-castle, c'est un endroit tout-a-fait au nord, je crois, et ils doivent y rester, je ne sais combien de tems ; le regiment de Mr.

eng: They are gone down to Newcastle, a place quite northward, it seems, and there they are to stay, I do not know how long.
His regiment is there; for I suppose you have heard of his leaving the ----shire, and of his being gone into the regulars.
fr: Wikam y est, car je suppose que vous savez qu'il a quitte le regiment de milice de et qu'il est entre dans les troupes reglees.

eng: Thank Heaven! ~~~ he has _some_ friends, though perhaps not so many as he deserves."
fr: Dieu soit loue, il a quelques amis, quoique pas autant qu'il le meriteroit.

eng: Elizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at Mr. Darcy, was in such misery of shame, that she could hardly keep her seat.
fr: Elisabeth qui savoit que ces mots etoient diriges contre Mr.

eng: It drew from her, however, the exertion of speaking, which nothing else had so effectually done before; and she asked Bingley, whether he meant to make any stay in the country at present.
fr: Darcy, etoit tellement accablee de honte, qu'elle pouvoit a peine respirer ; cependant le vif desir d'empecher sa mere de continuer, lui donna la force de rompre enfin le silence, qu'elle avoit garde jusqu'alors ; elle demanda a Bingley s'il avoit l'intention de passer quelques jours a Netherfield ?

eng: A few weeks, he believed.
fr: -- Quelques semaines, repondit-il.

eng: "When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley," said her mother, "I beg you will come here, and shoot as many as you please, on Mr. Bennet's manor.
fr: -- Quand vous aurez tue tout le gibier qu'il y a chez vous, Monsieur Bingley, dit Mistriss Bennet, je vous prie de venir ici et de chasser tant qu'il vous plaira sur les proprietes de Mr. ~~~ Bennet.

eng: I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of the covies for you."
fr: Je suis sure qu'il sera fort heureux de vous obliger, et qu'il gardera les meilleures couvees pour vous.

eng: Elizabeth's misery increased, at such unnecessary, such officious attention!
Were the same fair prospect to arise at present, as had flattered them a year ago, every thing, she was persuaded, would be hastening to the same vexatious conclusion.

At that instant she felt, that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends, for moments of such painful confusion. ~~~ "The first wish of my heart," said she to herself, "is never more to be in company with either of them.
fr: Des attentions si officieuses et si peu necessaires, faisoient souffrir Elisabeth et sa soeur au point que la premiere croyoit que des annees de bonheur ne pourroient les dedommager de ce qu'elles eprouvoient alors.

eng: Their society can afford no pleasure, that will atone for such wretchedness as this! ~~~ Let me never see either one or the other again!"
fr: Mon plus vif desir, pensoit-elle, seroit de ne jamais les revoir ni l'un ni l'autre ; rien ne peut compenser des momens si penibles que ceux-ci !

eng: Yet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no compensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing how much the beauty of her sister re-kindled the admiration of her former lover.
fr: Cependant, la confusion que des annees de bonheur ne pouvoient dedommager, fut bientot extremement diminuee par la joie qu'elle eprouva en voyant que la beaute de Jane rallumoit les transports de son ancien adorateur.

eng: When first he came in, he had spoken to her but little; but every five minutes seemed to be giving her more of his attention.
fr: Il lui avoit peu parle dans le commencement de sa visite, mais ensuite il parut plus occupe d'elle que jamais.

eng: He found her as handsome as she had been last year; as good natured, and as unaffected, though not quite so chatty.
fr: Il la trouvoit aussi belle, aussi bonne, aussi simple que l'annee derniere, mais pas tout-a-fait aussi gaie, ni aussi animee.

eng: When the gentlemen rose to go away, Mrs. Bennet was mindful of her intended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at Longbourn in a few days time.
fr: Lorsque ces Messieurs se leverent pour prendre conge, Mistriss Bennet se rappela la politesse qu'elle vouloit faire, et elle les invita a diner pour quelques jours apres.
-- Vous me devez vraiment une visite, Mr.

eng: "You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley," she added, "for when you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with us, as soon as you returned.
fr: Bingley, ajouta-t-elle, car lorsque vous partites pour la ville, l'automne dernier, vous me promites de venir diner en famille aussitot que vous seriez de retour.

eng: Mrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there, that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think any thing less than two courses, could be good enough for a man, on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a-year.
fr: Mistriss Bennet avoit une extreme envie de les retenir a diner le jour meme, mais quoiqu'elle eut toujours une tres-bonne table, elle pensoit qu'il falloit au moins deux services pour un homme sur lequel elle avoit des intentions, et pour satisfaire l'appetit et l'orgueil de celui qui avoit au moins dix mille livres de rente.

eng: CHAPTER XII.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE VI.

eng: As soon as they were gone, Elizabeth walked out to recover her spirits; or in other words, to dwell without interruption on those subjects that must deaden them more.
fr: Immediatement apres le depart de ces Messieurs, Elisabeth oppressee et affligee, chercha dans la promenade, la solitude dont elle avoit besoin pour se remettre de ce qu'elle avoit souffert pendant cette visite.

eng: Mr. Darcy's behaviour astonished and vexed her.
fr: -- Ah ! ~~~ pourquoi est-il venu ?

eng: "Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent," said she, "did he come at all?"
fr: s'ecrioit-elle ; etoit-ce pour se montrer si froid, si indifferent ?

eng: She could settle it in no way that gave her pleasure.
"He could be still amiable, still pleasing, to my uncle and aunt, when he was in town; and why not to me? ~~~ If he fears me, why come hither?
fr: Il savoit bien etre aimable et chercher a plaire a mon oncle et a ma tante, mais a moi non ; il ne m'aime plus, il ne s'occupe plus de moi !

eng: If he no longer cares for me, why silent?
Teazing, teazing, man!
fr: Oh le terrible homme !

eng: I will think no more about him."
fr: je n'y veux plus penser !

eng: Her resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach of her sister, who joined her with a cheerful look, which shewed her better satisfied with their visitors, than Elizabeth.
fr: Elle remplit en effet sa promesse pendant quelques minutes, mais c'etoit bien involontairement ; sa soeur venoit vers elle ; elle l'aborda avec un air de gaiete qui prouvoit qu'elle etoit plus satisfaite que la pauvre Elisabeth.

eng: "Now," said she, "that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly easy. ~~~ I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by his coming.
fr: -- A present que cette premiere entrevue est passee, disoit-elle, je suis parfaitement a mon aise ; je ne serai plus embarrassee lorsqu'il reviendra.

eng: I am glad he dines here on Tuesday. ~~~ It will then be publicly seen, that on both sides, we meet only as common and indifferent acquaintance."
fr: Je suis charmee qu'il dine ici mardi avec du monde ; on verra au moins que nous ne sommes l'un pour l'autre que de simples connoissances fort indifferentes.

eng: "Yes, very indifferent indeed," said Elizabeth, laughingly.
fr: -- Oui, tres-indifferentes, en verite, dit Elisabeth ; ah !

eng: "Oh, Jane, take care."
fr: Jane, prenez garde !

eng: "My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak, as to be in danger now."
fr: -- Mais, ma chere Lizzy, me croyez-vous assez foible pour que je puisse courir encore quelque danger ?

eng: * * * * * They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes, which the good humour, and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour's visit, had revived.
fr: On ne revit point ces Messieurs jusqu'au mardi, et pendant ce temps Mistriss Bennet formoit de nouveau les plans les plus brillans ; la politesse et les attentions de Bingley, pendant une visite d'une demi-heure, avoient ranime toutes ses esperances.

eng: On Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn; and the two, who were most anxiously expected, to the credit of their punctuality as sportsmen, were in very good time.
When they repaired to the dining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take the place, which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by her sister.
Her prudent mother, occupied by the same ideas, forbore to invite him to sit by herself.
fr: Il y avoit beaucoup de monde a Longbourn, et MM.

eng: On entering the room, he seemed to hesitate; but Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was decided.
He placed himself by her.
fr: Darcy et Bingley arriverent de bonne heure.

eng: Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend.
fr: Lorsqu'on passa dans la salle a manger, Elisabeth observoit attentivement si Bingley reprendroit son ancienne place aupres de Jane.

eng: He bore it with noble indifference, and she would have imagined that Bingley had received his sanction to be happy, had she not seen his eyes likewise turned towards Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing alarm.
fr: Mistriss Bennet, occupee de la meme idee, ne lui fit point signe de venir se placer a cote d'elle ; il hesitoit lui-meme, mais Jane ayant souri en regardant autour d'elle, la chose fut decidee, il se placa a ses cotes.

eng: His behaviour to her sister was such, during dinner time, as shewed an admiration of her, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded Elizabeth, that if left wholly to himself, Jane's happiness, and his own, would be speedily secured.
Though she dared not depend upon the consequence, she yet received pleasure from observing his behaviour.
It gave her all the animation that her spirits could boast; for she was in no cheerful humour.
fr: Elisabeth etoit aussi loin de Mr.

eng: Mr. Darcy was almost as far from her, as the table could divide them.
fr: Darcy que la table pouvoit le permettre.

eng: He was on one side of her mother. ~~~ She knew how little such a situation would give pleasure to either, or make either appear to advantage.
fr: Il etoit a cote de sa mere ; elle sentoit que ce rapprochement etoit aussi desagreable pour l'un que pour l'autre, et qu'ils paroitroient tous deux a leur desavantage.

eng: She was not near enough to hear any of their discourse, but she could see how seldom they spoke to each other, and how formal and cold was their manner, whenever they did.
fr: Elle etoit trop loin pour pouvoir entendre ce qu'ils se disoient, mais elle voyoit qu'ils se parloient fort peu et avec une froideur et une ceremonie excessives.

eng: Her mother's ungraciousness, made the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth's mind; and she would, at times, have given any thing to be privileged to tell him, that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the family.
fr: La secheresse que sa mere affectoit vis-a-vis de Mr.

eng: She was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of bringing them together; that the whole of the visit would not pass away without enabling them to enter into something more of conversation, than the mere ceremonious salutation attending his entrance.
fr: Darcy, faisoit sentir a Elisabeth, d'une maniere encore plus douloureuse, toutes les obligations qu'on lui avoit, et dans ce moment elle auroit voulu lui dire qu'il y avoit quelqu'un dans la famille qui connoissoit et apprecioit toute l'etendue de sa generosite.

eng: Anxious and uneasy, the period which passed in the drawing-room, before the gentlemen came, was wearisome and dull to a degree, that almost made her uncivil.
fr: Elle esperoit que dans le courant de la soiree le hasard les rapprocheroit l'un de l'autre et qu'elle pourroit enfin entrer en conversation avec lui.

eng: She looked forward to their entrance, as the point on which all her chance of pleasure for the evening must depend.
fr: Le temps lui parut long et ennuyeux jusqu'a ce que les hommes revinssent dans le salon, elle attendoit leur retour avec anxiete.

eng: "If he does not come to me, _then_," said she, "I shall give him up for ever."
fr: -- S'il ne vient pas vers moi, pensoit-elle, c'est fini, il n'y faut plus penser.

eng: The gentlemen came; and she thought he looked as if he would have answered her hopes; but, alas!
fr: Enfin le moment desire arriva, les hommes revinrent.

eng: the ladies had crowded round the table, where Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth pouring out the coffee, in so close a confederacy, that there was not a single vacancy near her, which would admit of a chair. ~~~ And on the gentlemen's approaching, one of the girls moved closer to her than ever, and said, in a whisper, "The men shan't come and part us, I am determined.
fr: Mais les dames alors se presserent tellement autour de la table ou on servoit le cafe, qu'il ne resta pas une seule place aupres d'elle ; et lorsque quelques hommes s'avancerent, une jeune demoiselle, rapprochant sa chaise de la sienne, lui dit a l'oreille : -- Ne permettons pas a ces Messieurs de venir nous separer ; nous n'en avons pas besoin, n'est-ce pas ?

eng: We want none of them; do we?" ~~~ Darcy had walked away to another part of the room.
fr: Darcy etoit de l'autre cote du salon, elle le suivoit des yeux et envioit le sort de tous ceux auxquels il parloit.

eng: She followed him with her eyes, envied every one to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough to help anybody to coffee; and then was enraged against herself for being so silly! ~~~ "A man who has once been refused!
How could I ever be foolish enough to expect a renewal of his love?
fr: Son impatience etoit telle, qu'elle pouvoit a peine la contenir.

eng: Is there one among the sex, who would not protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman?
fr: Elle etoit fachee contre elle-meme de se sentir si troublee.

eng: There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings!"
fr: Enfin cependant elle le vit s'approcher.

eng: She was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee cup himself; and she seized the opportunity of saying, "Is your sister at Pemberley still?"
fr: Elle se hata de commencer la conversation : -- Votre soeur est-elle encore a Pemberley ?

eng: "Mrs. Annesley is with her.
fr: -- Mistriss Ammesley est avec elle.

eng: The others have been gone on to Scarborough, these three weeks."
fr: Mistriss Hurst et Miss Bingley sont a Scarborough depuis trois semaines.
Apres cela, elle ne trouva plus rien a lui dire.

eng: She could think of nothing more to say; but if he wished to converse with her, he might have better success.
fr: -- Mais s'il desire continuer la conversation, pensoit-elle, c'est a lui a parler maintenant.

eng: He stood by her, however, for some minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young lady's whispering to Elizabeth again, he walked away.
fr: -- Il resta quelques minutes aupres d'elle ; et la jeune demoiselle ayant encore chuchote quelque chose a l'oreille d'Elisabeth, il s'en alla.

eng: When the tea-things were removed, and the card tables placed, the ladies all rose, and Elizabeth was then hoping to be soon joined by him, when all her views were overthrown, by seeing him fall a victim to her mother's rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated with the rest of the party.
fr: Lorsque la table a the fut emportee et les tables de jeu placees, Elisabeth espera qu'il reviendroit aupres d'elle, mais ses esperances furent encore trompees, il devint la victime de sa mere, qui le placa a une partie de jeu.

eng: She now lost every expectation of pleasure.
fr: Elle-meme fut mise, pour toute la soiree, a une autre table.

eng: They were confined for the evening at different tables, and she had nothing to hope, but that his eyes were so often turned towards her side of the room, as to make him play as unsuccessfully as herself.
fr: Ainsi, tout plaisir fut aneanti ; mais les yeux de Darcy etoilent si souvent tournes de son cote, qu'il jouoit tout aussi mal qu'elle.

eng: "Well girls," said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, "What say you to the day?
fr: mesdemoiselles, dit Mistriss Bennet a ses filles, lorsque tout le monde fut loin, que dites-vous de cette journee ?
Je crois que tout s'est bien passe.

eng: I think every thing has passed off uncommonly well, I assure you.
fr: Le diner etoit aussi bien servi que possible. ~~~ Le gibier etoit a point.

eng: The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw.
fr: Chacun s'est recrie sur la bonte du mouton.

eng: The venison was roasted to a turn--and everybody said, they never saw so fat a haunch.
fr: Le potage etoit mille fois meilleur que celui que nous avons eu chez les Lucas la semaine derniere ; Mr.

eng: The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the Lucas's last week; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged, that the partridges were remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French cooks at least.
fr: Darcy lui-meme a avoue que les perdrix etoient excessivement delicates, et je suppose qu'il a au moins deux ou trois cuisiniers francais.

eng: And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater beauty. ~~~ Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. ~~~ And what do you think she said besides?
fr: Enfin, ma chere Jane, je ne vous ai jamais vue aussi belle qu'aujourd'hui ; lorsque j'ai demande a Mistriss Long ce qu'elle pensoit de vous, que croyez-vous qu'elle ait repondu ?

eng: 'Ah!
fr: << Ah !

eng: Mrs. Bennet, we shall have her at Netherfield at last.'
She did indeed.
fr: Mistriss Bennet !

eng: I do think Mrs. Long is as good a creature as ever lived--and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls, and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously."

Mrs. Bennet, in short, was in very great spirits; she had seen enough of Bingley's behaviour to Jane, to be convinced that she would get him at last; and her expectations of advantage to her family, when in a happy humour, were so far beyond reason, that she was quite disappointed at not seeing him there again the next day, to make his proposals.
"It has been a very agreeable day," said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth.
fr: nous la verrons bientot etablie a Netherfield.

eng: "The party seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other.
I hope we may often meet again."
Elizabeth smiled.
fr: >> C'est la verite.

eng: "Lizzy, you must not do so. ~~~ You must not suspect me. ~~~ It mortifies me.
fr: Mistriss Long est la meilleure creature qu'on ait jamais vue.

eng: I assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an agreeable and sensible young man, without having a wish beyond it.
I am perfectly satisfied from what his manners now are, that he never had any design of engaging my affection.
fr: Ses nieces sont fort bien elevees, point jolies du tout ; je les aime beaucoup.

eng: It is only that he is blessed with greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally pleasing than any other man." ~~~ "You are very cruel," said her sister, "you will not let me smile, and are provoking me to it every moment." ~~~ "How hard it is in some cases to be believed!"
fr: Mistriss Bennet etoit de tres-bonne humeur ; la conduite de Bingley envers Jane avoit suffi pour la convaincre qu'il finiroit par l'epouser, et elle fut tres-etonnee de ne pas le voir revenir le lendemain pour faire sa demande.

eng: "And how impossible in others!"
fr: * * * CHAPITRE VII.

eng: "But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I acknowledge?"
"That is a question which I hardly know how to answer.
We all love to instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing.
Forgive me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make _me_ your confidante."
CHAPTER XIII.
fr: Peu de jours apres, Mr.

eng: A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, and alone.
fr: Bingley vint faire visite.

eng: His friend had left him that morning for London, but was to return home in ten days time.
fr: Il etoit seul ; son ami l'avoit quitte le matin meme pour aller a Londres ; il devoit revenir dans dix jours.

eng: He sat with them above an hour, and was in remarkably good spirits. ~~~ Mrs. Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many expressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.
fr: Il resta environ une heure et fut extremement gai ; Mistriss Bennet voulut le retenir a diner, mais il avoua, d'un air fort afflige, qu'il etoit engage ailleurs.

eng: "Next time you call," said she, "I hope we shall be more lucky."
fr: -- J'espere que nous serons plus heureux, lorsque vous reviendrez.

eng: He should be particularly happy at any time, &c. &c.; and if she would give him leave, would take an early opportunity of waiting on them.
fr: Mr. ~~~ Bingley se confondit en remercimens, et promit de saisir la premiere occasion de revenir.

eng: "Can you come to-morrow?"
fr: -- Pouvez-vous demain ?

eng: Yes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was accepted with alacrity.
fr: Il n'avoit aucun engagement pour le lendemain, et l'invitation fut acceptee avec joie.

eng: He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed.
fr: Il arriva le lendemain, mais de si bonne heure, qu'aucune des dames n'etoit habillee.

eng: In ran Mrs. Bennet to her daughter's room, in her dressing gown, and with her hair half finished, crying out, "My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down.
fr: Mistriss Bennet, a moitie vetue, courut a la chambre de ses filles.

eng: He is come--Mr. Bingley is come.--He is, indeed. ~~~ Make haste, make haste.
fr: -- Ma chere Jane, lui dit-elle, depechez-vous, il est arrive, il est la-bas !

eng: "We will be down as soon as we can," said Jane; "but I dare say Kitty is forwarder than either of us, for she went up stairs half an hour ago."
fr: -- Nous descendrons des que nous pourrons, dit Jane ; mais je crois que Kitty doit etre plus avancee que nous dans sa toilette, car il y a plus d'une demi-heure qu'elle est montee ; elle pourroit aller recevoir Mr.

eng: "Oh!
fr: Bingley.

eng: hang Kitty!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: what has she to do with it?
fr: laissez Kitty, qu'a-t-elle a faire la ?

eng: Come be quick, be quick!
fr: Ou est votre ceinture, ma chere ?

eng: where is your sash my dear?"
fr: Allons, depechez-vous.

eng: But when her mother was gone, Jane would not be prevailed on to go down without one of her sisters.
fr: Mais lorsque sa mere fut loin, Jane ne voulut jamais descendre sans une de ses soeurs.

eng: Two obstacles of the five being thus removed, Mrs. Bennet sat looking and winking at Elizabeth and Catherine for a considerable time, without making any impression on them. ~~~ Elizabeth would not observe her; and when at last Kitty did, she very innocently said, "What is the matter mamma?
fr: Sur cinq, deux etant deja eloignes, Mistriss Bennet faisoit des signes a Kitty et a Elisabeth pour les engager a sortir de la chambre, mais cette derniere ne vouloit pas les voir, et quant a Kitty, elle lui dit tres-innocemment : -- Qu'est-ce que c'est, maman ?

eng: What do you keep winking at me for?
fr: Pourquoi me faites-vous ces signes ?

eng: What am I to do?"
fr: Que voulez-vous que je fasse ?

eng: "Nothing child, nothing. ~~~ I did not wink at you."
fr: -- Rien, mon enfant, je ne vous ai point fait de signes.

eng: She then sat still five minutes longer; but unable to waste such a precious occasion, she suddenly got up, and saying to Kitty, "Come here, my love, I want to speak to you," took her out of the room.
fr: Elle se contint encore cinq minutes, puis, ne pouvant se resoudre a laisser echapper une si bonne occasion, elle se leva tout-a-coup et dit a Kitty : -- Venez, mon ange, j'ai a vous parler : -- et elle l'emmena dans une autre chambre.

eng: Elizabeth was forced to go.
fr: Elisabeth fut forcee de se rendre a cette sommation.

eng: "We may as well leave them by themselves you know;" said her mother as soon as she was in the hall.
fr: -- Il faut que nous les laissions un peu seuls, dit Mistriss Bennet.

eng: "Kitty and I are going upstairs to sit in my dressing-room."
fr: Kitty et moi nous allons monter dans ma chambre.

eng: Elizabeth made no attempt to reason with her mother, but remained quietly in the hall, till she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned into the drawing-room.
fr: Elisabeth n'essaya point de discuter avec sa mere, mais elle attendit dans le vestibule jusqu'a ce qu'elle fut partie avec Kitty, et alors elle rentra dans le salon.

eng: Mrs. Bennet's schemes for this day were ineffectual. ~~~ Bingley was every thing that was charming, except the professed lover of her daughter.
fr: Ainsi, les plans de Mistriss Bennet echouerent pour ce jour-la, Bingley etoit empresse, attentif, gai et aimable, mais il ne pensoit point a faire une declaration.

eng: His ease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their evening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the mother, and heard all her silly remarks with a forbearance and command of countenance, particularly grateful to the daughter.

He scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper; and before he went away, an engagement was formed, chiefly through his own and Mrs. Bennet's means, for his coming next morning to shoot with her husband.
fr: Il eut a peine besoin d'une invitation pour rester a souper ; et, avant de s'en aller, il prit aupres de Mistriss Bennet l'engagement de venir chasser le lendemain avec son mari.

eng: After this day, Jane said no more of her indifference.
fr: Depuis ce jour-la Jane ne parla plus de son indifference ni de son calme, et pas un mot de Bingley ne fut prononce entre les deux soeurs.

eng: Not a word passed between the sisters concerning Bingley; but Elizabeth went to bed in the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless Mr. Darcy returned within the stated time. ~~~ Seriously, however, she felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman's concurrence.
fr: Elisabeth alla se coucher dans la douce persuasion que tout seroit bientot fini, a moins pourtant que Darcy ne revint plutot qu'il ne l'avoit dit, quoiqu'elle crut bien cependant qu'il ne s'opposoit plus au bonheur de son ami.

eng: Bingley was punctual to his appointment; and he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together, as had been agreed on.
fr: Bingley fut exact au rendez-vous. ~~~ Il passa la journee avec Mr.

eng: The latter was much more agreeable than his companion expected.
fr: Bennet, comme il en avoit ete convenu.

eng: There was nothing of presumption or folly in Bingley, that could provoke his ridicule, or disgust him into silence; and he was more communicative, and less eccentric than the other had ever seen him.
fr: Il etoit plus aimable que ce dernier ne s'y seroit attendu. ~~~ Il etoit naturel que Mr.

eng: "'Tis too much!"
fr: -- C'est trop, c'est trop !

eng: she added, "by far too much. ~~~ I do not deserve it.
fr: disoit-elle, je ne le merite pas.

eng: Oh!
fr: Oh !

eng: why is not every body as happy?"
fr: pourquoi tout le monde n'est-il pas aussi heureux que moi ?

eng: Elizabeth's congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth, a delight, which words could but poorly express.
fr: Elisabeth la felicita avec une vivacite, une chaleur que les mots ne sauroient exprimer, et chacune de ses expressions de tendresse etoit une nouvelle source de bonheur pour Jane.

eng: Every sentence of kindness was a fresh source of happiness to Jane. ~~~ But she would not allow herself to stay with her sister, or say half that remained to be said, for the present.
fr: -- Il faut, s'ecria tout-a-coup Jane, que j'aille vers ma mere ; je ne dois pas tromper sa tendre sollicitude, ni permettre qu'elle apprenne mon bonheur d'un autre que de moi.

eng: "I must go instantly to my mother;" she cried.
fr: Il est deja vers mon pere pour lui demander son consentement.

eng: "I would not on any account trifle with her affectionate solicitude; or allow her to hear it from any one but myself.
He is gone to my father already.
Oh!
fr: Oh Lizzy !

eng: Lizzy, to know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear family!
fr: quelle douceur pour moi de savoir que ce que j'ai a dire fera tant de plaisir a toute ma chere famille !

eng: how shall I bear so much happiness!"
fr: Comment puis-je supporter tant de bonheur !

eng: She then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the card party, and was sitting up stairs with Kitty.
Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation.
fr: Elisabeth fut rejointe, au bout de tres-peu de momens, par Bingley lui-meme, dont la conference avec son pere avoit ete tres-courte et tres-heureuse.

eng: "And this," said she, "is the end of all his friend's anxious circumspection!
of all his sister's falsehood and contrivance!
fr: -- Ou est votre soeur ?

eng: the happiest, wisest, most reasonable end!"
fr: dit-il en entrant dans la chambre.

eng: In a few minutes she was joined by Bingley, whose conference with her father had been short and to the purpose.
fr: -- En haut, avec ma mere ; elle descendra bientot, je suppose.

eng: "Where is your sister?" ~~~ said he hastily, as he opened the door.
fr: Alors il s'avanca vers elle, et reclama les souhaits et la tendresse d'une soeur.

eng: "With my mother up stairs.
fr: Elisabeth lui exprima franchement sa joie.

eng: She will be down in a moment I dare say."
fr: Cette soiree fut delicieuse pour tous.

eng: He then shut the door, and coming up to her, claimed the good wishes and affection of a sister.
fr: La satisfaction qu'eprouvoit Jane repandoit une douce vivacite sur sa figure et la rendoit plus belle que jamais.

eng: Elizabeth honestly and heartily expressed her delight in the prospect of their relationship.
fr: Kitty minaudoit, sourioit et se bercoit de l'esperance que son tour viendroit bientot.

eng: They shook hands with great cordiality; and then till her sister came down, she had to listen to all he had to say, of his own happiness, and of Jane's perfections; and in spite of his being a lover, Elizabeth really believed all his expectations of felicity, to be rationally founded, because they had for basis the excellent understanding, and super-excellent disposition of Jane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and himself.
It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet's mind gave a glow of such sweet animation to her face, as made her look handsomer than ever.
fr: Mistriss Bennet ne trouvoit pas des termes assez vifs pour exprimer son bonheur, et cependant elle ne pouvoit parler d'autre chose. ~~~ Lorsque Mr.

eng: Kitty simpered and smiled, and hoped her turn was coming soon.
fr: Bennet les rejoignit a souper, on vit dans toutes ses manieres combien il etoit heureux.

eng: Mrs. Bennet could not give her consent, or speak her approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy her feelings, though she talked to Bingley of nothing else, for half an hour; and when Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly shewed how really happy he was.
Not a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their visitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he turned to his daughter and said, "Jane, I congratulate you.
fr: Cependant il ne prononca pas un mot qui eut rapport a ce qui s'etoit passe, jusqu'a ce que Bingley se fut retire ; alors, se tournant du cote de sa fille, il lui dit : -- Jane, vous serez une heureuse femme !

eng: You will be a very happy woman."
fr: Jane lui baisa la main.

eng: Jane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his goodness. ~~~ "You are a good girl;" he replied, "and I have great pleasure in thinking you will be so happily settled. ~~~ I have not a doubt of your doing very well together.
fr: -- Vous etes une bonne fille, lui dit-il, et j'ai un grand plaisir a penser que vous serez si bien etablie ; je ne doute pas que vous ne vous conveniez tres-bien, vos caracteres ne presentent pas de grands contrastes ; vous etes tous deux si complaisans, qu'il n'y aura jamais de discussions ; si faciles, que tous les domestiques vous tromperont ; et si genereux, que vous depenserez toujours plus que votre revenu.

eng: Your tempers are by no means unlike.
fr: -- Depenser plus que leur revenu !

eng: You are each of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so easy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will always exceed your income."
"I hope not so.
fr: mon cher Mr.

eng: Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters, would be unpardonable in _me_."
fr: Bennet, s'ecria sa femme.

eng: "Exceed their income!
fr: Que dites-vous ?

eng: My dear Mr. Bennet," cried his wife, "what are you talking of?
fr: Il a quatre mille livres de rente et peut-etre davantage !

eng: Why, he has four or five thousand a-year, and very likely more."
Then addressing her daughter, "Oh! ~~~ my dear, dear Jane, I am so happy!
fr: Puis, s'adressant a sa fille : -- Je suis si heureuse, ma chere Jane !

eng: I am sure I sha'nt get a wink of sleep all night.
fr: Je suis sure que je ne fermerai pas l'oeil de toute la nuit !

eng: I knew how it would be.
fr: Je savois bien que cela arriveroit !

eng: I always said it must be so, at last.
fr: J'ai toujours dit qu'il falloit que cela fut ainsi.

eng: I was sure you could not be so beautiful for nothing!
fr: J'etois sure que le Ciel ne vous avoit pas fait si belle pour rien.

eng: he is the handsomest young man that ever was seen!"
fr: c'est le plus beau jeune homme que j'aie jamais vu !

eng: Wickham, Lydia, were all forgotten.
fr: Wikam, Lydie, tout etoit oublie !

eng: Jane was beyond competition her favourite child. ~~~ At that moment, she cared for no other.
fr: Jane etoit son enfant bien aime, et dans ce moment elle ne pensoit point aux autres.

eng: Her younger sisters soon began to make interest with her for objects of happiness which she might in future be able to dispense.
fr: Elle la voyoit deja entouree de tout le luxe et l'elegance que peut donner la fortune.

eng: Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.
fr: Kitty demandoit qu'on eut des bals a Netherfield tous les hivers, et Mary qu'on lui permit de faire usage de la bibliotheque.

eng: In the absence of Jane, he always attached himself to Elizabeth, for the pleasure of talking of her; and when Bingley was gone, Jane constantly sought the same means of relief.
fr: Lorsque Jane etoit quelques instans absente, Bingley parloit d'elle a Elisabeth ; et quand Bingley n'y etoit pas, Jane recouroit aux memes moyens de consolation.

eng: "He has made me so happy," said she, one evening, "by telling me, that he was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring!
I had not believed it possible."
fr: -- Que je suis heureuse !

eng: "I suspected as much," replied Elizabeth.
fr: disoit-elle un soir ; il m'a dit qu'il avoit absolument ignore que je fusse a Londres le printemps dernier.

eng: "But how did he account for it?" ~~~ "It must have been his sister's doing.
fr: -- Je le soupconnois fort, dit Elisabeth ; vous a-t-il explique comment cela avoit pu se faire ?

eng: They were certainly no friends to his acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have chosen so much more advantageously in many respects.
fr: -- Ses soeurs le lui avoient cache ; il paroit bien certain qu'elles n'etoient pas satisfaites de notre liaison, et je n'en suis pas surprise, puisqu'elles avoient fait un choix si avantageux pour lui sous tous les rapports.

eng: But when they see, as I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will learn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again; though we can never be what we once were to each other."
fr: Mais j'espere que lorsqu'elles verront leur frere heureux, elles ne seront plus fachees qu'il se soit attache a moi, et que nous vivrons fort bien ensemble ; cependant je ne crois pas que nous puissions jamais redevenir ce que nous avons ete.

eng: "That is the most unforgiving speech," said Elizabeth, "that I ever heard you utter.
fr: -- Voila le discours le plus rempli de ressentiment que je vous aie jamais entendu prononcer, dit Elisabeth.

eng: Good girl!
fr: Excellente personne !

eng: It would vex me, indeed, to see you again the dupe of Miss Bingley's pretended regard."
fr: je serois bien en colere si je vous voyois de nouveau la dupe de la pretendue amitie de Miss Bingley.

eng: "Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November, he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of _my_ being indifferent, would have prevented his coming down again!"
fr: -- Croirez-vous, Lizzy, que lorsqu'il partit pour Londres au mois de Novembre, il m'aimoit veritablement, et que ce ne fut que la conviction de mon indifference qui put l'empecher de revenir ?

eng: "He made a little mistake to be sure; but it is to the credit of his modesty."
fr: -- Il est sur qu'il s'est bien laisse tromper, mais cela meme fait l'eloge de sa modestie.

eng: This naturally introduced a panegyric from Jane on his diffidence, and the little value he put on his own good qualities.
fr: Cette reflexion amena tout naturellement Jane a parler des bonnes qualites de Bingley.

eng: Elizabeth was pleased to find, that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend, for, though Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice her against him.
fr: Elisabeth fut charmee de voir qu'il n'avoit point inculpe son ami ; car, quoique Jane eut le coeur le plus genereux du monde, il eut ete bien difficile que les circonstances de cette affaire, si elle les eut connues, ne lui eussent pas donne de la prevention contre Mr.

eng: "I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!"
fr: Darcy. ~~~ -- Je suis la plus heureuse creature du monde !

eng: cried Jane.
fr: s'ecrioit Jane.

eng: "Oh!
fr: Oh Lizzy !

eng: Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed above them all!
fr: pourquoi ai-je ete ainsi choisie et benie entre toutes ! ~~~ Ah !

eng: If there _were_ but such another man for you!"
fr: S'il y avoit un autre Bingley pour vous !

eng: "If you were to give me forty such men, I never could be so happy as you.
fr: -- Je ne serai jamais aussi heureuse que vous !

eng: Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your happiness.
fr: Tant que je n'aurai pas votre excellent caractere, votre angelique bonte !
je ne puis avoir votre bonheur !

eng: No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time."
fr: Non, laissez-moi me changer moi-meme ; et ensuite, si mon heureuse etoile le permet, je pourrai peut-etre retrouver un autre Mr.

eng: The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a secret.
fr: Collins.

eng: Mrs. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mrs. Philips, and _she_ ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her neighbours in Meryton. ~~~ The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world, though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away, they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.
fr: On ne pouvoit garder le secret long-temps a Longbourn sur le mariage de Jane ; on permit a Mistriss Bennet d'en dire un mot a l'oreille de Mistriss Phillips, qui, sans permission, le dit a tous ses voisins, et bientot les Bennet passerent dans tout le voisinage pour une famille destinee au bonheur, quoique peu de semaines auparavant, lors de l'enlevement de Lydie, on les avoit cru nes pour l'infortune.

eng: CHAPTER XIV.
fr: CHAPITRE VIII.

eng: One morning, about a week after Bingley's engagement with Jane had been formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window, by the sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn. ~~~ It was too early in the morning for visitors, and besides, the equipage did not answer to that of any of their neighbours.
fr: Environ huit jours apres que Bingley eut demande la main de Jane, un matin qu'il etoit avec les dames de la famille dans la salle a manger, ils furent attires a la fenetre par le bruit d'un equipage, et virent une chaise de poste a quatre chevaux qui entroit dans l'avenue : c'etoit trop tot pour une visite ; d'ailleurs c'etoient des chevaux de poste, et ni le carosse, ni la livree du domestique qui le precedoit, ne leur etoient connus.

eng: The horses were post; and neither the carriage, nor the livery of the servant who preceded it, were familiar to them. ~~~ As it was certain, however, that somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the shrubbery.
fr: Cependant comme il etoit bien sur que c'etoit quelqu'un qu'il faudroit recevoir, Bingley engagea Miss Bennet a se soustraire a cet ennui en allant se promener avec lui dans le verger ; ils s'echapperent tous les deux, laissant les autres faire des conjectures sur cette visite inconnue, jusqu'au moment ou la porte s'ouvrit et ou l'on annonca Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

eng: They both set off, and the conjectures of the remaining three continued, though with little satisfaction, till the door was thrown open, and their visitor entered.
fr: La surprise que causa cette apparition soudaine ne peut se decrire, et celle d'Elisabeth fut encore plus grande que celle de sa mere et de Kitty.

eng: It was lady Catherine de Bourgh. ~~~ They were of course all intending to be surprised; but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elizabeth felt. ~~~ She entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no other reply to Elizabeth's salutation, than a slight inclination of the head, and sat down without saying a word.
fr: Lady Catherine entra dans la chambre avec un air encore moins gracieux qu'a l'ordinaire ; elle ne repondit a l'accueil d'Elisabeth que par un simple signe de tete, et s'assit sans dire un mot ; Elisabeth l'avoit nommee a sa mere, quoique sa Seigneurie n'eut point demande a lui etre presentee.

eng: Elizabeth had mentioned her name to her mother, on her ladyship's entrance, though no request of introduction had been made.
fr: Mistriss Bennet, extremement flattee de la visite d'une aussi grande dame, s'efforcoit de la recevoir avec toute la politesse imaginable.

eng: Mrs. Bennet all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such high importance, received her with the utmost politeness.
fr: Apres avoir garde le silence quelques instans, Lady Catherine dit fort sechement a Elisabeth : -- J'espere que vous etes bien, Miss Bennet ?

eng: After sitting for a moment in silence, she said very stiffly to Elizabeth, "I hope you are well, Miss Bennet.
That lady I suppose is your mother."
fr: Cette dame est votre mere, je suppose ?

eng: Elizabeth replied very concisely that she was.
fr: Elisabeth repondit un oui fort bref.

eng: "And _that_ I suppose is one of your sisters."
fr: -- Et celle-ci, une de vos soeurs, je pense ?

eng: "Yes, madam," said Mrs. Bennet, delighted to speak to a lady Catherine.

"She is my youngest girl but one. ~~~ My youngest of all, is lately married, and my eldest is somewhere about the grounds, walking with a young man, who I believe will soon become a part of the family."
fr: -- Oui, Madame, repondit Mistriss Bennet, qui etoit ravie de parler a Lady Catherine, c'est une des cadettes ; la plus jeune de toutes s'est mariee dernierement, et l'ainee se promene dans ce moment avec un jeune homme qui sera bientot son epoux.

eng: "This must be a most inconvenient sitting room for the evening, in summer; the windows are full west."
fr: -- Cette chambre doit etre bien incommode en ete, car les fenetres sont au couchant.

eng: Mrs. Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner; and then added, "May I take the liberty of asking your ladyship whether you left Mr. and Mrs. Collins well."
fr: Mistriss Bennet l'assura qu'on ne s'y tenoit jamais apres le diner. ~~~ -- Puis-je prendre, ajouta-t-elle, la liberte de demander a votre Seigneurie si elle a laisse Mr.

eng: "Yes, very well.
fr: et Mistriss Collins en bonne sante ?

eng: I saw them the night before last."
fr: -- Oui, tres-bonne ; je les vis avant-hier au soir.

eng: "Go, my dear," cried her mother, "and shew her ladyship about the different walks. ~~~ I think she will be pleased with the hermitage."
fr: -- Allez, ma chere, s'ecria sa mere, et faites voir toutes les promenades a sa Seigneurie ; je pense que l'hermitage lui plaira.

eng: Elizabeth obeyed, and running into her own room for her parasol, attended her noble guest down stairs.
fr: Elisabeth obeit, et sortit avec sa noble visite.

eng: As they passed through the hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and drawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent looking rooms, walked on.
fr: En traversant le vestibule, Lady Catherine ouvrit toutes les portes du salon et de la salle a manger et apres un leger examen, elle prononca que c'etoient d'assez bonnes chambres.

eng: Her carriage remained at the door, and Elizabeth saw that her waiting-woman was in it.
fr: Son carosse etoit a la porte, Elisabeth en passant y vit sa femme de chambre.

eng: They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk that led to the copse; Elizabeth was determined to make no effort for conversation with a woman, who was now more than usually insolent and disagreeable. ~~~ "How could I ever think her like her nephew?"
fr: Elles suivirent en silence le chemin qui conduisoit au petit bois ; Elisabeth etoit fort decidee a ne faire aucun effort pour entretenir la conversation avec une femme qui etoit encore plus insolente et plus desagreable qu'a l'ordinaire.

eng: said she, as she looked in her face. ~~~ As soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following manner:-- "You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my journey hither. ~~~ Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I come." ~~~ Elizabeth looked with unaffected astonishment.
fr: Des qu'elles furent entrees dans le petit bois, Lady Catherine commenca a parler de la maniere suivante : -- Vous devez comprendre, Miss Bennet, le motif de ma visite ; votre coeur et votre conscience doivent vous dire pourquoi je suis venue.

eng: "Indeed, you are mistaken, Madam.
fr: Elisabeth etoit tres-etonnee.

eng: I have not been at all able to account for the honour of seeing you here."
"Miss Bennet," replied her ladyship, in an angry tone, "you ought to know, that I am not to be trifled with.
fr: -- En verite, Madame, vous vous trompez, je ne sais pas du tout a quelle cause attribuer l'honneur que j'ai de vous voir ici.

eng: But however insincere _you_ may choose to be, you shall not find _me_ so.
fr: -- Miss Bennet, repliqua sa Seigneurie, vous devez savoir qu'on ne doit point plaisanter avec moi.

eng: My character has ever been celebrated for its sincerity and frankness, and in a cause of such moment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it.
fr: Mais si vous ne voulez pas etre sincere, vous ne me trouverez pas de meme ; mon caractere a toujours ete renomme par sa franchise, et dans ce moment-ci je ne m'en ecarterai certainement pas.

eng: "If you believed it impossible to be true," said Elizabeth, colouring with astonishment and disdain, "I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far.
fr: -- Si vous croyez a l'impossibilite de la chose, dit Elisabeth en rougissant de surprise et d'indignation, je suis etonnee que vous ayez pris la peine de venir de si loin.

eng: What could your ladyship propose by it?"
fr: Que se proposoit donc votre Seigneurie ?

eng: "At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted."
fr: -- D'insister pour que ce conte fut refute.

eng: "Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family," said Elizabeth, coolly, "will be rather a confirmation of it; if, indeed, such a report is in existence."
fr: -- Votre voyage a Longbourn, pour me voir ainsi que ma famille, repondit froidement Elisabeth, confirmeroit plutot un pareil bruit, s'il existe.

eng: Has it not been industriously circulated by yourselves?
fr: Ne l'avez-vous pas habilement repandu vous-meme ?

eng: Do you not know that such a report is spread abroad?"
fr: Ne savez-vous pas qu'il circule au loin ?

eng: "I never heard that it was."
fr: -- Je n'en avois jamais entendu parler.

eng: "And can you likewise declare, that there is no _foundation_ for it?"
fr: -- Et pouvez-vous aussi bien declarer qu'il n'a aucun fondement ?

eng: "I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your ladyship. ~~~ _You_ may ask questions, which _I_ shall not choose to answer."
fr: -- Je ne pretends point avoir autant de franchise que votre Seigneurie : vous pourriez me faire des questions auxquelles je ne serois pas disposee a repondre.

eng: "This is not to be borne. ~~~ Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied.
fr: -- Je ne puis supporter cela, Miss Bennet, et j'insiste pour que vous me repondiez.

eng: Has he, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?"
fr: Mon neveu vous a-t-il fait une proposition de mariage ?

eng: "Miss Bennet, do you know who I am?
fr: -- Miss Bennet, savez-vous qui je suis ?

eng: I have not been accustomed to such language as this.
fr: Je n'ai pas ete accoutumee a un pareil langage ; je suis la plus proche parente de Mr.

eng: I am almost the nearest relation he has in the world, and am entitled to know all his dearest concerns."
fr: Darcy, et j'ai des droits a connoitre ses plus chers interets.

eng: "But you are not entitled to know _mine_; nor will such behaviour as this, ever induce me to be explicit."
fr: -- Mais, Madame, vous n'avez aucun droit a connoitre les miens, et une conduite comme la votre ne pourra jamais m'engager a m'expliquer.

eng: "Let me be rightly understood.
fr: -- Permettez-moi, Miss Bennet, de parler franchement.

eng: This match, to which you have the presumption to aspire, can never take place.
fr: Cette union, a laquelle vous avez la presomption d'aspirer, ne peut jamais avoir lieu, non jamais !

eng: No, never.
fr: Mr.

eng: Mr. Darcy is engaged to _my daughter_.
fr: Darcy est promis a ma fille.

eng: Now what have you to say?"
fr: Maintenant, qu'avez-vous a dire ?

eng: "Only this; that if he is so, you can have no reason to suppose he will make an offer to me."
fr: -- Rien, Madame ; s'il est promis, vous ne pouvez avoir aucune raison de supposer qu'il ait demande ma main.

eng: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment, and then replied, "The engagement between them is of a peculiar kind.
fr: Lady Catherine hesita un moment, puis elle repondit : -- L'engagement qui existe entre eux est d'une espece particuliere.

eng: From their infancy, they have been intended for each other. ~~~ It was the favourite wish of _his_ mother, as well as of her's. ~~~ While in their cradles, we planned the union: and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would be accomplished, in their marriage, to be prevented by a young woman of inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to the family!
fr: Des leur enfance ils furent destines l'un a l'autre ; c'etoit le souhait le plus ardent de sa mere, aussi bien que le mien ; ils etoient encore au berceau, que nous projetions leur union ; et maintenant que le voeu des deux soeurs pourroit etre accompli, faut-il qu'il soit traverse par une jeune femme d'une naissance si inferieure, qui ne jouit d'aucune consideration dans le monde, et qui est tout-a-fait inconnue a notre famille ?

eng: Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends? ~~~ To his tacit engagement with Miss De Bourgh?
fr: N'avez-vous aucun egard pour ses amis, pour son engagement tacite avec Miss de Bourgh ?

eng: Are you lost to every feeling of propriety and delicacy?
fr: Avez-vous donc perdu tout sentiment de delicatesse et de convenance ?

eng: "Yes, and I had heard it before. ~~~ But what is that to me?
fr: -- Oui, et je le savois meme avant de vous connoitre ; mais que me fait tout cela ?

eng: If there is no other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not be kept from it, by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to marry Miss De Bourgh.
You both did as much as you could, in planning the marriage. ~~~ Its completion depended on others.
fr: S'il n'y avoit pas d'autres obstacles a mon union avec votre neveu, ce n'est pas certainement ce qui l'empecheroit.

eng: If Mr. Darcy is neither by honour nor inclination confined to his cousin, why is not he to make another choice? ~~~ And if I am that choice, why may not I accept him?"
fr: Si Mr. ~~~ Darcy n'est engage avec sa cousine, ni par sa parole ni par inclination, pourquoi ne pourroit-il pas faire un autre choix ?

eng: "Because honour, decorum, prudence, nay, interest, forbid it.
fr: et si ce choix tomboit sur moi, pourquoi ne l'accepterois-je pas ?

eng: Yes, Miss Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all.
fr: -- Parce que l'honneur, les convenances, la prudence, et meme votre interet vous le defendent, car n'esperez pas etre jamais reconnue par ses parens et ses amis.

eng: Your alliance will be a disgrace; your name will never even be mentioned by any of us."
fr: Nous considererons votre alliance comme un deshonneur, et votre nom ne sera jamais prononce parmi nous.

eng: "These are heavy misfortunes," replied Elizabeth.
fr: -- Ce sont en effet de terribles infortunes, repondit Elisabeth ; mais la femme de Mr.

eng: "But the wife of Mr. Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily attached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause to repine."
fr: Darcy aura tant d'autres moyens de bonheur, qu'elle pourra bien ne pas en etre accablee.

eng: "Obstinate, headstrong girl!
fr: -- Femme obstinee !

eng: I am ashamed of you!
fr: je suis honteuse pour vous !

eng: "Let us sit down.
fr: Mais asseyons-nous.

eng: You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came here with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will I be dissuaded from it.
fr: Vous comprendrez, Miss Bennet, que je suis venue dans la ferme resolution de venir a bout de mon projet ; je n'en serai point dissuadee ; je n'ai pas ete accoutumee a me plier aux volontes de personne, et je n'ai point l'habitude des mecomptes.

eng: I have not been used to submit to any person's whims. ~~~ I have not been in the habit of brooking disappointment."
fr: -- C'est ce qui rend la position actuelle de votre Seigneurie plus facheuse ; mais cela n'a aucune influence sur moi.

eng: "_That_ will make your ladyship's situation at present more pitiable; but it will have no effect on _me_."
fr: -- Je ne veux pas etre interrompue ; ecoutez-moi en silence : Ma fille et mon neveu sont nes l'un pour l'autre.

Du cote maternel ils descendent d'une famille noble ; et du cote paternel, de familles anciennes et respectables, quoique non titrees ; leurs fortunes sont superbes des deux cotes ; tous les membres de leurs familles respectives desirent cette union.

eng: "I will not be interrupted.
fr: Qui pourroit les separer ?

eng: Hear me in silence. ~~~ My daughter and my nephew are formed for each other.
fr: Sera-ce les pretentions ridicules d'une jeune femme sans famille, sans amis, sans fortune ?

eng: They are descended on the maternal side, from the same noble line; and, on the father's, from respectable, honourable, and ancient, though untitled families.
fr: Non, cela ne sera pas, et si vous connoissiez bien vos interets, vous ne desireriez pas de sortir de la sphere ou vous etes nee.

eng: Their fortune on both sides is splendid. ~~~ They are destined for each other by the voice of every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them?
fr: -- Je ne croirois point quitter cette sphere, en epousant votre neveu ; il est gentilhomme, et je suis la fille d'un gentilhomme ; ainsi nous sommes egaux.

eng: The upstart pretensions of a young woman without family, connections, or fortune.
fr: -- Il est vrai, vous etes fille d'un gentilhomme ; mais qu'etoit votre mere ?

eng: Is this to be endured!
fr: que sont vos oncles et vos tantes ?

eng: But it must not, shall not be.
fr: Ne croyez pas que j'ignore leur condition.
