eng: If you were sensible of your own good, you would not wish to quit the sphere, in which you have been brought up."
"In marrying your nephew, I should not consider myself as quitting that sphere. ~~~ He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman's daughter; so far we are equal."
fr: -- Quels que soient mes parens, repondit Elisabeth, s'ils ne sont pas des obstacles pour votre neveu, ils ne doivent en etre pour personne.

eng: "True.
fr: -- Finissons.

eng: You _are_ a gentleman's daughter. ~~~ But who was your mother?
fr: Dites-moi, une fois pour toutes, etes-vous engagee avec lui ?

eng: Who are your uncles and aunts?
Do not imagine me ignorant of their condition."
"Whatever my connections may be," said Elizabeth, "if your nephew does not object to them, they can be nothing to _you_."
"Tell me once for all, are you engaged to him?"
fr: -- Je ne le suis pas, repondit Elisabeth.

eng: Though Elizabeth would not, for the mere purpose of obliging Lady Catherine, have answered this question; she could not but say, after a moment's deliberation, "I am not."
Lady Catherine seemed pleased.
fr: Lady Catherine eut l'air enchante.

eng: "And will you promise me, never to enter into such an engagement?"
fr: -- Eh bien, promettez-moi de ne jamais vous engager avec lui.

eng: "I will make no promise of the kind."
fr: -- Je ne ferai jamais aucune promesse de cette espece.

eng: "Miss Bennet I am shocked and astonished.
fr: -- Miss Bennet, je suis etonnee, revoltee !

eng: I expected to find a more reasonable young woman. ~~~ But do not deceive yourself into a belief that I will ever recede.
fr: Je m'attendois a trouver une jeune personne plus raisonnable ; mais ne vous bercez pas de l'idee que je me dedirai jamais ; je ne m'en irai point que vous ne m'ayez fait la promesse que je vous demande.

eng: I shall not go away, till you have given me the assurance I require."
fr: -- Je ne la ferai certainement pas ; je ne saurois etre intimidee par des menaces aussi ridicules.

eng: "And I certainly _never_ shall give it.
fr: Votre Seigneurie desire que Mr.

eng: I am not to be intimidated into anything so wholly unreasonable.
Your ladyship wants Mr. Darcy to marry your daughter; but would my giving you the wished-for promise, make _their_ marriage at all more probable?
fr: Darcy epouse sa fille, mais la promesse que vous voulez que je vous fasse rendroit-elle son mariage plus probable ?

eng: Allow me to say, Lady Catherine, that the arguments with which you have supported this extraordinary application, have been as frivolous as the application was ill-judged.
fr: Permettez-moi de vous dire, Madame, que les raisonnemens dont vous avez appuye cette etrange requete, sont aussi frivoles que la requete etoit mal imaginee ; et vous avez bien mal connu mon caractere, si vous avez cru que je pusse etre influencee par tout ce que vous venez de dire.

eng: You have widely mistaken my character, if you think I can be worked on by such persuasions as these.
fr: Je ne sais pas jusqu'a quel point Mr.

eng: How far your nephew might approve of your interference in _his_ affairs, I cannot tell; but you have certainly no right to concern yourself in mine.
fr: Darcy approuve que vous vous ingeriez ainsi dans ses affaires, mais vous n'avez certainement aucun droit de vous meler des miennes ; ainsi, je vous demande de ne plus m'importuner sur ce sujet.

eng: I must beg, therefore, to be importuned no farther on the subject." ~~~ "Not so hasty, if you please.
fr: -- Ne vous hatez pas tant de terminer, je ne vous ai pas encore dit tous les obstacles que je vois a votre mariage avec mon neveu ; il en est un dont je n'ai pas encore parle.

eng: I have by no means done. ~~~ To all the objections I have already urged, I have still another to add.
fr: Je n'ai point ignore l'enlevement de votre soeur cadette, et toutes particularites de son infame conduite.

eng: I am no stranger to the particulars of your youngest sister's infamous elopement. ~~~ I know it all; that the young man's marrying her, was a patched-up business, at the expence of your father and uncles. ~~~ And is _such_ a girl to be my nephew's sister?
fr: Je sais qu'on n'a pu obtenir du jeune homme qu'il l'epousat, qu'en faisant un arrangement d'argent avec votre pere et vos oncles ; et une telle personne seroit belle-soeur de mon neveu !

eng: Is _her_ husband, is the son of his late father's steward, to be his brother?
fr: et il auroit pour beau-frere le fils de l'intendant de son pere !

eng: Heaven and earth!--of what are you thinking?
fr: Ciel et terre ! ~~~ a quoi pensez-vous !

eng: Are the shades of Pemberley to be thus polluted?"
fr: les ombrages de Pemberley seront-ils ainsi souilles ?

eng: "You can _now_ have nothing farther to say," she resentfully answered. ~~~ "You have insulted me, in every possible method. ~~~ I must beg to return to the house."
fr: -- Vous ne pouvez avoir rien d'autre a me dire, repondit Elisabeth ; vous m'avez offensee de toutes les manieres, je dois vous prier de finir cet entretien et de revenir a la maison.

eng: And she rose as she spoke. ~~~ Lady Catherine rose also, and they turned back.
fr: -- En parlant ainsi, elle se leva, Lady Catherine se leva aussi, et elles retournerent sur leurs pas.

eng: "You are then resolved to have him?"
fr: -- Vous etes donc decidee a l'epouser ?

eng: "I have said no such thing.
fr: -- Je n'ai pas dit cela.

eng: I am only resolved to act in that manner, which will, in my own opinion, constitute my happiness, without reference to _you_, or to any person so wholly unconnected with me." ~~~ "It is well.
fr: Je suis seulement decidee a me conduire selon ce qui me conviendra, sans prendre conseil de gens qui me sont parfaitement etrangers.

eng: You are determined to ruin him in the opinion of all his friends, and make him the contempt of the world."
fr: Vous voulez le perdre dans l'opinion, le rendre l'objet du mepris general.

eng: "Neither duty, nor honour, nor gratitude," replied Elizabeth, "have any possible claim on me, in the present instance. ~~~ No principle of either, would be violated by my marriage with Mr. Darcy.
fr: -- Le devoir, l'honneur et la reconnoissance auront toujours leurs droits sur moi, repondit Elisabeth, mais je ne viole aucun de leurs principes en epousant Mr.

eng: And with regard to the resentment of his family, or the indignation of the world, if the former _were_ excited by his marrying me, it would not give me one moment's concern--and the world in general would have too much sense to join in the scorn."
fr: Darcy ; et quant au ressentiment de sa famille ou au mepris du monde, si le premier etoit excite par son mariage avec moi, il ne me donneroit pas un instant d'inquietude ; le monde est trop juste pour que je craigne son jugement dans cette occasion.

eng: "And this is your real opinion! ~~~ This is your final resolve!
fr: -- Ainsi, voila votre derniere resolution ?

eng: Very well.
fr: Fort bien.

eng: Elizabeth made no answer; and without attempting to persuade her ladyship to return into the house, walked quietly into it herself.
fr: Elisabeth ne repondit point, et rentra tranquillement dans la maison sans offrir a sa Seigneurie de s'y reposer.

eng: She heard the carriage drive away as she proceeded up stairs.
fr: Peu d'instans apres elle entendit partir la voiture.

eng: Her mother impatiently met her at the door of the dressing-room, to ask why Lady Catherine would not come in again and rest herself.
fr: Sa mere l'attendoit avec impatience a la porte de sa chambre pour lui demander si Lady Catherine vouloit rentrer et prendre quelques rafraichissemens.

eng: "She did not choose it," said her daughter, "she would go." ~~~ "She is a very fine-looking woman!
fr: -- Non, lui repondit Elisabeth, elle a prefere s'en aller.

eng: and her calling here was prodigiously civil! ~~~ for she only came, I suppose, to tell us the Collinses were well.
fr: -- C'est une belle femme encore, dit Mistriss Bennet, et sa visite est bien obligeante, car je suppose qu'elle est seulement venue pour nous donner des nouvelles des Collins.

eng: She is on her road somewhere, I dare say, and so passing through Meryton, thought she might as well call on you.
fr: Elle va sans doute a quelqu'autre endroit, et en passant par Meryton, elle aura eu l'idee de s'arreter ici.

eng: I suppose she had nothing particular to say to you, Lizzy?"
fr: N'est-ce pas aussi votre avis ?

eng: Elizabeth was forced to give into a little falsehood here; for to acknowledge the substance of their conversation was impossible.
fr: Elisabeth fut forcee de faire un leger mensonge, il lui etoit impossible d'avouer le sujet qui avoit amene Lady Catherine.

eng: CHAPTER XV.
fr: CHAPITRE IX.

eng: The discomposure of spirits, which this extraordinary visit threw Elizabeth into, could not be easily overcome; nor could she for many hours, learn to think of it less than incessantly.
fr: Le trouble dans lequel cette etrange visite avoit jete Elisabeth, ne put se dissiper facilement.

eng: Lady Catherine it appeared, had actually taken the trouble of this journey from Rosings, for the sole purpose of breaking off her supposed engagement with Mr. Darcy.
fr: Lady Catherine avoit donc pris la peine de venir a Longbourn, dans la seule intention de chercher a rompre cet engagement suppose avec Mr. ~~~ Darcy ? ~~~ Mais d'ou pouvoit venir ce bruit ?

eng: It was a rational scheme to be sure!
fr: Elisabeth ne savoit qu'imaginer.

eng: but from what the report of their engagement could originate, Elizabeth was at a loss to imagine; till she recollected that _his_ being the intimate friend of Bingley, and _her_ being the sister of Jane, was enough, at a time when the expectation of one wedding, made every body eager for another, to supply the idea.
fr: Enfin elle pensa que le mariage de Bingley, ami intime de Mr. ~~~ Darcy, avoit donne lieu a beaucoup de conjectures, et que le bruit qui la concernoit en etoit la consequence naturelle.

eng: She had not herself forgotten to feel that the marriage of her sister must bring them more frequently together.
fr: Elle n'avoit pas ete la derniere a imaginer que le mariage de Jane devoit la rapprocher de Mr.

eng: And her neighbours at Lucas lodge, therefore, (for through their communication with the Collinses, the report she concluded had reached lady Catherine) had only set _that_ down, as almost certain and immediate, which _she_ had looked forward to as possible, at some future time.
fr: Darcy, en leur donnant l'occasion de se voir plus frequemment ; et leurs voisins Lucas avoient surement arrange et regarde comme certain ce qui n'etoit que possible.

eng: In revolving lady Catherine's expressions, however, she could not help feeling some uneasiness as to the possible consequence of her persisting in this interference.
fr: Ce devoit etre par leur communication avec les Collins, que ce bruit avoit pu parvenir jusqu'aux oreilles de Lady Catherine.

eng: From what she had said of her resolution to prevent their marriage, it occurred to Elizabeth that she must meditate an application to her nephew; and how _he_ might take a similar representation of the evils attached to a connection with her, she dared not pronounce.
fr: Elle pensoit avec inquietude, que sa Seigneurie, ayant echoue aupres d'elle, alloit s'adresser a son neveu lui-meme.

eng: She knew not the exact degree of his affection for his aunt, or his dependence on her judgment, but it was natural to suppose that he thought much higher of her ladyship than _she_ could do; and it was certain, that in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with _one_, whose immediate connections were so unequal to his own, his aunt would address him on his weakest side.
fr: Elle ne connoissoit pas jusqu'ou pouvoit aller sa tendresse pour sa tante et sa confiance en elle ; mais elle n'etoit que trop sure qu'elle l'attaqueroit par son cote faible, en lui representant tous les desagremens que lui procureroit une alliance avec une personne dont les relations etoient si differentes des siennes.

eng: With his notions of dignity, he would probably feel that the arguments, which to Elizabeth had appeared weak and ridiculous, contained much good sense and solid reasoning.
fr: Il etoit probable qu'il trouvoit beaucoup de bon sens et de solidite dans des argument, qui n'avoient paru a Elisabeth que foibles et ridicules.

eng: If he had been wavering before, as to what he should do, which had often seemed likely, the advice and intreaty of so near a relation might settle every doubt, and determine him at once to be as happy, as dignity unblemished could make him.
In that case he would return no more. ~~~ Lady Catherine might see him in her way through town; and his engagement to Bingley of coming again to Netherfield must give way.
fr: -- Ainsi donc pensoit-elle, s'il ne tient pas sa promesse de revenir a Netherfield, je saurai que Lady Catherine est parvenue a detruire le reste de tendresse qu'il avoit pour moi !

eng: "If, therefore, an excuse for not keeping his promise, should come to his friend within a few days," she added, "I shall know how to understand it.
fr: Mais si de semblables considerations peuvent l'engager a renoncer a ma main je ne dois pas le regretter.

eng: I shall then give over every expectation, every wish of his constancy.
If he is satisfied with only regretting me, when he might have obtained my affections and hand, I shall soon cease to regret him at all."

* * * * * The surprise of the rest of the family, on hearing who their visitor had been, was very great; but they obligingly satisfied it, with the same kind of supposition, which had appeased Mrs. Bennet's curiosity; and Elizabeth was spared from much teazing on the subject.
fr: La surprise de toute la famille, en apprenant la visite de Lady Catherine, fut extreme ; cependant chacun ayant eu la bonte de se contenter de l'explication qui avoit satisfait la curiosite de Mistriss Bennet ; Elisabeth put se dispenser d'en dire davantage.

eng: The next morning, as she was going down stairs, she was met by her father, who came out of his library with a letter in his hand.
fr: Le lendemain, en descendant l'escalier, elle rencontra son pere qui sortoit de la bibliotheque.

eng: "Lizzy," said he, "I was going to look for you; come into my room."
fr: -- Lizzy, lui dit-il, j'allois vous chercher, venez dans mon cabinet.

eng: She followed him thither; and her curiosity to know what he had to tell her, was heightened by the supposition of its being in some manner connected with the letter he held. ~~~ It suddenly struck her that it might be from lady Catherine; and she anticipated with dismay all the consequent explanations.
fr: Sa curiosite etoit encore augmentee par l'idee que la lettre que son pere tenoit a la main avoit peut-etre rapport a elle ; elle imagina tout a coup qu'elle pouvoit etre de Lady Catherine, et elle fremit de toutes les explications auxquelles cela devoit donner lieu.

eng: She followed her father to the fire place, and they both sat down. ~~~ He then said, "I have received a letter this morning that has astonished me exceedingly.
fr: Son pere la fit asseoir aupres de son feu ; et commenca ainsi : -- J'ai recu une lettre ce matin qui m'a fort etonne, et comme elle vous concerne principalement, je dois vous la faire connoitre.

eng: As it principally concerns yourself, you ought to know its contents. ~~~ I did not know before, that I had _two_ daughters on the brink of matrimony.
fr: Je ne savois pas que j'eusse deux filles sur le point de se marier ; permettez-moi de vous feliciter de la brillante conquete que vous avez faite.

eng: Let me congratulate you, on a very important conquest." ~~~ The colour now rushed into Elizabeth's cheeks in the instantaneous conviction of its being a letter from the nephew, instead of the aunt; and she was undetermined whether most to be pleased that he explained himself at all, or offended that his letter was not rather addressed to herself; when her father continued, "You look conscious.
fr: Une vive rougeur couvrit a l'instant la figure d'Elisabeth qui s'etoit persuadee que cette lettre venoit du neveu et non de la tante ; elle cherchoit deja dans son coeur, si elle etoit bien aise qu'il s'expliquat enfin tout-a-fait, ou fachee qu'il ne se fut pas plutot adresse a elle ; lorsque son pere continua : -- Mais vous avez l'air de le savoir deja, les jeunes personnes ont une bien grande penetration pour les choses de ce genre.

eng: Young ladies have great penetration in such matters as these; but I think I may defy even _your_ sagacity, to discover the name of your admirer. ~~~ This letter is from Mr.
fr: Cependant je crois pouvoir vous defier, malgre votre sagacite, de deviner le nom de votre adorateur ; cette lettre est de Mr.

eng: Collins."
fr: Collins.

eng: "From Mr. Collins!
fr: -- M. Collins ?

eng: and what can _he_ have to say?"
fr: Et que peut-il avoir a vous dire ?

eng: "Something very much to the purpose of course.
fr: -- Quelque chose de tres-interessant.

eng: He begins with congratulations on the approaching nuptials of my eldest daughter, of which it seems he has been told, by some of the good-natured, gossiping Lucases.
fr: Il commence par me feliciter sur le mariage de ma fille ainee, qu'il paroit avoir appris par quelqu'une des bonnes commeres Lucas ; mais je ne veux point faire languir votre impatience, ecoutez donc ce que dit votre cousin.

eng: I shall not sport with your impatience, by reading what he says on that point.
fr: >> Vous ayant fait mes sinceres felicitations et celles de Miss.

eng: What relates to yourself, is as follows. ~~~ "Having thus offered you the sincere congratulations of Mrs. Collins and myself on this happy event, let me now add a short hint on the subject of another: of which we have been advertised by the same authority. ~~~ Your daughter Elizabeth, it is presumed, will not long bear the name of Bennet, after her elder sister has resigned it, and the chosen partner of her fate, may be reasonably looked up to, as one of the most illustrious personages in this land.""
fr: Collins, sur cet heureux evenement ; permettez-moi d'ajouter quelques mots sur une nouvelle que nous tenons de la meme source : On croit que votre fille Elisabeth ne portera pas long-temps le nom de Bennet apres que sa soeur ainee l'aura quitte ; et l'on peut raisonnablement considerer l'homme qu'elle a choisi, comme l'un des personnages les plus illustres de ce pays.

eng: Yet in spite of all these temptations, let me warn my cousin Elizabeth, and yourself, of what evils you may incur, by a precipitate closure with this gentleman's proposals, which, of course, you will be inclined to take immediate advantage of."
fr: Cependant, malgre des avantages aussi seducteurs, permettez-moi de vous avertir ainsi que votre fille Elisabeth, des maux auxquels vous vous exposerez en acceptant trop precipitamment les propositions de ce jeune homme, comme il est naturel que vous le fassiez.

eng: "Have you any idea, Lizzy, who this gentleman is? ~~~ But now it comes out."
fr: >> -- Avez-vous quelque idee, Lizzy, de ce que peut etre ce jeune homme ?

eng: "My motive for cautioning you, is as follows.
fr: Mais patience, vous allez le savoir.

eng: We have reason to imagine that his aunt, lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look on the match with a friendly eye."
fr: << Les motifs que j'ai pour vous recommander une extreme prudence ; sont, que nous avons des raisons de croire que Lady Catherine ne voit pas ce mariage de bon oeil.

eng: "_Mr. ~~~ Darcy_, you see, is the man!
fr: >> -- Vous voyez que ce jeune homme est Mr.

eng: Now, Lizzy, I think I _have_ surprised you.
fr: Darcy ! ~~~ J'espere, Lizzy, que vous etes surprise !

eng: Could he, or the Lucases, have pitched on any man, within the circle of our acquaintance, whose name would have given the lie more effectually to what they related?
fr: Pouvoit-on choisir, dans le cercle de toutes nos connoissances, un homme dont le nom seul dementit plus formellement la nouvelle qu'ils ont forgee ? ~~~ Mr.

eng: Mr. Darcy, who never looks at any woman but to see a blemish, and who probably never looked at _you_ in his life!
fr: Darcy, qui ne jette jamais les yeux sur une femme que pour la critiquer, et qui ne vous a probablement jamais dit quatre mots de suite !

eng: It is admirable!"
fr: Cela est admirable !

eng: "Are you not diverted?"
fr: -- Cela ne vous amuse-t-il pas ?

eng: "Oh! ~~~ yes.
fr: -- Oh oui, beaucoup !

eng: Pray read on."
fr: Je vous prie, continuez.

eng: "After mentioning the likelihood of this marriage to her ladyship last night, she immediately, with her usual condescension, expressed what she felt on the occasion; when it became apparent, that on the score of some family objections on the part of my cousin, she would never give her consent to what she termed so disgraceful a match.
fr: << Lorsque nous avons parle de la possibilite de ce mariage a sa Seigneurie, hier au soir ; elle s'est exprimee avec sa bonte ordinaire, et il m'a paru evident, d'apres quelques reflexions qu'elle a faites sur la famille de ma cousine, qu'elle n'accorderoit jamais son consentement a ce qu'elle appeloit une alliance aussi deshonorable.

eng: I thought it my duty to give the speediest intelligence of this to my cousin, that she and her noble admirer may be aware of what they are about, and not run hastily into a marriage which has not been properly sanctioned."
fr: J'ai pense qu'il etoit de mon devoir d'en donner avis le plus promptement possible a ma cousine et a son noble adorateur, afin qu'ils voient ce qu'ils ont a faire, et qu'ils ne precipitent pas un mariage qui ne seroit pas convenablement sanctionne.

eng: "Mr. Collins moreover adds," "I am truly rejoiced that my cousin Lydia's sad business has been so well hushed up, and am only concerned that their living together before the marriage took place, should be so generally known.
fr: >> Mr. ~~~ Collins ajoutoit encore : << Je suis vraiment satisfait que la triste affaire de ma cousine Lydie ait ete si vite etouffee ; je suis seulement fache que le scandale de sa conduite avant son mariage ait ete generalement connu.

eng: I must not, however, neglect the duties of my station, or refrain from declaring my amazement, at hearing that you received the young couple into your house as soon as they were married.
fr: Je ne dois cependant pas negliger les devoirs de ma place, et dissimuler l'etonnement que j'ai ressenti en apprenant que vous aviez recu ces jeunes gens dans votre maison, des qu'ils ont ete maries.

eng: "Oh!"
fr: -- Oh !

eng: cried Elizabeth, "I am excessively diverted.
fr: s'ecria Elisabeth, cela me divertit extremement !

eng: But it is so strange!"
fr: C'est cependant bien extraordinaire !

eng: Nay, when I read a letter of his, I cannot help giving him the preference even over Wickham, much as I value the impudence and hypocrisy of my son-in-law.
fr: Collins pour rien au monde, et je vous assure qu'en lisant cette lettre je le preferois presque a Wikam pour sa stupidite emphatique, malgre que j'apprecie beaucoup l'impudence et l'hypocrisie de ce dernier.

eng: And pray, Lizzy, what said Lady Catherine about this report?
fr: Et je vous prie, Lizzy, qu'a dit Lady Catherine ?

eng: Did she call to refuse her consent?"
fr: Refuse-t-elle son consentement ?

eng: To this question his daughter replied only with a laugh; and as it had been asked without the least suspicion, she was not distressed by his repeating it. ~~~ Elizabeth had never been more at a loss to make her feelings appear what they were not.
fr: Elisabeth ne repondit a cette question que par un eclat de rire ; jamais elle n'avoit ete plus embarrassee ; voulant deguiser ses sentimens, elle se mit a rire pour ne pas pleurer ; son pere l'avoit cruellement mortifiee par tout ce qu'il lui avoit dit sur l'indifference de Mr.

eng: It was necessary to laugh, when she would rather have cried.
fr: Darcy.

eng: Her father had most cruelly mortified her, by what he said of Mr. Darcy's indifference, and she could do nothing but wonder at such a want of penetration, or fear that perhaps, instead of his seeing too _little_, she might have fancied too _much_.
CHAPTER XVI.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE X.

eng: Instead of receiving any such letter of excuse from his friend, as Elizabeth half expected Mr. Bingley to do, he was able to bring Darcy with him to Longbourn before many days had passed after Lady Catherine's visit.
fr: Peu de jours apres la visite de Lady Catherine, Mr.

eng: The gentlemen arrived early; and, before Mrs. Bennet had time to tell him of their having seen his aunt, of which her daughter sat in momentary dread, Bingley, who wanted to be alone with Jane, proposed their all walking out.
fr: Darcy loin de s'excuser aupres de son ami, comme le craignoit Elisabeth, revint a Netherfield.

eng: It was agreed to.
fr: Monsieur Bingley l'amena un matin a Longbourn.

eng: Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking, Mary could never spare time, but the remaining five set off together.
fr: Mistriss Bennet n'avoit pas encore eu le temps de dire a Mr.

eng: Bingley and Jane, however, soon allowed the others to outstrip them.
fr: Darcy que sa tante etoit venue leur faire visite, lorsque Bingley proposa une promenade.

eng: They lagged behind, while Elizabeth, Kitty, and Darcy, were to entertain each other.
fr: Mistriss Bennet n'avoit point l'habitude de marcher, et Mary ne vouloit pas perdre son temps ; ainsi les cinq autres partirent ensemble.

eng: Very little was said by either; Kitty was too much afraid of him to talk; Elizabeth was secretly forming a desperate resolution; and perhaps he might be doing the same.
fr: Bingley et Jane, resterent bientot en arriere, comme a l'ordinaire, tandis qu'Elisabeth et Kitty furent en avant avec Mr. ~~~ Darcy.

eng: They walked towards the Lucases, because Kitty wished to call upon Maria; and as Elizabeth saw no occasion for making it a general concern, when Kitty left them, she went boldly on with him alone.
fr: La conversation etoit peu animee, Kitty avoit trop peur de lui, pour oser parler, Elisabeth meditoit en secret une resolution desesperee, et peut-etre la meme idee occupoit-elle Darcy.

eng: Now was the moment for her resolution to be executed, and, while her courage was high, she immediately said, "Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish creature; and, for the sake of giving relief to my own feelings, care not how much I may be wounding your's.
fr: Ils dirigerent leur promenade du cote de Lucas-Lodge ; Kitty vouloit aller voir Maria, Elisabeth ne voyoit aucune necessite d'y aller aussi. ~~~ Alors Kitty les quitta, et sa soeur continua courageusement sa promenade avec Mr. ~~~ Darcy.

eng: I can no longer help thanking you for your unexampled kindness to my poor sister.
fr: C'etoit le moment d'executer sa resolution, pendant qu'elle en avoit la force.

-- Vous me trouverez peut-etre, dit-elle, une personne bien egoiste si dans le but de soulager mes propres sentimens, je ne crains pas de blesser les votres ; mais je ne puis m'empecher plus long-temps de vous remercier de la bonte sans exemple que vous avez eue pour ma pauvre soeur.

eng: Ever since I have known it, I have been most anxious to acknowledge to you how gratefully I feel it.
fr: Depuis que j'en ai ete instruite, j'ai desire ardemment pouvoir vous exprimer combien j'en ai ete touchee !

eng: "You must not blame my aunt. ~~~ Lydia's thoughtlessness first betrayed to me that you had been concerned in the matter; and, of course, I could not rest till I knew the particulars.
fr: -- Vous ne devez pas blamer ma tante, reprit Elisabeth, l'etourderie de Lydie a trahi la part que vous avez prise a ce qui la concernoit, et vraiment je ne pouvois etre tranquille jusqu'a ce que j'en connusse tous les details.

eng: Let me thank you again and again, in the name of all my family, for that generous compassion which induced you to take so much trouble, and bear so many mortifications, for the sake of discovering them."
fr: Permettez-moi de vous remercier encore au nom de toute ma famille, de la genereuse compassion qui vous a porte a prendre tant de peine, a supporter tant de mortifications et a faire tant de sacrifices, pour des etres qui vous etoient si etrangers !

eng: "If you _will_ thank me," he replied, "let it be for yourself alone.
fr: -- Si vous voulez me remercier, que ce soit pour vous seule !

eng: That the wish of giving happiness to you, might add force to the other inducements which led me on, I shall not attempt to deny.
fr: repondit-il, je ne puis nier que le desir de vous procurer quelque consolation, n'ait ajoute beaucoup de force aux motifs qui m'ont dirige dans cette occasion.

eng: But your _family_ owe me nothing. ~~~ Much as I respect them, I believe, I thought only of _you_."
fr: Votre famille ne me doit rien, quoique je la respecte et la considere infiniment, je ne pensois qu'a vous.

eng: Elizabeth was too much embarrassed to say a word. ~~~ After a short pause, her companion added, "You are too generous to trifle with me.
fr: Elisabeth etoit trop embarrassee pour pouvoir repondre un seul mot ; apres un instant de silence il ajouta : -- Vous etes trop genereuse pour vouloir vous jouer de moi.

eng: Had Elizabeth been able to encounter his eye, she might have seen how well the expression of heart-felt delight, diffused over his face, became him; but, though she could not look, she could listen, and he told her of feelings, which, in proving of what importance she was to him, made his affection every moment more valuable.
fr: Si Elisabeth avoit ose lever les yeux, elle auroit vu combien l'expression du bonheur donnoit de charmes a sa figure ; mais si elle n'osoit le regarder, au moins elle l'entendoit. ~~~ Tout ce qu'il lui dit de ses sentimens lui rendit sa tendresse d'autant plus precieuse, qu'elle vit combien elle etoit vive et respectueuse.

eng: They walked on, without knowing in what direction.
fr: Ils marchoient toujours sans s'embarrasser ou ils alloient, ils avoient trop a penser, a sentir et a dire pour pouvoir songer a autre chose.

eng: There was too much to be thought; and felt, and said, for attention to any other objects.
fr: Elisabeth apprit bientot qu'elle devoit la declaration de Mr.

eng: She soon learnt that they were indebted for their present good understanding to the efforts of his aunt, who _did_ call on him in her return through London, and there relate her journey to Longbourn, its motive, and the substance of her conversation with Elizabeth; dwelling emphatically on every expression of the latter, which, in her ladyship's apprehension, peculiarly denoted her perverseness and assurance, in the belief that such a relation must assist her endeavours to obtain that promise from her nephew, which _she_ had refused to give.
fr: Darcy, aux efforts de sa tante, qui avoit ete le voir a Londres et lui avoit raconte sa visite a Longbourn, ainsi que les motifs et les details de la conservation qu'elle avoit eue avec Elisabeth. ~~~ Elle avoit appuye avec emphase sur toutes les paroles de cette derniere, qui, dans l'opinion de sa Seigneurie, prouvoient par dessus tout son ambition et son insolence.

eng: But, unluckily for her ladyship, its effect had been exactly contrariwise.
fr: Elle croyoit qu'un tel recit devoit lui faire obtenir de son neveu la promesse qu'Elisabeth avoit refuse de faire ; mais malheureusement pour sa Seigneurie, ce recit eut un effet absolument contraire.

eng: "It taught me to hope," said he, "as I had scarcely ever allowed myself to hope before.
fr: -- Cela m'apprit, dit-il, ce que je ne m'etois jamais permis de supposer...

eng: I knew enough of your disposition to be certain, that, had you been absolutely, irrevocably decided against me, you would have acknowledged it to Lady Catherine, frankly and openly."
fr: Je connoissois assez votre caractere pour etre sur, que si vous aviez ete aussi prevenue contre moi que le printemps dernier, et absolument decidee a ne jamais accepter ma main, vous l'auriez franchement dit a Lady Catherine.

eng: "What did you say of me, that I did not deserve?
fr: -- Qu'avez-vous dit de moi qui ne fut merite ?

eng: For, though your accusations were ill-founded, formed on mistaken premises, my behaviour to you at the time, had merited the severest reproof.
fr: car quoique vos accusations fussent mal fondees, ma conduite vis-a-vis de vous dans ce moment, meritoit les reproches les plus severes ; elle etoit impardonnable, et je ne puis y penser sans indignation.

-- Ne nous disputons point pour savoir lequel de nous deux etoit le plus blamable ce jour-la, dit Elisabeth, notre conduite a l'un et a l'autre, si on l'examinoit de bien pres, seroit loin d'etre irreprochable, mais j'espere que depuis lors nous avons fait des progres dans la politesse.

eng: It was unpardonable. ~~~ I cannot think of it without abhorrence."
fr: -- Je ne puis pas me reconcilier si facilement avec moi-meme.

eng: "We will not quarrel for the greater share of blame annexed to that evening," said Elizabeth. ~~~ "The conduct of neither, if strictly examined, will be irreproachable; but since then, we have both, I hope, improved in civility."
fr: Le souvenir de ma conduite, de mes manieres, de mes expressions, m'a ete depuis bien des mois extremement penible ; et surtout les reproches si bien merites que vous me fites alors, et que je n'oublierai jamais.

eng: "I cannot be so easily reconciled to myself.
fr: << Si vous vous etiez conduit en homme comme il faut.

eng: The recollection of what I then said, of my conduct, my manners, my expressions during the whole of it, is now, and has been many months, inexpressibly painful to me.
fr: >> C'etoient vos propres expressions ; vous ne pouvez savoir combien elles m'ont tourmente !

eng: Your reproof, so well applied, I shall never forget: 'had you behaved in a more gentleman-like manner.' ~~~ Those were your words.
fr: Mais c'etoit je l'avoue quelque temps avant que je fusse devenu assez raisonnable pour sentir combien elles etoient justes.

eng: You know not, you can scarcely conceive, how they have tortured me;--though it was some time, I confess, before I was reasonable enough to allow their justice."
"I was certainly very far from expecting them to make so strong an impression.
fr: -- J'etois bien eloignee de penser qu'elles feroient une impression si vive !

eng: I had not the smallest idea of their being ever felt in such a way." ~~~ "I can easily believe it.
fr: Je n'avois pas la plus legere idee qu'elles pussent etre senties de cette maniere.

eng: You thought me then devoid of every proper feeling, I am sure you did.
fr: -- Je le crois ; vous pensiez alors que j'etois depourvu de toute sensibilite.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Ah !

eng: do not repeat what I then said.
These recollections will not do at all.
I assure you, that I have long been most heartily ashamed of it."
fr: ne repetez pas ce que je vous ai dit alors, j'en ai trop rougi depuis.

eng: Darcy mentioned his letter. ~~~ "Did it," said he, "did it _soon_ make you think better of me?
fr: Darcy parla ensuite de sa lettre : -- Vous donna-t-elle un peu meilleure idee de moi ?

eng: Did you, on reading it, give any credit to its contents?"
fr: Ajoutates-vous foi, a ce qu'elle contenoit ?

eng: She explained what its effect on her had been, and how gradually all her former prejudices had been removed.
fr: Elle lui raconta l'effet qu'elle avoit produit, et comment peu a peu tous ses anciens prejuges s'etoient evanouis.

eng: "I knew," said he, "that what I wrote must give you pain, but it was necessary. ~~~ I hope you have destroyed the letter.
fr: -- Je savois, reprit-il, que ce que j'ecrivois devoit vous faire de la peine, mais c'etoit necessaire.

eng: There was one part especially, the opening of it, which I should dread your having the power of reading again. ~~~ I can remember some expressions which might justly make you hate me."
fr: J'espere que vous avez brule cette lettre ; je ne voudrois pas que vous pussiez la relire, il y avoit, surtout au commencement, quelques expressions qui pourroient vous engager a me hair.

eng: You must learn some of my philosophy. ~~~ Think only of the past as its remembrance gives you pleasure."
fr: Vous devez prendre un peu de ma philosophie, il ne faut songer au passe que lorsque le souvenir en est agreable.

eng: "I cannot give you credit for any philosophy of the kind. ~~~ _Your_ retrospections must be so totally void of reproach, that the contentment arising from them, is not of philosophy, but what is much better, of ignorance.
fr: -- Vous vous vantez-la d'une philosophie que vous n'avez point ; vos souvenirs doivent etre depourvus de remords, il n'en est pas de meme pour moi ; je dois avoir de penibles reminiscences, que je ne puis ni ne dois repousser.

eng: But with _me_, it is not so. ~~~ Painful recollections will intrude, which cannot, which ought not to be repelled.
fr: J'ai ete toute ma vie un etre egoiste, sinon par sentiment et par principes, du moins par l'habitude et par le fait.

eng: I have been a selfish being all my life, in practice, though not in principle.
fr: Lorsque j'etois enfant on ne m'a jamais appris a corriger mon caractere, et si l'on me donna des bons principes je les suivis avec orgueil.

eng: As a child I was taught what was _right_, but I was not taught to correct my temper.
fr: Malheureusement j'etois fils unique, (et pendant plusieurs annees seul enfant).

eng: I was given good principles, but left to follow them in pride and conceit.
fr: Je fus gate par mes parens, qui quoique bons eux-memes, me laisserent devenir un etre vain et insupportable.

eng: Unfortunately an only son, (for many years an only _child_) I was spoilt by my parents, who though good themselves, (my father particularly, all that was benevolent and amiable,) allowed, encouraged, almost taught me to be selfish and overbearing, to care for none beyond my own family circle, to think meanly of all the rest of the world, to _wish_ at least to think meanly of their sense and worth compared with my own.
fr: Je concentrai toutes mes affections dans le cercle etroit de ma famille, ayant mauvaise opinion du reste du monde, et me croyant superieur, soit pour le jugement soit pour le rang, a tout ce qui n'etoit pas de mes relations intimes.

eng: What do I not owe you!
fr: Que ne vous dois-je pas ?

eng: You taught me a lesson, hard indeed at first, but most advantageous. ~~~ By you, I was properly humbled.
fr: Vous m'avez donne une cruelle lecon, vous m'avez justement humilie, je m'offris a vous plein de confiance et n'ayant pas imagine que vous pourriez me refuser.

eng: I came to you without a doubt of my reception. ~~~ You shewed me how insufficient were all my pretensions to please a woman worthy of being pleased."
fr: Vous me prouvates combien tous mes pretendus avantages etoient insuffisans pour plaire a une femme veritablement digne d'etre aimee.

eng: "Had you then persuaded yourself that I should?" ~~~ "Indeed I had.
fr: -- Vous etiez donc parfaitement sur que j'accepterais votre main ?

eng: What will you think of my vanity? ~~~ I believed you to be wishing, expecting my addresses."
fr: -- Oui, que penserez-vous de ma vanite, si je vous dis que je vous croyois impatiente de recevoir ma declaration ?

eng: "Hate you!
fr: -- Vous hair !

eng: I was angry perhaps at first, but my anger soon began to take a proper direction."
fr: je fus fache au premier moment, mais ma colere se tourna bien promptement contre moi-meme.

eng: "I am almost afraid of asking what you thought of me; when we met at Pemberley.
fr: -- J'ose a peine vous demander ce que vous pensates lorsque nous nous rencontrames a Pemberley ?

eng: You blamed me for coming?"
fr: Ne me blamates-vous pas d'y etre allee ?

eng: "No indeed; I felt nothing but surprise."
fr: -- Non, en verite, je n'eprouvois que de la surprise.

eng: "Your surprise could not be greater than _mine_ in being noticed by you.
fr: -- Votre surprise ne pouvoit pas etre plus grande que la mienne.

eng: My conscience told me that I deserved no extraordinary politeness, and I confess that I did not expect to receive _more_ than my due."
fr: Lorsque vous m'abordates, ma conscience me disoit que je ne meritois pas un accueil si poli, et j'avoue que je ne m'attendois point a vous trouver si genereux !

eng: "My object _then_," replied Darcy, "was to shew you, by every civility in my power, that I was not so mean as to resent the past; and I hoped to obtain your forgiveness, to lessen your ill opinion, by letting you see that your reproofs had been attended to.
fr: -- Mon but, repondit Darcy, etoit de vous prouver que je n'avois pas assez de petitesse dans l'esprit pour conserver du ressentiment sur le passe. ~~~ J'esperois me faire pardonner ma grossierete et changer un peu l'opinion que vous aviez de moi, en vous laissant voir que vos reproches n'avoient pas ete inutiles.

eng: How soon any other wishes introduced themselves I can hardly tell, but I believe in about half an hour after I had seen you."
fr: Je ne puis vous dire tous les sentimens et toutes les esperances qui se ranimerent alors dans mon coeur !

eng: He then told her of Georgiana's delight in her acquaintance, and of her disappointment at its sudden interruption; which naturally leading to the cause of that interruption, she soon learnt that his resolution of following her from Derbyshire in quest of her sister, had been formed before he quitted the inn, and that his gravity and thoughtfulness there, had arisen from no other struggles than what such a purpose must comprehend.
fr: Il lui raconta ensuite quel plaisir Georgina avoit eu a faire sa connoissance et quel chagrin elle avoit eprouve de son depart si precipite. ~~~ Il lui dit aussi qu'avant de sortir de l'auberge, il avoit deja forme le projet de quitter aussitot le Derbyshire pour aller a la poursuite de Lydie, et que c'etoit ce qui lui avoit donne l'air serieux et preoccupe qu'il avoit en la quittant.

eng: After walking several miles in a leisurely manner, and too busy to know any thing about it, they found at last, on examining their watches, that it was time to be at home.
fr: Ils firent ainsi plusieurs milles sans s'apercevoir que le temps s'ecouloit, et furent assez etonnes de voir qu'il etoit fort tard et qu'ils devoient retourner a la maison.

eng: "What could become of Mr. Bingley and Jane!"
fr: Que sont devenus Jane et Mr. ~~~ Bingley ?

eng: was a wonder which introduced the discussion of _their_ affairs.
fr: fut une exclamation qui les amena a en parler.

eng: Darcy was delighted with their engagement; his friend had given him the earliest information of it.
fr: Darcy avoit ete charme du mariage de son ami, qui le lui avoit confie a l'instant ou il avoit ete conclu.

eng: "I must ask whether you were surprised?"
fr: -- N'avez-vous pas ete bien surpris ?

eng: said Elizabeth.
fr: dit Elisabeth.

eng: "Not at all. ~~~ When I went away, I felt that it would soon happen."
fr: -- Non, pas du tout, je m'y attendois lorsque je suis parti.

eng: "That is to say, you had given your permission.
fr: -- C'est-a-dire que vous aviez donne votre consentement !

eng: Bingley is most unaffectedly modest. ~~~ His diffidence had prevented his depending on his own judgment in so anxious a case, but his reliance on mine, made every thing easy.
fr: -- Oui, Bingley est l'homme le plus essentiellement modeste que je connoisse, sa defiance de lui-meme l'avoit empeche de s'en remettre a son propre jugement dans une affaire aussi delicate, la confiance qu'il avoit en moi a fait le reste.

eng: I was obliged to confess one thing, which for a time, and not unjustly, offended him. ~~~ I could not allow myself to conceal that your sister had been in town three months last winter, that I had known it, and purposely kept it from him.
fr: Elisabeth ne pouvoit s'empecher de penser que M. Bingley etoit l'ami le plus commode qu'on put avoir, et que la facilite avec laquelle on le conduisoit devoit le rendre d'un prix inestimable comme epoux ; mais elle se souvint que Mr.

eng: He was angry. ~~~ But his anger, I am persuaded, lasted no longer than he remained in any doubt of your sister's sentiments.
fr: Darcy n'avoit pas ete accoutume a la plaisanterie, elle se tut, pensant que ce seroit commencer de trop bonne heure.

eng: He has heartily forgiven me now." ~~~ Elizabeth longed to observe that Mr. Bingley had been a most delightful friend; so easily guided that his worth was invaluable; but she checked herself.
fr: Ils arriverent a la maison, en s'entretenant du bonheur de Bingley, que Mr.

eng: She remembered that he had yet to learn to be laught at, and it was rather too early to begin.
In anticipating the happiness of Bingley, which of course was to be inferior only to his own, he continued the conversation till they reached the house.
In the hall they parted.
fr: Darcy trouvoit bien inferieur au sien.

eng: CHAPTER XVII.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE XI.

eng: "My dear Lizzy, where can you have been walking to?"
fr: Ma chere Lizzy, ou avez-vous donc ete vous promener ?

eng: was a question which Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as she entered the room, and from all the others when they sat down to table.
fr: fut la question que Jane fit a Elisabeth lorsqu'elle entra dans la chambre, et que chacun lui repeta lorsqu'on se reunit pour diner ; elle ne savoit que repondre, sinon qu'ils avoient promene sans trop savoir ou ; elle rougit en disant cela, mais ni son embarras ni sa rougeur, ne donnerent de soupcons a personne.

eng: She had only to say in reply, that they had wandered about, till she was beyond her own knowledge.
fr: La soiree se passa fort tranquillement ; les amans reconnus parloient et rioient ensemble ; les inconnus gardoient le silence.

eng: She coloured as she spoke; but neither that, nor any thing else, awakened a suspicion of the truth.
fr: Darcy n'etoit pas d'un caractere auquel le bonheur inspire une joie bruyante ; et Elisabeth, agitee et confuse, savoit qu'elle etoit heureuse plus qu'elle ne l'eprouvoit encore.

eng: The evening passed quietly, unmarked by any thing extraordinary.
fr: Car, outre l'embarras du moment, elle etoit inquiete de la maniere dont son mariage seroit recu dans sa famille.

eng: The acknowledged lovers talked and laughed, the unacknowledged were silent.
fr: Elle savoit bien qu'il n'y avoit que Jane qui rendit justice a Mr.

eng: Darcy was not of a disposition in which happiness overflows in mirth; and Elizabeth, agitated and confused, rather _knew_ that she was happy, than _felt_ herself to be so; for, besides the immediate embarrassment, there were other evils before her.

She anticipated what would be felt in the family when her situation became known; she was aware that no one liked him but Jane; and even feared that with the others it was a _dislike_ which not all his fortune and consequence might do away.
fr: Darcy ; tous les autres avoient pour lui un tel eloignement, qu'elle craignoit que son rang et sa fortune ne pussent pas meme le dissiper.

eng: This cannot be!--engaged to Mr. Darcy! ~~~ No, no, you shall not deceive me.
fr: -- Vous plaisantez, Lizzy, cela ne peut pas etre ; vous, engagee avec Mr.

eng: I know it to be impossible."
fr: Darcy !

eng: "This is a wretched beginning indeed!
fr: non, vous me trompez, cela est impossible !

eng: My sole dependence was on you; and I am sure nobody else will believe me, if you do not.
Yet, indeed, I am in earnest.
fr: -- C'est un bien triste debut !

eng: I speak nothing but the truth.
fr: Toute mon esperance reposoit en vous !

eng: He still loves me, and we are engaged." ~~~ Jane looked at her doubtingly. ~~~ "Oh, Lizzy!
fr: Si vous ne voulez pas ajouter foi a ce que je vous dis, qui me croira ?

eng: it cannot be. ~~~ I know how much you dislike him." ~~~ "You know nothing of the matter.
fr: Oui, je parle serieusement, je dis la verite ; il m'aime toujours, et nous sommes promis.

eng: _That_ is all to be forgot. ~~~ Perhaps I did not always love him so well as I do now.
fr: Jane la regardoit avec etonnement, et doutoit encore ; dites-moi, Lizzy, comment voulez-vous que je le croie, je sais que vous le detestiez !

eng: But in such cases as these, a good memory is unpardonable. ~~~ This is the last time I shall ever remember it myself."
fr: -- Tout est oublie ; je ne l'ai peut-etre pas toujours autant aime qu'a present ; mais, dans une occasion comme celle-ci, une memoire fidele est une chose odieuse, et c'est la derniere fois que je veux me souvenir de moi-meme.

eng: Miss Bennet still looked all amazement.
fr: Miss Bennet la regardoit encore avec une surprise extreme, et Elisabeth protestoit toujours qu'elle disoit la verite.

eng: Elizabeth again, and more seriously assured her of its truth.
fr: -- Bon Dieu, cela peut-il etre !

eng: "Good Heaven! ~~~ can it be really so!
fr: Cependant je dois vous croire.

eng: Yet now I must believe you," cried Jane.
fr: Lizzy, ma chere Lizzy !

eng: "My dear, dear Lizzy, I would--I do congratulate you--but are you certain?
fr: je vous felicite ; mais etes-vous bien sure, pardonnez cette question, etes-vous bien sure que vous l'aimez ?

eng: forgive the question--are you quite certain that you can be happy with him?"
fr: que vous serez heureuse avec lui ?

eng: "There can be no doubt of that.
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ je n'en doute pas !

eng: do any thing rather than marry without affection.
fr: Ne vous mariez pas sans amour !

eng: Are you quite sure that you feel what you ought to do?"
fr: Etes-vous bien sure de l'aimer assez ?

eng: "Oh, yes! ~~~ You will only think I feel _more_ than I ought to do, when I tell you all."
fr: -- Vous trouverez peut-etre que je l'aime trop, lorsque je vous dirai tout.

eng: "What do you mean?"
fr: -- Que voulez-vous dire ?

eng: "Why, I must confess, that I love him better than I do Bingley.
fr: -- Je crains que vous ne soyez fachee si je vous avoue que je crois l'aimer encore plus que vous n'aimez Bingley.

eng: I am afraid you will be angry."
fr: -- Oh !

eng: "My dearest sister, now _be_ be serious. ~~~ I want to talk very seriously. ~~~ Let me know every thing that I am to know, without delay.
fr: ma soeur cherie, ne plaisantez plus, parlez serieusement, apprenez-moi tout ; depuis quand l'aimez-vous ?

eng: Will you tell me how long you have loved him?" ~~~ "It has been coming on so gradually, that I hardly know when it began.
fr: -- Cela est venu tellement par gradation, que je sais a peine quand cela a commence ; mais je crois que je puis dater mon sentiment pour lui du moment ou j'ai vu sa superbe terre de Pemberley.

eng: But I believe I must date it from my first seeing his beautiful grounds at Pemberley."
fr: Jane la supplia encore d'abandonner le ton de la plaisanterie.

eng: Another intreaty that she would be serious, however, produced the desired effect; and she soon satisfied Jane by her solemn assurances of attachment.
fr: Elisabeth prit enfin sur elle de parler serieusement, et parvint a persuader sa soeur de la verite de son attachement pour Mr. ~~~ Darcy.

eng: When convinced on that article, Miss Bennet had nothing farther to wish. ~~~ "Now I am quite happy," said she, "for you will be as happy as myself. ~~~ I always had a value for him.
fr: -- Maintenant, dit Jane, je n'ai plus rien a desirer, car vous serez aussi heureuse que moi ; j'ai toujours eu beaucoup d'estime pour lui, et l'amour qu'il eprouve ne peut que la confirmer.

eng: Were it for nothing but his love of you, I must always have esteemed him; but now, as Bingley's friend and your husband, there can be only Bingley and yourself more dear to me.
fr: Desormais, comme votre epoux et comme ami du mien, aucun homme ne peut m'etre plus cher que lui, apres Bingley lui-meme.

eng: But Lizzy, you have been very sly, very reserved with me.
fr: Mais, Lizzy, comment avez-vous pu etre si reservee vis-a-vis de moi ?

eng: How little did you tell me of what passed at Pemberley and Lambton!
fr: Comment ne m'avez-vous rien dit de ce qui s'etoit passe a Pemberley et a Lambton ?

eng: I owe all that I know of it, to another, not to you."
fr: Tout ce que j'ai su, je l'ai su par d'autres que par vous.

eng: Elizabeth told her the motives of her secrecy.
fr: Elisabeth lui dit alors le motif qu'elle avoit eu de garder le silence.

eng: She had been unwilling to mention Bingley; and the unsettled state of her own feelings had made her equally avoid the name of his friend.
fr: Ne voulant pas parler de Bingley, elle avoit craint dans son inquietude, de prononcer le nom meme de son ami.

eng: But now she would no longer conceal from her, his share in Lydia's marriage.
fr: Elle lui raconta aussi la part que Mr.

eng: All was acknowledged, and half the night spent in conversation.
fr: Darcy avoit eue au mariage de Lydie, et la moitie de la nuit se passa dans cette conversation.

eng: cried Mrs. Bennet, as she stood at a window the next morning, "if that disagreeable Mr. Darcy is not coming here again with our dear Bingley!
fr: s'ecria Mistriss Bennet qui etoit a la fenetre le lendemain matin, voila encore cet ennuyeux Mr. ~~~ Darcy qui vient avec notre cher Bingley !

eng: What can he mean by being so tiresome as to be always coming here?
fr: A quoi pense-t-il donc de venir si souvent ici !

eng: I had no notion but he would go a shooting, or something or other, and not disturb us with his company.
fr: Il devroit bien aller a la chasse, ou faire toute autre chose, plutot que de nous fatiguer constamment de sa desagreable societe.

eng: What shall we do with him?
fr: Que ferons-nous de lui ?

eng: Lizzy, you must walk out with him again, that he may not be in Bingley's way."
fr: Lizzy, il faut que vous alliez encore vous promener avec lui.

eng: Elizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal; yet was really vexed that her mother should be always giving him such an epithet.
fr: Il ne faut pas qu'il soit toujours aux cotes de Bingley. ~~~ Elisabeth put a peine s'empecher de rire de l'arrangement que faisoit sa mere, et qui venoit si fort a-propos.
Elle etoit cependant fachee des epithetes qu'elle lui avoit donnees.
En entrant, Bingley lui serra la main et la regarda avec une expression telle, qu'elle ne put pas douter que Mr.

eng: As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her so expressively, and shook hands with such warmth, as left no doubt of his good information; and he soon afterwards said aloud, "Mr. Bennet, have you no more lanes hereabouts in which Lizzy may lose her way again to-day?"
fr: Darcy ne lui eut fait part de ce qui s'etoit passe la veille. ~~~ -- Mistriss Bennet, dit-il tout haut, n'avez-vous plus de grands chemins dans vos environs ou Lizzy puisse encore se perdre, comme hier ? ~~~ -- Je conseille a Mr.

eng: "I advise Mr. Darcy, and Lizzy, and Kitty," said Mrs. Bennet, "to walk to Oakham Mount this morning.
fr: Darcy, a Lizzy et a Kitty, dit Mistriss Bennet, d'aller promener du cote de Oakham-Mount, ce matin ; c'est une tres-longue et tres jolie promenade, Mr.

eng: It is a nice long walk, and Mr. Darcy has never seen the view."
fr: Darcy ne la connoit pas. ~~~ -- C'est tres-bien pour lui, reprit Mr.

eng: "It may do very well for the others," replied Mr. Bingley; "but I am sure it will be too much for Kitty.
fr: Bingley, mais je suis sur que ce sera trop long pour Kitty.

eng: Wont it, Kitty?"
fr: N'est-ce pas, Kitty ?

eng: Kitty owned that she had rather stay at home.
fr: Kitty avoua qu'elle preferoit rester a la maison.

eng: Darcy professed a great curiosity to see the view from the Mount, and Elizabeth silently consented.
fr: Darcy temoigna la plus vive curiosite de connoitre cette jolie promenade, et Elisabeth consentit a la lui faire faire.

eng: As she went up stairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her, saying, "I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that disagreeable man all to yourself.
fr: Comme elle montoit a sa chambre pour prendre son chapeau, Mistriss Bennet la suivit en disant : -- Je suis bien fachee, Lizzy, que vous soyez obligee de vous charger toute seule de cet ennuyeux personnage, mais j'espere que vous ne vous en inquieterez pas trop ; c'est pour en debarrasser Jane.

eng: But I hope you will not mind it: it is all for Jane's sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking to him, except just now and then.
fr: Il n'y a pas besoin de lui parler constamment, un mot de temps a autre seulement, cela suffit ; ainsi, ne vous en tourmentez pas trop.

eng: So, do not put yourself to inconvenience."
fr: Ils convinrent pendant leur promenade que Mr.

eng: During their walk, it was resolved that Mr. Bennet's consent should be asked in the course of the evening.
fr: Darcy demanderoit le soir meme, le consentement de Mr.

eng: Elizabeth reserved to herself the application for her mother's.
fr: Bennet. ~~~ Elisabeth se reserva de demander celui de sa mere.

eng: She could not determine how her mother would take it; sometimes doubting whether all his wealth and grandeur would be enough to overcome her abhorrence of the man.
fr: Elle doutoit quelquefois que la richesse et le rang de Mr. ~~~ Darcy fussent suffisans pour lui faire surmonter l'aversion qu'elle avoit pour lui.

eng: But whether she were violently set against the match, or violently delighted with it, it was certain that her manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit to her sense; and she could no more bear that Mr. Darcy should hear the first raptures of her joy, than the first vehemence of her disapprobation.
fr: Mais, soit que ce mariage lui fit beaucoup de peine, soit qu'il lui fut agreable, il n'en etoit pas moins certain que sa maniere d'en exprimer son sentiment ne feroit pas honneur a son jugement, et Elisabeth preferoit que Mr. ~~~ Darcy ne fut pas la dans le premier moment.

eng: * * * * * In the evening, soon after Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library, she saw Mr. Darcy rise also and follow him, and her agitation on seeing it was extreme.
fr: Lorsque Mr. ~~~ Bennet se fut retire apres le the dans sa bibliotheque, Mr. ~~~ Darcy se leva et l'y suivit.

eng: She did not fear her father's opposition, but he was going to be made unhappy, and that it should be through her means, that _she_, his favourite child, should be distressing him by her choice, should be filling him with fears and regrets in disposing of her, was a wretched reflection, and she sat in misery till Mr. Darcy appeared again, when, looking at him, she was a little relieved by his smile.
fr: Elisabeth fut alors saisie d'une extreme emotion ; elle ne craignoit point d'opposition de la part de son pere, mais elle eprouvoit un vif chagrin en pensant qu'elle, sa fille favorite, alloit peut-etre l'affliger par son choix et le rendre malheureux en disposant ainsi d'elle-meme. ~~~ Elle fut dans cette anxiete jusqu'au moment ou elle vit revenir Mr. ~~~ Darcy.

eng: In a few minutes he approached the table where she was sitting with Kitty; and, while pretending to admire her work, said in a whisper, "Go to your father, he wants you in the library."
fr: Il sourioit ; peu de minutes apres il s'approcha d'elle, sous pretexte de regarder son ouvrage, et lui dit tout bas : -- Allez vers votre pere, il vous attend dans sa bibliotheque...

eng: She was gone directly.
fr: Elle y alla tout de suite.

eng: Her father was walking about the room, looking grave and anxious.
fr: Mr. ~~~ Bennet se promenoit dans sa chambre, d'un air inquiet et agite.

eng: "Lizzy," said he, "what are you doing?
fr: -- Lizzy, lui dit il, que faites-vous ?

eng: Are you out of your senses, to be accepting this man?
fr: Etes-vous dans votre bon sens en acceptant la main de cet homme ?

eng: Have not you always hated him?"
fr: Ne l'avez-vous pas toujours deteste ?

eng: It would have spared her from explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give; but they were now necessary, and she assured him with some confusion, of her attachment to Mr. Darcy.
fr: Elles lui auroient epargne des explications et des protestations tres-embarrassantes, et cependant absolument necessaires. ~~~ Elle assura son pere, non sans un peu de confusion, qu'elle aimoit beaucoup Mr. ~~~ Darcy.

eng: "Or in other words, you are determined to have him.
fr: -- Oui, ou en d'autres termes, reprit-il, vous etes decidee a l'epouser ?

eng: He is rich, to be sure, and you may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane. ~~~ But will they make you happy?"
fr: Il est fort riche et vous aurez certainement de plus belles robes et de plus beaux equipages que Jane ; mais vous rendront-ils heureuse ?

eng: "Have you any other objection," said Elizabeth, "than your belief of my indifference?"
fr: -- N'avez-vous pas d'autres objections a faire que celle de mon indifference ?

eng: "None at all.
fr: dit Elisabeth.

eng: We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of man; but this would be nothing if you really liked him."
fr: -- Non, aucune. ~~~ Nous le connoissons pour etre fier et peu aimable ; mais cela ne fait rien, si vous l'aimez.

eng: "I do, I do like him," she replied, with tears in her eyes, "I love him.
fr: -- Oui, je l'aime, repondit-elle les larmes aux yeux.

eng: Indeed he has no improper pride.
fr: Son orgueil n'est pas indomptable, il est parfaitement aimable.

eng: He is perfectly amiable.
fr: Vous ne savez pas ce qu'il vaut dans le fond.

eng: You do not know what he really is; then pray do not pain me by speaking of him in such terms."
fr: Je vous en supplie, ne m'affligez pas en me parlant de lui de cette maniere.

eng: "Lizzy," said her father, "I have given him my consent.
fr: -- Lizzy, reprit son pere, je lui ai donne mon consentement.

eng: He is the kind of man, indeed, to whom I should never dare refuse any thing, which he condescended to ask.
fr: C'est un homme a qui en verite je n'oserai jamais rien refuser de ce qu'il aura la bonte de me demander.

eng: I now give it to _you_, if you are resolved on having him.
fr: A present je vous le donne aussi, si vous etes resolue a l'epouser ; mais permettez-moi de vous conseiller d'y reflechir encore.
Je connois bien votre caractere, Lizzy ; je sais que vous ne serez jamais heureuse si vous n'estimez pas votre mari, si vous ne le regardez pas comme un etre superieur.

eng: But let me advise you to think better of it. ~~~ I know your disposition, Lizzy.
fr: La vivacite de votre esprit vous mettra dans le plus grand danger, si vous faites un mariage inegal.

eng: I know that you could be neither happy nor respectable, unless you truly esteemed your husband; unless you looked up to him as a superior.
fr: Vous n'echapperez point a la honte et au malheur, si vous ne pouvez pas respecter le compagnon de votre vie !

eng: Your lively talents would place you in the greatest danger in an unequal marriage.
fr: Ah ! ~~~ ne me donnez pas ce chagrin, mon enfant !

eng: You could scarcely escape discredit and misery.
fr: Vous ne savez pas tout ce que vous etes, vous ne vous appreciez pas a votre juste valeur !

eng: My child, let me not have the grief of seeing _you_ unable to respect your partner in life.
fr: Elisabeth, encore plus emue, fut alors plus positive et plus solennelle dans ses reponses.

eng: You know not what you are about."
fr: Elle reussit enfin a persuader a son pere, que Mr.

eng: Elizabeth, still more affected, was earnest and solemn in her reply; and at length, by repeated assurances that Mr. Darcy was really the object of her choice, by explaining the gradual change which her estimation of him had undergone, relating her absolute certainty that his affection was not the work of a day, but had stood the test of many months suspense, and enumerating with energy all his good qualities, she did conquer her father's incredulity, and reconcile him to the match.
fr: Darcy etoit bien veritablement l'objet de son choix et de sa tendresse, en lui expliquant le changement graduel qu'avoient subi ses sentimens pour lui, et en lui prouvant que son amour ne datoit pas d'un jour, mais de plusieurs mois. ~~~ Elle parvint ainsi, en decouvrant toutes les bonnes qualites de Darcy, a vaincre l'incredulite de son pere et a le reconcilier avec l'idee de cette union. ~~~ -- Eh bien !

eng: I could not have parted with you, my Lizzy, to any one less worthy."
fr: Je n'aurois jamais pu me separer de ma Lizzy pour l'accorder a un homme qui n'en auroit pas ete digne.

eng: To complete the favourable impression, she then told him what Mr. Darcy had voluntarily done for Lydia.
fr: Alors, pour augmenter encore l'impression favorable qu'il venoit de recevoir, elle lui dit tout ce que Mr.

eng: He heard her with astonishment.
fr: Darcy avoit fait pour Lydie.

eng: "This is an evening of wonders, indeed!
fr: Il l'ecoutoit avec etonnement.

eng: And so, Darcy did every thing; made up the match, gave the money, paid the fellow's debts, and got him his commission!
fr: -- En verite, c'est une journee de miracles que celle-ci ! ~~~ Et c'est Mr.

eng: So much the better.
fr: Darcy qui a fait tout cela !

eng: It will save me a world of trouble and economy.
fr: Il a fait le mariage, il a donne l'argent, il a paye les dettes, achete la commission !

eng: Had it been your uncle's doing, I must and _would_ have paid him; but these violent young lovers carry every thing their own way.
fr: Tant mieux, cela m'evite beaucoup de depenses et de peines ! ~~~ Si c'eut ete votre oncle, j'aurois voulu et j'aurois du le rembourser.
Mais ces jeunes amans sont ardens, et il faut leur laisser faire les choses comme ils l'entendent.
Demain je lui offrirai de le payer, je lui dirai meme que je le veux : il se fachera, tempetera, parlera de son amour ; il faudra bien ceder, et tout sera fini.

eng: I shall offer to pay him to-morrow; he will rant and storm about his love for you, and there will be an end of the matter."
fr: Il se souvint alors de l'embarras qu'elle avoit du eprouver quelques jours auparavant pendant qu'il lui lisoit la lettre de Mr.

eng: He then recollected her embarrassment a few days before, on his reading Mr. Collins's letter; and after laughing at her some time, allowed her at last to go--saying, as she quitted the room, "If any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at leisure."
fr: Collins ; et apres l'avoir un peu plaisantee, il lui permit de s'en aller, en lui disant lorsqu'elle quitta la chambre : -- S'il y avoit encore quelques jeunes gens qui voulussent se presenter pour Mary ou pour Kitty, vous pouvez me les envoyer pendant que je suis bien dispose.

eng: When her mother went up to her dressing-room at night, she followed her, and made the important communication.
fr: Lorsque Mistriss Bennet se retira dans sa chambre pour se coucher, Elisabeth la suivit et lui fit l'importante communication de la demande de Mr. ~~~ Darcy.
Elle produisit un effet tres-extraordinaire.

eng: Its effect was most extraordinary; for on first hearing it, Mrs. Bennet sat quite still, and unable to utter a syllable.
fr: Mistriss Bennet ne l'eut pas plutot entendue, qu'elle s'assit, incapable de se soutenir et de proferer une syllabe.

eng: Nor was it under many, many minutes, that she could comprehend what she heard; though not in general backward to credit what was for the advantage of her family, or that came in the shape of a lover to any of them.
fr: Elle resta pendant cinq minutes sans pouvoir comprendre ce qu'elle entendoit, quoiqu'elle fut tres-prompte ordinairement a saisir tout ce qui pouvoit etre a l'avantage de ses filles, surtout quand il etoit question de mariage.

eng: She began at length to recover, to fidget about in her chair, get up, sit down again, wonder, and bless herself.
fr: Elle commenca enfin a reprendre l'usage de ses facultes et a s'agiter sur sa chaise ; elle se leva, se rassit, se releva, puis enfin eclata en benedictions sur elle-meme.

eng: only think!
fr: Qui auroit pu l'imaginer !

eng: dear me!
fr: Que je suis heureuse !

eng: Mr. Darcy!
fr: Mr.

eng: Who would have thought it!
fr: Darcy !

eng: And is it really true? ~~~ Oh!
fr: qui auroit pu le croire ?

eng: my sweetest Lizzy!
fr: Est-ce bien vrai ?

eng: how rich and how great you will be!
fr: Oh, ma chere Lizzy, que vous serez riche, que vous serez noble !

eng: Such a charming man!--so handsome!
fr: C'est un charmant homme, si beau, l'air si noble !

eng: so tall!--Oh, my dear Lizzy!
fr: Oh ma bien-aimee Lizzy !

eng: pray apologise for my having disliked him so much before.
fr: pardonnez-moi de l'avoir deteste si long-temps.

eng: I hope he will overlook it.
fr: J'espere qu'il ne m'en voudra pas !

eng: Dear, dear Lizzy.
fr: Chere, chere Lizzy !

eng: A house in town! ~~~ Every thing that is charming!
fr: Une maison a la ville, une superbe terre, tout ce qui est agreable !

eng: Three daughters married!
fr: Trois filles mariees !

eng: Ten thousand a year!
fr: Dix mille livres par an !

eng: Oh, Lord!
fr: Oh !

eng: What will become of me.
fr: Seigneur, que deviendrai-je ?

eng: Ten thousand a year, and very likely more!
fr: Dix mille livres par an, et peut-etre meme davantage !
C'est un aussi bon parti qu'un Lord, et vous serez maries par une licence particuliere, ce sera delicieux !

eng: 'Tis as good as a Lord! ~~~ And a special licence.
fr: Mais, mon cher enfant, dites-moi quel est le plat que Mr.

eng: You must and shall be married by a special licence.
fr: Darcy aime de predilection, je voudrois le faire faire demain pour le diner.

eng: But my dearest love, tell me what dish Mr. Darcy is particularly fond of, that I may have it to-morrow."
fr: C'etoit un triste presage de ce que seroit la conduite de sa mere vis-a-vis de Mr.

eng: This was a sad omen of what her mother's behaviour to the gentleman himself might be; and Elizabeth found, that though in the certain possession of his warmest affection, and secure of her relations' consent, there was still something to be wished for.
fr: Darcy ; Elisabeth sentit que, malgre qu'elle fut sure de posseder son coeur et qu'elle eut le consentement de ses parens, elle avoit encore quelque chose a desirer. ~~~ Le lendemain matin se passa cependant mieux qu'elle n'auroit ose l'esperer.

eng: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing her father taking pains to get acquainted with him; and Mr. Bennet soon assured her that he was rising every hour in his esteem.
fr: Elisabeth eut la satisfaction de voir que son pere prenoit de la peine pour faire connoissance avec Mr.

eng: "I admire all my three sons-in-law highly," said he.
fr: Darcy, et il avoua qu'il gagnoit beaucoup a etre connu.

eng: "Wickham, perhaps, is my favourite; but I think I shall like _your_ husband quite as well as Jane's."
fr: -- J'admire extremement mes trois gendres, disoit-il ; j'avoue que Wikam est toujours mon favori ; mais, Lizzy, je crois bien que je finirai par aimer votre mari autant que celui de Jane.

eng: CHAPTER XVIII.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE XII.

eng: Elizabeth's spirits soon rising to playfulness again, she wanted Mr. Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her.
fr: L'esprit d'Elisabeth reprit bientot son enjouement.

eng: "How could you begin?"
fr: Elle voulut que Mr.

eng: said she. ~~~ "I can comprehend your going on charmingly, when you had once made a beginning; but what could set you off in the first place?"
"I cannot fix on the hour, or the spot, or the look, or the words, which laid the foundation.
fr: Darcy lui expliquat comment il etoit devenu amoureux d'elle.

eng: It is too long ago. ~~~ I was in the middle before I knew that I _had_ begun."
fr: -- Je comprends tres-bien que vous ayez continue ; mais qu'est-ce qui vous a d'abord charme en moi ?

eng: "My beauty you had early withstood, and as for my manners--my behaviour to _you_ was at least always bordering on the uncivil, and I never spoke to you without rather wishing to give you pain than not.
fr: -- Je ne saurois fixer ni l'heure, ni la place, ni l'expression, ni les paroles qui commencerent a me seduire ; il y a trop long-temps que je vous aime, et j'etois deja passionne avant que je me fusse apercu que vous me plaisiez.

eng: Now be sincere; did you admire me for my impertinence?" ~~~ "For the liveliness of your mind, I did."
fr: -- Vous avez franchement nie que je fusse jolie, et mes manieres devoient vous etre peu agreables, puisque j'avois presque toujours le desir de vous blesser au moins legerement.

eng: "You may as well call it impertinence at once.
fr: A present, soyez sincere, avouez que vous avez commence a etre seduit par mon impertinence !

eng: It was very little less.
fr: -- Par la vivacite de votre esprit.

eng: The fact is, that you were sick of civility, of deference, of officious attention.
fr: -- Appelez-la seulement impertinence, j'en etois toujours si pres !

eng: You were disgusted with the women who were always speaking and looking, and thinking for _your_ approbation alone.
fr: Le fait est que vous etiez blase, a force de politesses, de deferences, de prevenances ; vous etiez ennuye de voir toujours des femmes uniquement occupees a rechercher votre approbation.

eng: I roused, and interested you, because I was so unlike _them_.
fr: Je vous reveillai de votre apathie et je vous amusai, parce que je ne leur ressemblois point.

eng: "Dearest Jane!
fr: -- Chere Jane !

eng: who could have done less for her?
But make a virtue of it by all means.
fr: auroit-on pu faire moins pour elle ?

eng: My good qualities are under your protection, and you are to exaggerate them as much as possible; and, in return, it belongs to me to find occasions for teazing and quarrelling with you as often as may be; and I shall begin directly by asking you what made you so unwilling to come to the point at last.
fr: Mais erigez tout en vertu chez moi, si vous le voulez ; mes bonnes qualites sont sous votre protection, et vous devez chercher a les exagerer autant que possible ; en retour, je vous promets de chercher toutes les occasions de vous tourmenter et de vous contredire.

eng: What made you so shy of me, when you first called, and afterwards dined here?
fr: Pour commencer, je vous demanderai pourquoi vous etiez si peu empresse d'arriver a la conclusion ?

eng: Why, especially, when you called, did you look as if you did not care about me?"
fr: Qu'est-ce qui vous rendoit si froid, si reserve lorsque vous vintes ici faire visite ?

eng: "Because you were grave and silent, and gave me no encouragement."
fr: Pourquoi aviez-vous l'air de ne point vous occuper de moi ?
-- Parce que vous etiez serieuse et taciturne, et que vous ne m'encouragiez point du tout.

eng: "But I was embarrassed."
fr: -- Mais j'etois embarrassee.

eng: "And so was I."
fr: -- Et moi aussi.

eng: "You might have talked to me more when you came to dinner."
fr: -- Vous auriez pu me parler davantage le jour que vous vintes diner ici.

eng: "A man who had felt less, might."
fr: -- Je l'aurois fait si j'avois senti moins vivement.

eng: "How unlucky that you should have a reasonable answer to give, and that I should be so reasonable as to admit it!
fr: -- Qu'il est malheureux que vous ayez toujours une reponse satisfaisante a me faire, et que je sois assez raisonnable pour l'admettre !

eng: But I wonder how long you _would_ have gone on, if you had been left to yourself.
fr: Mais je voudrois savoir combien de temps vous auriez pu continuer ainsi, si vous aviez ete laisse a vous-meme ?

eng: I wonder when you _would_ have spoken, if I had not asked you!
fr: Je voudrois savoir quand vous auriez parle, si je n'avois pas commence ?

eng: My resolution of thanking you for your kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect.
fr: La ferme resolution que j'avois prise de vous remercier des bontes que vous avez eues pour Lydie, a eu beaucoup d'effet, trop peut-etre je le crains !

eng: _Too much_, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort springs from a breach of promise, for I ought not to have mentioned the subject?
fr: Car que deviendroit la morale, si notre felicite devoit naitre d'une promesse enfreinte, d'une parole trahie !

eng: This will never do." ~~~ "You need not distress yourself.
fr: Je n'aurois pas du etre instruite de cette affaire-la, et alors ?

eng: The moral will be perfectly fair.
fr: tout le reste ne seroit pas arrive.

eng: Lady Catherine's unjustifiable endeavours to separate us, were the means of removing all my doubts.
fr: -- Ne vous affligez pas, ma chere Elisabeth, il y a moyen de tout arranger ; la morale sera parfaitement hors d'atteinte.

eng: I am not indebted for my present happiness to your eager desire of expressing your gratitude. ~~~ I was not in a humour to wait for any opening of your's.
fr: Les efforts impertinens de Lady Catherine pour nous separer ont justement detruit tous mes doutes, et ce n'est point a cette parole trahie, a votre empressement de me temoigner votre reconnoissance, que je dois mon bonheur actuel.

eng: My aunt's intelligence had given me hope, and I was determined at once to know every thing."
fr: Ce que ma tante m'avoit appris, avoit ranime toutes mes esperances, et j'etois decide a parler.

eng: "Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy, for she loves to be of use.
fr: -- Ainsi, Lady Catherine nous a rendu un grand service ; cela doit lui faire bien plaisir, car elle aime beaucoup a etre utile aux autres.

eng: But tell me, what did you come down to Netherfield for? ~~~ Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed?
fr: Mais dites-moi, aurez-vous le courage d'annoncer a Lady Catherine le succes qu'ont eu ses efforts pour nous faire renoncer l'un a l'autre ?

eng: or had you intended any more serious consequence?"
fr: -- Pouvez-vous en douter ?

eng: "My real purpose was to see _you_, and to judge, if I could, whether I might ever hope to make you love me.
fr: Si vous voulez me donner une feuille de papier, je le ferai tout de suite, pour ne pas la laisser plus long-temps dans l'inquietude.

eng: My avowed one, or what I avowed to myself, was to see whether your sister were still partial to Bingley, and if she were, to make the confession to him which I have since made." ~~~ "Shall you ever have courage to announce to Lady Catherine, what is to befall her?"
fr: -- Ah ! ~~~ si je n'avois pas moi-meme une lettre a ecrire, je pourrois m'asseoir a cote de vous, et admirer l'egalite de votre ecriture, la regularite de vos lignes, comme le faisoit jadis une jeune dame.

eng: "I am more likely to want time than courage, Elizabeth.
fr: Mais j'ai aussi une tante et je ne dois pas la negliger.

eng: But it ought to be done, and if you will give me a sheet of paper, it shall be done directly."
fr: Elisabeth n'avoit point encore repondu a la longue lettre de Mistriss Gardiner.

eng: "And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you, and admire the evenness of your writing, as another young lady once did. ~~~ But I have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected."
fr: Elle avoit senti qu'elle devoit detruire les esperances que son oncle et sa tante paroissoient avoir concues pour elle ; et elle n'avoit pas eu le courage de leur dire que probablement Mr.

eng: From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy had been over-rated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner's long letter, but now, having _that_ to communicate which she knew would be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find, that her uncle and aunt had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as follows: "I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done, for your long, kind, satisfactory, detail of particulars; but to say the truth, I was too cross to write.
